## Page 5

A BSTRACT On behalf of the City of Denton and Freese and Nichols, Inc., Acacia Heritage Consulting conducted archeological significance testing and data recovery excavations at sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 within the Hickory Creek Interceptor alignment in Denton County, Texas. The project is sponsored by the City of Denton; thus, investigations were conducted in compliance with the Antiquities Code of Texas (ACT) under Permit 30127. Rachel Feit served as Principal Investigator. The Hickory Creek Interceptor project will involve construction of an approximately 2.46- mile-long sewer line in central Denton County, extending from west of IH 35 West to an outfall located east of US Route 377. The project area for the previous survey efforts included the 60-ft-wide utility easement along the entirety of the proposed line. In October 2020, Acacia’s survey identified two archeological sites within the alignment, 41DN580 and 41DN624. Both sites are on the bank of Hickory Creek southwest of the City of Denton. The Texas Historical Commission (THC) recommended avoidance or, if avoidance is not possible, additional testing to determine State Antiquities Landmark (SAL) and National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) eligibility. Therefore, from 2021-2022, Acacia conducted testing excavations. Subsequent coordination with THC indicated that both 41DN580 and 41DN624 are eligible for listing as SAL and NRHP properties. Data recovery and mitigation excavations at both sites were therefore undertaken by Acacia. This report presents the results of the eligibility testing and data recovery investigations conducted from May 2021 through January 2022. Acacia’s work was conducted under the ACT. The testing and data recovery investigations at sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 sought to identify site chronology and the number of occupations or components at each. Additionally, Acacia hypothesized that the features and their associated activities would allow us to address group foraging strategies and potentially identify seasonal occupation patterns. Finally, Acacia hoped to estimate the size of the social groups occupying the sites and understand their mobility patterns over time. Eligibility testing efforts at site 41DN580 showed it is a stratified multicomponent Prehistoric site on the southwest bank of Hickory Creek. The site contains components dating to the Middle Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. Acacia summarized the results of testing efforts in an interim report that was submitted to THC for regulatory review. THC recommended 41DN580 as eligible for listing as a SAL and NRHP property. Therefore, data recovery and site mitigation efforts were undertaken. Acacia investigated site components through intensive mechanical excavations and scraping, geomorphological study, and hand excavations. A total of 32 cubic meters of sediment was hand-excavated from the site during both phases of investigation. During these excavations, 18 Archaic period features were identified, along with a Late Prehistoric site component initially identified as Feature 14. Archaic period features are primarily composed of fire-cracked rock (FCR) and represent the remains of various cook stone activities. Acacia’s efforts showed that these features represent a range of domestic activities that utilized various aspects of the local environmental mosaic over time. The Late Prehistoric component is represented by scattered, discarded occupation debris from what was probably a temporary campsite (or series of campsites) based on the lack of defined features but the presence of a variety of small and exhausted artifacts. This component notably Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 i


---

## Page 6

includes Nacona Plain ceramics, which radiocarbon dates indicate may be some of the earliest examples from the region. Likewise, testing revealed site 41DN624 is a multicomponent Prehistoric site with occupations during the Middle and Late Archaic periods. Initial results of testing efforts were submitted to THC in an interim report. The site was recommended as eligible for listing as a SAL and in the NRHP, and data recovery and mitigation efforts were undertaken. Acacia used similar methods as at 41DN580, revealing 13 Archaic period features through excavation of about 25 cubic meters of sediment. These are similarly composed mostly of FCR and represent cook stone activities that utilized multiple resources in the local environment. Features represent three primary periods of occupation from the Middle through Late Archaic periods. Acacia was tentatively able to distinguish several associated activity areas from the latter period. Excavations at both 41DN580 and 41DN624 were limited to the Hickory Creek Interceptor ROW, and therefore the exposures afforded only partial glimpses of the sites. Based on the assemblages recovered, both sites are interpreted as temporary camps as indicated by the predominance of single-use cook stone/FCR features and faunal remains, but a general lack of tools or other artifacts. These occupations show how small groups of hunter-foragers used the abundance of riparian environmental mosaic resources across thousands of years. Although the overall artifact assemblage was relatively small, the number of features and assemblage patterns allow Acacia to address the research questions posed. Site 41DN580 contains at least three primary periods of occupation dating to the Middle Archaic and the Late Prehistoric. 41DN624 likewise has three primary occupations dating to the Middle and Late Archaic periods. At both sites, our interpretations are strongly influenced by preservation bias against organic materials. Riverine resources (primarily Unionidae mussel shells) were common, and palaeobotanical remains also indicate a broad mosaic riparian/woodland/grassland environment. People occupying these sites utilized this ecologically rich zone on their short, temporary stays at each site. While there needs to be more data before we can make solid interpretations about the seasonality of these occupations, the data we have is suggestive of a late summer to fall stay. While it is difficult to make any solid estimates of group size, the small number of materials associated with the identified features indicates these were likely very small groups that did not stay long. Patterns of group mobility are primarily indicated by the frequency of non-local lithic materials. These show that the frequency of Edwards chert from central Texas notably decreases over time. This suggests that group mobility and/or far-reaching socio-economic networks decreased through time. There are substantial avenues for future research. Notably, if exploration outside of the current ROW is possible, that data would give a more comprehensive view of the sites. Other avenues could include additional specialized analyses on the data already collected to potentially include lipids and residue analyses, additional palaeobotanical studies, petrographic and neutron activation analysis on recovered ceramics, and palynological studies. In sum, sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 are considered eligible for designation as SAL properties and for listing in the NRHP. However, Acacia’s excavation efforts mitigated the project’s effects within the Hickory Creek Interceptor ROW. Any future project that could impact the sites beyond the current ROW may warrant further consideration to assess the possibilities for additional contributing Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 ii

1. I NTRODUCTION In 2021 and 2022, Acacia Heritage Consulting (Acacia) conducted testing and data recovery investigations at two sites, 41DN580 and 41DN624, in Denton County, Texas under Antiquities Permit No. 30127 (Figure 1.1). Both sites are precontact Indigenous occupation sites located along Hickory Creek within the easement for the 2.46-mile (mi)-long (13,009 linear foot [ft]) Hickory Creek Interceptor line, which extends from west of Interstate Highway (IH) 35 West to an outfall located east of U.S. Route (US) 377. The sewer line is built in an approximately 60-ft-wide utility easement, with installation occurring through open cut trenching and directional boring. The project is sponsored by the City of Denton, and therefore the Antiquities Code of Texas (ACT) applies. The ACT requires consultation with the Texas Historical Commission (THC) to identify the effects of a project to cultural resources within the project footprint. Acacia previously conducted an archeological survey of the project area, or Area of Potential Effects (APE), under Antiquities Permit No. 9641 in October 2020. This effort identified that the previously recorded site 41DN580 extended into the interceptor easement. Acacia also identified a new site, 41DN624, on the south side of Hickory Creek near US 377. At that time, both sites were recommended for avoidance or additional testing to determine eligibility for listing as State Antiquities Landmark (SAL) and National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) properties. Therefore, under Antiquities Permit No. 30127, eligibility testing at 41DN580 and 41DN624 occurred in May and June of 2021. These efforts identified six new intact features at 41DN580 and two features at 41DN624. Beyond the identified features, both sites were judged to have good contextual integrity, datable organic materials, and artifact assemblages that could yield significant data about Prehistoric lifeways in north-central Texas. Based on these data, THC recommended that both sites are eligible for SAL and NRHP listing and therefore avoidance or mitigation efforts were required. Antiquities Permit No. 30127 was amended in October 2021 to include data recovery of site 41DN580 and the southern half of site 41DN624. Acacia completed data recovery for site 41DN624 in November 2021 and at 41DN580 in January 2022. From both testing and data recovery efforts at site 41DN580, Acacia archeologists excavated a combined total of 32.38 cubic meters (m3) of sediment across 83, 1 x 1 meter (m) test units, identifying a total of 19 features. Similarly, at 41DN624 Acacia excavated 13 features through a total of 25.32 m3 in 66, 1 x 1 m test units, as well as 11, 50 x 50-centimeter (cm) control units. Geoarchaeological analyses and chronometric modelling were conducted by SWCA, Inc. in support of the archeological effort. Led by Ken Lawrence, geoarchaeologists profiled trench exposures, collected sediment column samples from multiple locations at each site, and collected samples for optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) and humate dating. Additional laboratory analyses included artifact analysis by material specialists, flotation, micro-artifact identification, as well as radiocarbon analyses conducted by Beta Analytic (Beta). A complete presentation of raw data is included in the Appendices attached to this report. This report is submitted in accordance with permitting and reporting standards of the THC and Council of Texas Archeologists (CTA). All artifacts collected during these efforts will be curated along with project records at the Center for Archaeological Studies (CAS) in San Marcos. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 1

Rachel Feit served as Principal Investigator, and Victoria Ingalls and Heath Anderson served as Project Archeologists and field leads. Field technicians involved in the project are Chesney Kuper, Manda Adam, Danielle Blut, Kristin Corl, Luc D’Rovencourt, Spencer Gage, Jose Garcia, Jennifer Herrera, Alesia Hoyle, Savanah Neil, Allison Ramirez, Steven Schooler, and Emory Worrell. Ingalls and Feit prepared and edited this report, with substantial contributions by individual materials experts presented in the following chapters of this report. Chapters 2 and 3 outline background environmental, geologic, and cultural data. Chapter 4 outlines Acacia’s methods, Chapter 5 presents results and feature descriptions from site 41DN580. Similarly, we cover results and features from 41DN624 in Chapter 6. Chapter 7 presents Ken Lawrence and Ashley Eyeington’s geoarcheological analyses and chronometric modelling. In Chapter 8, Sergio Ayala and Katharine Pontillo detail their analyses of the lithic assemblage from both sites. The late Timothy Perttula analyzed the Late Prehistoric ceramic assemblage from site 41DN580, and his results and interpretations are presented in Chapter 9. James Ramsey, Jodi Jacobson, and Stefanie Haliburton describe the vertebrate faunal assemblage in Chapter 10. Chapter 11 presents Lori Phillips’ analysis of the invertebrate assemblage, as well as our discussion of the modified shell tools. Leslie Bush presents her paleobotanical analysis of flotation and carbonized material in Chapter 12, and Linda Scott Cummings presents her analyses of pollen, phytolith, and starch in Chapter 13. Ingalls and Feit outline Acacia’s experimental studies and their results in Chapter 14. Finally, Chapters 15 and 16 synthesize interpretations and make recommendations for each site. Previous Investigations Site 41DN580 is a deeply buried precontact site located on the south side of a bend in Hickory Creek. In 2014, Blanton and Associates (Blanton) excavated more than 20 backhoe trenches at this location in support of the then-proposed drainage basin for the Bonnie Brae Road expansion project. Four trenches contained cultural materials, including two identified features (Figure 1.2). Between 80 and 165 cm (2.6-5.4 ft) below the surface (bs), Blanton documented two fire-cracked rock (FCR) features, faunal bone, mussel shell, scattered FCR, and a chert flake (Young 2014). Blanton’s Feature 2 is worth special note. It was over 4 m in length and at least 1 m wide at an elevation of 116-137 cmbs and was made up of FCR (some very large) and scattered mussel shell across a single surface. Although it was mechanically excavated through, archeologists noted no carbonized materials or soil discoloration and suggested it may be a rake out pile from another nearby feature. While that may certainly be the case, this substantial feature represents behavior not seen in Acacia’s later work. Blanton’s four positive trenches are located just outside of the Hickory Creek Interceptor’s APE to the east, while trenches within and west of the current Interceptor easement were negative for cultural materials. The site was recommended for avoidance or further NRHP eligibility testing at that time (Young 2014). Project planners chose avoidance and constructed the drainage basin away from the delineated site limits. The drainage basin was excavated and constructed in 2017, and the new Bonnie Brae Road and bridge were constructed between 2017 and 2019. In 2020, Acacia conducted a survey of the Hickory Creek Interceptor line which was planned outside the western edge of the original 41DN580 site boundary. During this survey, investigators excavated three trenches near the site (Feit 2020). Two trenches contained FCR feature remnants, Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 2


---

## Page 27

labeled Features 1 and 2, both of which were concentrations of sandstone FCR observed in association with scattered mussel shell (Feit 2020). Cultural deposits were recorded between 150 and 190 cmbs, and characteristics were comparable with Blanton’s original findings. Additionally, Acacia documented scattered FCR and a Late Archaic Kent-like dart point eroding from the drainage basin banks. These eroding materials were clustered to suggest that they are the remains of features and were at roughly the same level below the original surface as the features seen in trenches. No cultural materials were observed below these features, including on the drainage basin floor, which was about 2.5-3 m below the original ground surface (Feit 2020). Acacia’s 2020 report extended site boundaries to the north and west and recommended that the site be avoided, or further NRHP and SAL eligibility testing should be undertaken. Acacia’s 2020 effort also documented site 41DN624 within two hayfields on either side of US 377 and the BNSF Railroad. Investigators delineated the site boundaries through four positive trenches (Figure 1.3). Cultural materials were documented between 90 and 190 cmbs, with materials concentrated between 110 and 150 cm in depth. The site area was delineated to cover roughly 220 m paralleling the south bank of Hickory Creek. Site characteristics were very similar to 41DN580 and include FCR features and mussel shell (Feit 2020). Therefore, avoidance or further testing at site 41DN624 were recommended. Summary of Current Investigations The overarching goal of this project was to document and excavate SAL and NRHP-eligible sites 41DN580 and 41DN624, mitigating the effects of the Hickory Creek interceptor project impacts. Both sites are characterized as deeply buried Precontact period Indigenous campsites. Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 fall on the south side of the main branch of Hickory Creek, less than five miles from Denton’s city center. The area is rapidly transitioning from large, rural agricultural tracts to suburban land uses of new single-family housing developments and associated infrastructure. Across both sites during testing and data recovery, Acacia archeologists excavated a total of 57.7 m3 of soil and documented 32 features. Most documented features date to the Archaic period, although archeologists also recorded a Late Prehistoric component at site 41DN580. During testing and data recovery excavations, Acacia’s team documented a total of 31 Archaic period features at sites 41DN580 and 41DN624, and one Late Prehistoric period feature/component at site 41DN580. Most of the features are small clusters of burned rock, and all include at least some FCR, which was collected by ancestral people from gravels in the bed of the nearby creek. Feature Descriptions and Categories Acacia preliminary grouped the features into three rough categories based on size and shape that may relate to function and/or longevity of use. These categories are: Category 1) non-patterned scatters of FCR (n=14); Category 2) tight clusters of FCR without a distinct basin shape (n=10); and Category 3) earth ovens with a central, basin-shaped depression (n=5). A full discussion of feature types and experimental studies are presented in Chapter 13. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 3

## Page 28

Category 1 is the most numerous feature type encountered across all excavated areas. These features are defined as small scatters of FCR with very little associated cultural material. The majority of FCR pieces are smaller than 10 cm and include an extremely small assemblage of mussel shell. Very little, if any, charcoal or organic materials were found associated with Category 1 features, which also lack soil discoloration. Category 2 features are well-defined, typically circular clusters of FCR that lack a formal basin- shape. Relatively little charcoal or other organic materials were found associated with Category 2 features, which also rarely exhibited any stained or discolored soil. At both sites, lithic flakes and points were recovered near these features, as were some freshwater mussel shell. Our initial interpretation was that Category 1 and 2 features are the remnants of simple, one- time use hearths that did not produce a large thermal signature on the soil as we see in the more formally constructed earth ovens from Category 3. While the lack of associated material does pose certain problems in interpretation, the number of these features across the sites points to repeated, short-term occupation of these locations. Acacia’s experimental studies (Chapter 13) present preliminary data that further suggest some of the Category 1 features may be related to stone boiling and other cook stone activities. Finally, Category 3 features are earth ovens with a central basin or depression. Two features at 41DN580 and three at 41DN624 are identified as earth ovens. These features are constructed fit for purpose and exhibit much more carbonized organic material and soil staining/discoloration than smaller types of features. Additionally, when compared with smaller features, the associated materials are both more diverse and found in higher quantities. These broad patterns suggest an intensity or longevity of use beyond that seen in association with the smaller features. Three Archaic features and the Late Prehistoric site component (originally designated a feature) do not fit into the categories described above. These are 41DN624 Features 9 and 10, as well as 41DN580 Feature 18. Each of these does contain some FCR, although their other aspects and patterning preclude them from direct comparisons with the rest of the sites’ features. Each of these is described in detail below. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 4

2. S S E ITE ETTING AND NVIRONMENT Vegetation and Topography The site areas extend along the main branch of Hickory Creek less than five miles south of the Denton city center. The surrounding area is very rapidly transitioning from rural to suburban, with multiple adjacent small-lot housing developments under construction during this archeological effort. The project setting is within the Grand Prairie region of the larger Cross Timbers environment. The Cross Timbers was named for the historically dense forests that formed a barrier to the open plains and prairies to the east and west. More specifically, Grand Prairie was characterized by undulating plains underlain with limestone beds (Griffith et al. 2007). Natural vegetation in this ecoregion is dominated by grassland species including little bluestem (Schizachyrium scoparium), big bluestem (Andropogon gerardii), Indian grass (Sorghastrum nutans), tall dropseed (Sporobolus asper), eastern gamagrass (Tripsacum dactyloides), and switch grass (Panicum virgatum). In addition, mesquite (Prosopis glandulosa), pecan (Carya illinoinensis), hackberry (Celtis laevigata), juniper (Juniperus ashei), bois d'arc (Maclura pomifera), and post and live oak (Quercus stellata and virginiana) are often observed in the woodlands along streams. However, little is left of this native environment, as the current landscape is a mix of urban and agricultural land with limited riparian woodlands. Native fauna include white-tailed deer, opossum, eastern cottontail rabbit, raccoon, striped skunk, nine-banded armadillo, and various rodents such as rats and squirrels. Common bird species include scissor-tail flycatcher, northern bobwhite, eastern meadowlark, mourning dove, killdeer, field sparrow, red-tailed hawk, turkey vulture, belted kingfisher, and mockingbird. Reptile and amphibian species common to this biotic zone include six-lined racerunner, rat snake, eastern hognose snake, Gulf Coast toad, Texas spiny lizard, rough green snake, copperhead, western diamondback rattlesnake, green treefrog, Blanchard’s cricket frog, diamondback water snake, Houston toad, and green anole. There are 44 known species of fish and 15 species of mussels that inhabit the waterways of north-central Texas (Todd 2014). Although herds of bison, red wolf and antelope were once common, these species were decimated through programmatic hunting and predator control programs of the nineteenth century (Griffith et al. 2007). Soils and Geology Ken Lawrence and Ashley Eyeington, SWCA Although the topography of the Denton area consists of rolling hills, the project areas along Hickory Creek are on the relatively flat floodplain. The elevation at both sites is approximately 570- 575 ft above mean sea level (amsl) (Figure 2.1). Both sites are on the west, depositional side of the creek while rolling hills slope up and away to the east. Soils Both 41DN580 and 41DN624 are mapped as the frequently flooded Frio silty clay (Natural Resources Conservation Service [NRCS] 2021). These deposits are characterized as very deep, slowly Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 8

permeable soils that formed in calcareous loamy and clayey alluvium that occupy floodplains and river valleys (NRCS 2021). Typical horizons for this series include an A1 horizon (0 to 20 cm), dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) silty clay when dry, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist, moderate fine and medium granular structure, hard and firm consistency, moderately sticky, moderately plastic, roots, few shell fragments, moderately alkaline with a clear smooth lower contact boundary. Below this is an A2 horizon, which typically is described as a dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) clay loam when dry, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) when moist, with a moderate and coarse subangular blocky structure giving way to moderate fine subangular blocky structure, few roots inclusions, few shells fragments, moderately alkaline, with a clear smooth boundary. Underlying the A2 horizon is a Bk1 horizon with characteristics including a dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) silty clay loam when dry, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) when moist, with a moderate fine and medium prismatic structure towards moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure, with a hard and firm consistency, few roots, films and threads of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), few shell fragment inclusions, moderately alkaline, with a gradual and smooth lower boundary. The fourth zone of a typical solum is a Bk2 horizon described as a dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) silty clay loam when dry, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) when moist, with a moderate fine and medium prismatic structure towards moderate medium and coarse subangular blocky structure, with a hard and firm consistency, few roots, films and threads of CaCO3 present, moderately alkaline, with a gradual smooth lower contact boundary. The underlying zone is a Bk3 horizon consisting of a grayish brown (10YR 5/2) silty clay when dry, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) when moist, with a moderate medium and coarse prismatic structure parting to a weak coarse blocky structure, with a hard and firm consistency, few roots, with many fine films and a few soft masses of CaCO3 (NRCS 2021). Geology The floodplain of Hickory Creek underlying 41DN580 and 41DN624 is mapped as Holocene- age Quaternary (Qal) deposits composed of alluvium (U.S. Geological Survey [USGS] 2021). The alluvium is generally described as containing sand, silt, clay and gravel. The surrounding uplands are mapped as Cretaceous age Grayson marl and Main Street Limestone, undivided (USGS 2021). The Grayson marl is characterized as a fossiliferous formation of light greenish-gray to medium gray marl the interbeds with the Main Street limestone. The Main Street limestone is described as yellowish gray to white limestone (USGS 2021). No outcrops of the unit were observed in the project area. Hydrology Hickory Creek is within the Upper Trinity River basin and is a tributary of the Elm Fork of the Trinity River. It joins the Elm Fork approximately 13.5 mi (21.7 kilometers [km]) downstream from 41DN624 and eventually the Trinity River. Hickory Creek at 41DN580 and 41DN624, is located in south-central Denton County, approximately 3.25 mi (5.2 km) southwest of Denton, Texas (see Figure 17.1). The Hickory Creek valley at this location is approximately 1 mi (1.6 km) wide and appears to have an unpaired terrace system floodplain near the two sites (Waters 1992:150–151). Specifically, the right bank (west side) of Hickory Creek has at least one alluvial landform (T0) composing the floodplain while the left bank (east side) quickly rises to the surrounding upland of the valley margin. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 9

## Page 34

At 41DN624, the T0 landform is generally 0.4 mi (640 m) wide at roughly 565–570 ft amsl. At 41DN580, the T0 landform is generally 0.35 mi (560 m) wide at roughly 570–575 ft amsl. Notably, the T0 landform around both sites is dissected in several locations across the floodplain by tributary channels. The tread of the T0 landform is positioned about 8–10 ft (2.5–3 m) above the channel base and quickly rises to the nearby valley margins on the left bank (east side) and gradually rises to the valley margins on the right bank (west side) containing 41DN580 and 41DN624. Hickory Creek at this crossing has a high Sinuosity Ratio (SR) of 1.3, indicating that it is a sinuous channel (Charlton 2008). This elevated SR value indicates that lateral erosion (exterior bends) and extensive sediment deposition (interior bends) are occurring within the channel, particularly at exterior and interior meander bends. Notably, site 41DN580 on the right bank (west side) is positioned on an interior meander bend, whereas 41DN624 is located on a relatively straight section of the drainage. Put simply, both 41DN580 and 41DN624 are in locations that appear to be actively expanding through continual flood deposition. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 10

3. C B ULTURAL ACKGROUND Denton County is within the north-central Texas Archeological region (Perttula 2004). Research driven archeological investigations in this portion of Texas have not been as extensive as in adjacent regions such as Central Texas, Northeast Texas, and Deep East Texas (Perttula 2004:7). The bulk of prior archeological research in the region has been conducted for large-scale reservoir projects including Lake Lavon (Dawson and Sullivan 1973; Lynott 1975; Stephenson 1950), Lake Ray Hubbard (Harris and Suhm 1963; Lorrain and Hoffrichter 1968), Ray Roberts Reservoir (Ferring 1987; Ferring and Yates 1997; Prikryl and Yates 1987; Skinner et al. 1982), Lewisville Lake (Brown and Lebo 1991; Ferring and Yates 1998; Stephenson 1950), Grapevine Lake (Ferring 1975; Morgan 1975), and Mountain Creek Lake (Peter and McGregor 1988). However, as this region continues to see a huge increase in population, the resulting archeological projects are bringing substantial new data to our understanding of past cultural groups and their lifeways. More recent site-specific investigations in the north-central Texas region have refined understanding of how humans interacted with the environment of north-central Texas in the millennia leading up to European contact (see Fields et al. 2000; Nickels 2014; Tinsley et al. 2011). This work is gradually bringing the precontact period into sharper focus, with an emphasis on understanding the ways in which precontact period people interacted with their environments in their daily cultural practice. Precontact chronology of the north-central Texas archeological region, like most of Texas, follows a tripartite model, encompassing three primary time periods: the Paleoindian, Archaic, and Late Prehistoric Periods. Paleoindian The earliest known human occupation in north-central Texas dates to the Paleoindian period (12,000 years Before Present [BP] to ca. 8500 BP). In north-central Texas, few sites of this age have in situ materials and stratigraphic integrity; most evidence derives from surface or mixed contexts. To date, the Lewisville and Aubrey sites at Lewisville Lake in Denton County have the only intact Paleoindian components (both associated with Clovis Complex occupations) in north-central Texas and these were excavated more than 40 years ago (Crook and Harris 1957, 1958; Ferring 1989, 2001). At the Aubrey site (41DN479) Clovis points and lithic debitage that dated to 11,500 BP were discovered under eight meters of Holocene alluvium on the Elm Fork of the Trinity River (Ferring 1989, 2001). Research at the Aubrey, Lewisville, and Paleoindian sites elsewhere have contributed to an overall impression that lifeways were characterized by high mobility, exploitation of a wide range of plant and animal resources, highly efficient use and curation of lithic materials (some which was procured long-distances from campsite locations), and possibly high task differentiation within sites (Bever and Meltzer 2007; Ferring 2001). Archaic In north-central Texas the Archaic spans the period from 8500–1250 BP and is broadly divided into the Early, Middle, and Late Archaic sub-periods (Prikryl 1990). Researchers believe the Archaic Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 13


---

## Page 38

period was precipitated by a climate shift to generally warmer, drier conditions, which began at the end of the Pleistocene and persisted for several millennia. By about 6000 BP, the Cross Timbers mosaic was formed in north-central Texas (Prikryl 1990). This climate shift hastened the extinction of most Pleistocene megafauna with the exception of bison (Haynes 1993), and archeologists believe that this also affected human subsistence patterns and culture expressions. Projectile point styles transitioned from unstemmed spear points to stemmed varieties such as the Martindale and Uvalde types (Black 1989). Most researchers posit that these stylistic changes correspond to changing adaptive strategies that focused subsistence on smaller game. The archeological record also demonstrates a heavier reliance on plant food processing, a wider variety of site functions, and more localized lithic resource procurement. This is reflected in an increase in the number of projectile point styles that proliferated during the Archaic, suggesting increasingly restricted mobile territories and a development of more localized production (Collins 1995). The archeological record, as it stands currently, reflects a paucity of Early Archaic sites in north-central Texas. No sites with intact Early Archaic components in this region have been documented with any detail and only two Middle Archaic sites have been investigated, 41DN102 (Calvert Site) and 41DN20. The Middle Archaic component at 41DN20 has a small assemblage and is heavily mixed with an Early Archaic component, making it nearly impossible to separate materials and features into discrete components (Ferring and Yates 1998). At site 41DN102 (the Calvert Site), there are no direct radiometric dates; the Middle Archaic component was dated entirely on projectile point styles and relative stratigraphy. Thus, archeologists’ understanding of Middle Archaic lifeways of north-central Texas and its chronology is still tentative (Ferring and Yates 1997). This scarcity of data may result from some combination of poor preservation, geoarcheological conditions related to site formation, or simply a factor of low regional populations at the time. There is presently not enough data about Early and Middle Archaic sites in this region to understand how these forces worked in tandem. Mobility probably remained relatively high throughout much of the Early and Middle Archaic period, and this is reflected in lithic source material, much of which still comes from non-local cherts of the Edwards Plateau or High Plains (Todd 2014). However, other evidence suggests that, over time, Archaic period groups may have begun to move in smaller bands, returning to certain campsites repeatedly (Ferring and Yates 1997; Peter and McGregor 1988). Prikryl’s 1990 research into the archeological data from the lower Elm Fork of the Trinity River indicates that most Middle Archaic sites are situated on the first terrace above stream flood plains, suggesting that Middle Archaic peoples stuck closely to major drainages in their hunting rounds and migrations. Sites from the Late Archaic period, which began around 3500 BP (although there is some discrepancy, see Perttula 2004; Prikryl 1993:199; Story 1985, 1990; Todd 2014), are vastly more numerous than those of earlier periods, and it is still not clear whether this reflects increased population, differences in site location selection, site preservation processes, or some combination of both. This period corresponds to the formation of the West Fork Paleosol, which has been identified throughout the Trinity River drainage basin in north-central Texas. The Pilot Point alluvium and West Fork Paleosol formed along primary waterways during the late Holocene through initially rapid aggradation, with local vegetation and pedogenic processes becoming more prominent than depositional processes thereafter (Hall et al. 2011:548; Tinsley and Dayton 2011:104). Hall and Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 14


---

## Page 39

colleagues (2011:548) used stable carbon isotope, molluscan fauna, and geomorphological data to conclude that this horizon “formed in a wet meadow environment dominated by C4 tallgrass species.” Although the frequency of open campsites increases during this period, the size and scale of sites tend to be smaller. Diagnostic dart points of the Late Archaic period include Dallas, Edgewood, Elam, Ellis, Ensor, Gary, Kent, Godley, Marcos, Trinity, and Yarborough types (Prikryl 1990:54). Smaller game continued to be exploited along with plants, the latter of which are indicated by an increase in lithic tool types associated with plant processing activities (Brownlow et al. 1999). Stone tools in the latter part of the Late Archaic are more commonly made from local quartzite and chert gravels which suggests decreased mobility (Lintz et al. 2008; Tinsley and Dayton 2011; Todd 2014). Late Archaic sites also contain a wide variety of features that include burned rock heaths, ovens, rock scatters, lithic reduction features, rockless pits filled with ash and charcoal, burned clay features, and dense scatters of faunal remains (Lintz et al. 2008; Nickels 2014; Tinsley and Dayton 2011). Baked clay, some with stick impressions, is a common feature at many of the sites recently surveyed and tested in north-central Texas (41TR170, 41DL203, 41DL436, and 41COL309), and researchers still do not know whether these remains reflect thermal elements used for cooking, intentionally thatched surfaces for dwellings, or something else (Bentley and Feit 2018; Lintz et al. 2008; Nickels 2014; Tinsley and Dayton 2011). Sites from this region are frequently characterized by abundant faunal remains and/or mussel shell, coupled with a dearth of lithic tools and tool debris. Although there is little evidence of sedentism and horticulture for Late Archaic peoples-- such as that which began to emerge in East and West Texas regions during this period-- these groups clearly used the area for camping, hunting and gathering, and likely adapted their environments to suit their needs (Tinsley and Dayton 2011). Late Prehistoric The transition from the Late Archaic to the Late Prehistoric is evidenced by significant changes in technology and subsistence in the material record. The commonly held date for the beginning of this interval is 1200 BP, although there exists some degree of overlap between diagnostic tools and features that are considered Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric. Nonetheless, researchers see a distinct alteration in the material record over time, which can be mapped onto corresponding changes in lifeways. A hallmark of the transition from the Archaic to the Late Prehistoric is the introduction of the bow and arrow, which enabled Indigenous hunters to pursue animals from greater distance. In north-central Texas arrow points such as the Alba, Catahoula, Steiner, and Scallorn are commonly seen at many Late Prehistoric sites (Prikryl 1990:58). Another climatic shift to dryer conditions occurred around 800 BP (AD 1150), which seems to have created more abundant grasslands which bison herds fed on, and which may account for the increase in bison remains represented on some sites of the Late Prehistoric II period. Technological expressions that enter the corresponding archeological record for this time include the diagnostic Perdiz point, alternately beveled bifaces, and specialized processing kits which are thought to be an adaptation to flourishing bison populations (Ricklis 1992). Increased reliance on bison hunting during the latter part of the Late Prehistoric period has been observed at some but not all Late Prehistoric sites excavated in north-central Texas (Nickels 2014; Tinsley and Dayton 2011). Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 15

## Page 40

There is also some evidence of early horticulture as Woodland Period sites of East Texas grew and influenced adjacent territories (Perttula 2004). Investigators at Site 41DL436 on Fish Creek Slough noted evidence of early horticulture and potentially intentional burning during the second phase of the Late Prehistoric period (Nickels 2014). Excavations at the Cobb-Pool site (41DL148) revealed possible house structures, roasting pits, Alba points, burned corn, and grog-tempered ceramics, suggesting significant adaptive transitions during the Late Prehistoric period (Peter and McGregor 1988). Evidence from the Late Prehistoric Harrell site in the western portion of north-central Texas reveals extensive trade networks and influences between the Plains Villages of the High Plains and settled Caddo peoples of east Texas. However, the precise way in which those networks materialized in north-central Texas is still poorly understood. While some researchers posit cultural influences coming in from southern Plains groups to the north and west (Prikryl 1990), others see influences from Woodland and Caddo peoples to the east through both tools and ceramics (McGregor and Bruseth 1987). These conflicting interpretations coupled with data recovered from excavated cemeteries has led some to posit that the transition between Late Prehistoric I and Late Prehistoric II was “a time of upheaval and extreme violence” (Texas Beyond History 2002). Evidence from dozens of cemeteries throughout Texas and Oklahoma from AD 1000-1300 show signs of violent death, mutilation, and mass burials. All of this implies that densifying population, coupled with lower mobility and greater territoriality, interaction, and exchange occurred in the Late Prehistoric II period, but the precise ways that these forces affected the people and adaptive strategies in north-central Texas has yet to be fully explored. Historic Period Documentary sources indicate the Tonkawa, Apache, Comanche, Wichita, Kitsai, Yojaune, Caddo, Delaware, and Kickapoo occupied the north-central region at various times between AD 1500 and 1700 (Campbell 1983; Newcomb 1961). Prior to about AD 1725–1750, Apachean groups appear to have dominated the High Plains of Texas and Oklahoma, west of the Denton area. After that time, the area was increasingly controlled by the Comanche and Kiowa. Within the area encompassing Denton County, the Wichita tribes became dominant during the eighteenth century (Bell et al. 1967). The Wichita are believed to have been Caddoan language speakers who migrated south and westward from the Arkansas River Valley to settle around the Red River valley in the Southern High Plains sometime around the sixteenth century (Newcomb 1961). Subgroups of the Wichita include Yojuane, Kichai, Tawakoni, Taovaya, Iscani (Waco), all of which eventually amalgamated to form the Historic period Wichita Tribe. The Wichita were described by European observers as living in semi-fortified villages of grass huts, surrounded by fields where they grew maize, pumpkins, melons, beans, and squash. They are believed to have acquired horses from the New Mexico pueblos sometime around the early seventeenth century and this helped them refocus their subsistence and economy around bison, which became an important staple and trade item (Newcomb 1961). Europeans entered Texas starting around AD 1528 but did not settle there until around AD 1700 when the French built fur trading outposts among the native groups who occupied the Southern High Plains (Webb 1952). In the middle of the seventeenth century, the French helped negotiate an alliance between the Comanche and Wichita, who then built a trading post along the Red River known Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 16


---

## Page 41

in Texas as Spanish Fort, in Montague County. The Wichita continued to move southward during the eighteenth century, building settlements and trading posts along the Brazos and Trinity Rivers (Newcomb 1961). However, to date there is no evidence that any of these large Indigenous villages were in Denton County in the period between 1600 to 1800. Likewise, material evidence of early Spanish and French explorers moving through or settling in Denton County is missing (Odom 2010). It was not until Anglo settlers from the United States came in the 1840s that Denton County had any significant non-Indigenous presence. The Cross Timbers region was attractive to early Anglo settlers because of its abundant wildlife, timber, and water. Settlers from the Peters Colony began to inhabit this region in 1841 (Odom 2010). Denton County was carved out of Fannin County in 1846, and named after John B. Denton, a lawyer and military captain from Tennessee, who was killed in the battle of Village Creek in 1841 (Hoole 2010). In 1848, Frenchman Étienne Cabet started a “utopian” socialist community, the Icarian Colony, in the southwestern portion of the county; the community failed in less than a year and the site was abandoned (Davidson 2010). The town of Denton was first settled in 1857. However, it was not established with an official charter until after the Civil War in 1866. In 1881, the Texas and Pacific Railway from Sherman to Fort Worth, and the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway from Denton to Dallas were completed, providing Denton railway access. Denton soon grew as an agricultural trade center with flour mills, cottonseed oil mills, and small cottage industries, like blacksmith and pottery shops. Texas Normal College (now University of North Texas) opened in 1890, followed in 1903 by Girls’ Industrial College (Texas Woman’s University). These two universities contributed to the economic growth and cultural expansion of Denton in the early twentieth century (Odom 2010). Denton Field, located 2.5 mi northeast of town, served as a training center for civilian pilots until World War II, when the focus was changed to training military pilots (Minor 1994). In the 1940s, a need for increased water storage capacity and additional flood control led the United States Congress to pass the River and Harbors Act of 1945, calling for additional construction in the Trinity River basin in Denton County. In 1948, the Corps of Engineers began development of Lewisville Lake near Denton, which would not only include Lake Dallas, but also impound Hickory Creek to the west, and Stewart, Panther, Cottonwood, Doe Branch, and Little Elm creeks to the east. The establishment of Dallas-Fort Worth Airport and the construction of Interstate 35 in the 1950s lead to a rapid influx of people to the Denton area (Odom 2010). Denton continues to expand rapidly as part of the larger Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex. The lands surrounding both sites have historically been used for agricultural production. Other disturbances at site 41DN580 include a gas pipeline that runs east-west along the southern boundary of the site, installed between 2001 and 2005. Since 41DN580 was first recorded in 2014, a drainage basin has been excavated around the north and west sides of the previously delineated site area. Additionally, an existing sewer line runs east-west through the center of the site boundary. At the time of this testing and data recovery effort at site 41DN624, the surrounding property was until very recently under cultivation. The site also spans US 377 and the BNSF Railroad, which run from southwest to northeast across the site area. There are additional utility lines, including a gas pipeline that run parallel to these transportation facilities. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 17

4. M ETHODS Both testing and data recovery efforts involved mechanical trenching and scraping supplemented by hand excavated units. Backhoe trenches initially established the maximum depth and typical soil profile of each site and scraped the site areas down to the level of identified features at each site. During mechanical excavations, archeologists monitored and screened sediment, and excavations ceased in a specific local when features or cultural deposits were identified. Detailed methods used in each phase of the project are described below. Recovered artifacts and samples were sent to material specialists for detailed analyses; specific methods used by each of these experts are described in Chapters 7-12. Artifacts, excluding culled materials such as burned rock and soil, and project records will be curated at CAS in San Marcos. Testing Field Methods During testing, Acacia anticipated excavating up to five trenches placed arbitrarily across Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 within the project area to maximize data yield. During the initial machine excavations, new features and artifact concentrations were noted and flagged for more targeted hand- excavations. The trenches varied in size, depending on the depth of Holocene alluvium, features encountered, and presence of the water table. Trenches ranged in length from 7-19.5 m, and in width from 1.2-6 m. Trenches that were deeper than 1.5 m were widened and stepped to comply with Occupational Safety and Health Administration guidelines for trench safety. Survey data indicated that the top 60 cm (2 ft) of soil at both sites did not have intact archeological materials, and therefore, the upper 50-60 cm sediments were stripped from the excavation work area without screening. However, excavated soil below this level was closely inspected for evidence of cultural materials. Feature numbering at each site followed from Acacia’s 2020 survey work. Hence, at Site 41DN580, new features uncovered during testing began at Feature 3; while at Site 41DN624, new features uncovered during testing began at 2. Test units were placed within the trenches over features and in areas of dense artifacts. Acacia excavated eight 1 x 1 m units at 41DN580, and eight 1 x 1 m units and three 50 x 50 cm soundings at 41DN624 totaling approximately 5 m3 of hand excavated sediments at each site. All excavation units were dug in 10 cm levels, all soil from test units was screened through ¼-inch wire mesh. Shovel skimming was the primary excavation technique, with troweling and small tools used in instances where finer detail and provenience control was required (i.e., during feature excavations). All non-FCR artifacts were collected for analysis. Burned and FCR found in test units were counted and weighed in the field. Random samples of FCR from features were collected for analysis and curation. Investigators collected soil samples from within features as well as soil columns from contexts close to features to gather macrobotanical and other types of data aimed at paleoenvironmental reconstruction (Figure 4.1). Columns were placed off hand-excavated test units to supplement feature-focused samples and provide control samples. Soil columns were 25 x 25 cm in size and were excavated 5-cm levels. Laboratory Methods After fieldwork of each phase of the project was complete, all artifacts were brought to Acacia headquarters in Austin for processing. Non-FCR artifacts were first catalogued and washed in tap water with a soft brush to remove dirt particles. Once clean, these were left to dry before being bagged by provenience and artifact class. Each class of artifact was then sent to material specialists for in- depth analysis. The results of these analyses are presented in subsequent chapters of this report. Soil samples gathered in the field were likewise brought back to Acacia for processing through flotation in an attempt to obtain palaeobotanical remains and possible micro-artifacts (Figure 4.8). A standard two liters of matrix from each soil sample was floted to separate organic material (light fraction) from sediment and micro-artifacts (heavy fraction), if present. Acacia archeologists sorted and analyzed the heavy fraction using 5 and 8 diopter magnifying lenses. Naturally occurring gravels and inclusions were sorted from possible micro-artifacts, which were likewise sorted based on material type. Light fraction materials were preliminarily examined to identify possible carbonized and ancient organic remains. Samples with organic materials were sent to Leslie Bush for analysis (Chapter 12). Research Domains and Questions for Data Recovery Precontact period sites found in north-central Texas are typically characterized by deeply buried archeological deposits (often associated with the rapidly aggrading Pilot Point formation and West Fork Paleosol) with a paucity of stone tools and flaking debris, but comparatively higher frequencies of faunal materials that commonly include freshwater mussel and turtle shells. Ash filled pits and baked clay lenses or features have also been identified at a number of the recently investigated sites of north-central Texas (e.g., 41DL203, 41TR170, 41DL436, 41COL309), all of which are Late Archaic through Late Prehistoric in age (Bentley and Feit 2018; Lintz et al. 2008; Nickels 2015; Tinsley and Dayton 2011). Due to a paucity of locally abundant lithic sources, lithic tools and tool debris from sites in north-central Texas tend to be highly curated and made from river gravels that come from outside the immediate area (Abbott 2011). Unusually, the Middle Archaic component of the nearby Calvert Site (41DN102) was made up primarily of locally sourced lithic materials. There are few burned rock middens in north-central Texas (41DN612 is a notable exception), and none of the scale and density as those found in the adjacent Edwards Plateau and West Texas areas. Several theories have been advanced to explain this pattern. One reason for the lack of burned rock middens in the area may be because the plant foods (such as agave, sotol, and other cacti) utilized in areas where burned rock middens frequently occur were not common in north-central Texas. A second interpretation focuses on the link between burned rock middens and the processing of acorns, which some believe requires limestone to leach the acids from the acorns. By contrast, the bedrock found in the oak savannahs of north Texas is typically sandstone and is chemically inert (Prikryl 1990). In either case, the natural and cultural factors that allowed such middens to proliferate appear to be absent in the region. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 25

## Page 50

The emerging picture is that prevailing environmental conditions of north-central Texas in the Middle to Late Holocene were unique and so were the adaptive strategies among Native American peoples who lived in the region. But other factors almost certainly contributed to the unique suite of features, archeological remains, and site types found in north-central Texas. Recent investigations of precontact period sites in north-central Texas have begun to create a more detailed picture of local Indigenous land use, social behaviors, and environmental conditions of the Late Holocene (see Lintz et al. 2008; Nickels 2014; Nielsen et al. 2021; Tinsley and Dayton 2011; also, Ferring & Yates 1997, 1998). The majority of known sites in north-central Texas date to the Late Archaic through Late Prehistoric periods. However, very few sites with contextual integrity are known from earlier periods, and to date only two Middle Archaic period sites, 41DN102 (Calvert Site) and 41DN20, have been investigated. In the case of 41DN20, the Middle Archaic component was limited and heavily mixed with an Early Archaic component, making it difficult to separate materials and features reflecting several thousand years of site use (Ferring and Yates 1998). In the case of the Calvert Site (41DN102), dating of the Middle Archaic component was based entirely on projectile point styles and relative stratigraphy, not radiocarbon dates. Thus, archeologists’ understanding of Middle Archaic lifeways of north-central Texas and its chronology is still somewhat tentative (Ferring and Yates 1997). Based primarily on lithic, faunal, and feature evidence from a Middle Archaic component of the Calvert Site, Ferring and Yates (1997) posited that the Indigenous peoples of the north-central Texas Middle Archaic were highly mobile, with territories that crossed diverse physiographies. Faunal subsistence focused on hunting deer and small game such as rabbits and canids, and capturing fish, turtles, and other aquatic species. Compared to Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric components of the Calvert and other sites in the region, animal processing may have been less intensive, involving butchering and cooking large elements directly over a fire, as opposed to boiling and cracking for marrow extraction. However, these hypotheses about the Middle Archaic Indigenous lifeways of the Trinity River drainage basin were formulated with limited data from just one site. More than twenty years later, almost no new investigations of the Middle Archaic have occurred. Consequently, archeologists fundamentally know very little about even the basics of human culture and adaptation in the Trinity River Basin area before 3800 BP. For this reason alone, data recovery investigations at Site 41DN580 have enormous potential to fill in the tableau for the Middle Archaic period in north-central Texas. Data from Site 41DN580 and 41DN624 resonate to some degree with the general cultural outline posited by Ferring and Yates from their work at Sites 41DN102 and 41DN20. The multiple small thermal features associated with a limited lithic and faunal assemblage certainly suggest short term, but reoccurring occupations along Hickory Creek. And the preponderance of mussel shell at both sites, with very little lithic and faunal materials suggest that there may have been a focus on aquatic resources, as opposed to hunting large game. The few burned faunal specimens collected from features at Site 41DN580 were highly burned, which superficially tracks with Ferring and Yates data set. The primary goals of gathering more data from site 41DN580 is to develop a more robust baseline for the Middle Archaic and also to better dialogue with Ferring and Yates initial culture- behavior model for this period. Notably, the Middle Archaic artifact assemblages from 41DN580 and 41DN102 are compositionally distinct. The Middle Archaic component of the Calvert Site was Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 26

## Page 51

represented by a single hearth feature with faunal remains (over 20 identified taxa) and lithic production debitage. However, 41ND580 has numerous small hearths and exceedingly few lithics or faunal remains other than mussel shell. Along with other distinguishing characteristics, this suggests distinct site use patterns and could further indicate differences in local resource availability, site seasonality or length of use, different group sizes or cultural traditions, temporal differences, etc. During archeological testing, the questions Acacia sought to answer for Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 involved first assessing where precisely the sites fit into the chronological framework for north-central Texas, whether they have single or multiple components; and if the latter, are those components discernibly different in content and context. These basic questions are answerable for both sites, which have multiple components. From these basic questions, we formulated higher order theoretical frameworks aimed at understanding how Indigenous peoples of the region were using the landscape and its resources during the periods of occupation. We posited that if sites like 41DN580 and 41DN624 represent short- term seasonal camps of small groups on their way to someplace else, the archeological assemblage would allow us to estimate the limits of population territories. We also hypothesized that it may be possible to estimate the size of the groups that camped at these sites, based on the number and size of features and the size/extent of the artifact assemblages. Further, if these groups were highly mobile over large territories, what made these locations along Hickory Creek a place where people returned to again and again. And finally, we hoped to address if land use and resource focus changed over time from the Middle Archaic to later periods and, if so, what could explain those changes. The results of field investigations along with subsequent analyses were used to address these hypotheses. Results are presented in Chapters 5-14, while interpretations and a discussion of how our data address these hypotheses is presented in Chapter 15. 5. R F I 41DN580 ESULTS OF IELD NVESTIGATIONS AT Site 41DN580 is on the south side of a bend in Hickory Creek in a formerly level floodplain (Figure 5.1). Across the creek to the north, rolling hills overlook the floodplain. From both testing and data recovery efforts at 41DN580, Acacia archeologists excavated a combined total of 32.38 m3 of sediment across 83 test units, identifying a total of 19 features (Figures 5.2-5.5; Table 5.1). The majority of these are Archaic period clusters of FCR with small amounts of associated faunal material (primarily freshwater mussel shells). A full description of each feature is presented below, and the results of specialized analysis of each artifact category are presented in the following chapters. Recent infrastructure improvements have significantly altered the landscape surrounding the currently defined site boundaries. These include an existing sewer line that runs east-west through the field just south of the site area, and a gas line that runs from northwest to southeast west of the site. Additionally, in 2017-2018 the new Bonnie Brae Road and bridge were constructed roughly 100- m west of the site. As part of this work, a large water detention pond was excavated around the west and north sides of the then defined site area. In wet years like 2021, the detention pond holds water for months at a time and evidence of erosion around the edges of the pond was evident. Aquatic species and water birds (notably heron) were abundant during these periods. In dry years, as in 2022, it is possible to walk and drive large vehicles across the area and fewer faunal species were observed. During dry periods, too, one can see artifacts (mostly FCR) eroding from the sloping banks and across the bottom of the artificial detention pond. The presence of these artifacts suggests the site originally extended beyond its present boundaries and outside of the current APE. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 28

Testing During the initial site visit prior to Acacia’s testing effort, archeologists noted large quantities of FCR and other cultural materials eroding from the bank of the recently constructed detention pond. Acacia point-plotted observed surface artifacts using the Trimble and collected diagnostic materials (including lithic tools). In addition to FCR, these surface finds include the base of a Marshall-like dart point, a chert flake, a mano, and mussel shell. A Kent-like point was found in this same location of the site during Acacia’s previous survey work (Feit 2021b). It is clear that site 41DN580 originally extended beyond the current interceptor APE and into the newly constructed pond, whose depth extends below the level of recorded features. For the testing phase, investigators mechanically excavated three large trenches in the interceptor easement (A, B, and C) covering a total area of approximately 250 m2 (Figure 5.2). The three trenches exhibited similar soil profiles, except along the bank of the detention pond where the A-horizon had been scraped away (see Chapter 7). Acacia excavated units with a total volume of 6.68 m3 (Table 5.1). Through these testing efforts, archeologists identified and investigated eight features, two previously identified during Acacia’s survey and six new FCR features (Features 1-8). Only one of these, Feature 3, represents the remains of an earth oven. The remaining features were all small clusters of FCR that had little evidence of burning and relatively little associated material. A total of 30 soil samples were collected, as well as six carbon and four FCR samples. Seven of the soil samples and all FCR and carbon samples were taken from features. At the southern end of the site, Acacia opened Trench A (6 x 19.5 m) between the existing sewer line and gas pipeline. Mechanically excavated to 2.4 m below the surface, it hit the top of the water table and began filling quickly. Additionally, significant rains occurred over the course of testing efforts, flooding the trench with over a meter of water which it retained even after being pumped out. Units 5-7 were initially opened in Trench A, and these encountered Feature 5. However, due to the heavy rains and issues with water, Trench A was inundated above the elevation of the units for several days (Figure 5.6). Once accessible, Feature 5 was fully excavated. Data Recovery During data recovery, Acacia machine scraped an area of about 890 m2 of the interceptor easement in three large trench blocks (D, E, and F). Trenches D-F filled the areas between the sewer and gas lines and the previously excavated trenches. Machine excavations generally stopped between 1-1.5 m below the existing ground surface, at or just above the level of previously identified cultural deposits. Newly exposed features were identified and flagged for excavation. Although 11 new features were identified and documented, overall artifact recovery was low. Stone tool and tool debris, as well as faunal remains were primarily confined to one area of the site. While mussel shells were present throughout the site (typically associated with features), the preservation of these materials is poor. The same can be said for other organic remains. Overall, the machine scraping revealed fewer features than expected based on testing. To respond to these unanticipated field conditions, Acacia placed large blocks of contiguous 1 x 1 m units in areas where features were not visible in the hopes of identifying still buried features. In the end, Acacia exceeded the volumetric goal of 25 m3, excavating 73 total 1 x 1 m units for a total volume of 27.3 m3. Over the course of data recovery fieldwork, Acacia made minor adjustments to the originally proposed field methods and level of effort in response to the actual conditions encountered, and the THC was notified of these adjustments through email updates. At the southern end of the site area and just north of an existing gas pipeline, Trench D (24 x 16 m) was the largest trench opened at 41DN580 (Figure 5.5). Twenty-nine units were excavated in this trench (Units 11-39), uncovering five small features (Features 9-13). Unlike the features at the northern end of the site, the features in Trench D were all loose scatters of FCR without a clear pattern. The Trench D features cluster into two elevations, 172.9-173.0 m above mean sea level (amsl) (Features 9 and 10) and 172.6-172.7 m amsl (Features 11-13). Across all contexts in this trench, archeologists recovered and collected 134 grams (g) of shell, 14 lithics, and 153 pieces of FCR. Trench E, roughly 16 x 17 m, opened onto the detention pond bank between Trenches A and C (Figures 5.4, 5.7). Four features were recorded in and around this trench (Features 14-17) and a total of 31 units were excavated in and around the trench (Units 40-66, and 84-85). Although no dates are available for Features 15, 16, and 17, their elevations (approximately 1.5-2 m below the current surface) indicate they likely belong in the Middle Archaic. These appear similar to other features across the site, and comprise a loose scatter of FCR, a cluster of FCR, and an earth oven or rock-lined pit. The associated artifact assemblage is also similar, comprising 82 collected pieces of FCR, 74.7 g of mussel shell, 1 lithic, and a single piece of faunal bone. Figure 5.7. ## Page 63

a Kent-like point previously recorded during the survey (Figure 5.11; Feit 2021b). The Marshall point is made of Uvalde chert and the tip was broken by an impact fracture (Chapter 8). FCR comprising the feature is mostly tabular sandstone, but irregular and rounded limestone rocks are also present. All are highly burned and discolored pinkish red color, and many cracked in place. Many of the smaller rocks appear to be spalls from the larger rocks. It is possible that Features 4 and 6 are rake-out piles from this central thermal feature, but this interpretation remains tentative. Two radiocarbon assays from Feature 3 returned slightly different age ranges. Burned bone collected as Sample 15 (Beta No. 595861) returned dates at 3590 ± 30 BP, with calibrated dates at 3980- 3829 (93.9%) and 3788-3777 (1.5%) cal BP (calibrated at 2σ with IntCal20 [Ramsey 2009; Reimer et al. 2020]). Sample 19 (Beta No. 595860) was charcoal and returned dates at 4050 ± 30 BP, with calibrated ranges at 4616-4421 (92.5%) and 4786-4767 (2.9%) cal BP (Ramsey 2009; Reimer et al. 2020). This less than 500-year discrepancy could be caused by many factors, but in either case places the feature at the end of the Middle Archaic period. Additionally, paleobotanical analysis (Bush, Chapter 12) identified carbonized hardwood (species indeterminate) and chenopod seed fragments (Chenopodium sp., aka Goosefoot) from this feature. Chenopod seeds as well as the greens are edible, although they must be processed (typically cooked) prior to consumption to remove nitrates and other toxins (Texas Beyond History 2023). These are common and typically available from early spring through early fall. Like most features and excavation units, the majority of faunal remains near Feature 3 are fragmented freshwater mussel shell. The shells fragments are very friable and most do not appear to have any signs of human modification. A representative sample of shells is presented in Figure 5.12. ## Page 79

(Figure 5.27; Chapter 11). Therefore, Acacia placed a total of sixteen 1 x 1 m units – Units 40-51, 64-68, and 84-85 – within this upper component to explore its integrity and extent. These units were arranged in two large contiguous excavation blocks, the first encompassing units 42-49, and the second units 40, 41, 50, 51, and 64-68. This component appears to be a relatively discrete activity area. Acacia placed Units 84 and 85 approximately 10 m northeast of Units 64-68 to determine the limits of this component. We recovered almost no material from these units, with only one piece of mussel shell and one small faunal bone fragment recorded. Further, Acacia recorded no evidence of this component during mechanical excavations or profile examinations in Trenches D and F. At least within the Interceptor easement, this upper component appears to be relatively isolated around the north side of Trench E. This site component is a thin scatter of cultural material between 174.6 and 174.43 m amsl (Figure 5.28). Small bits of burned clay were scattered across this ancient surface along with a very minute flecks of carbon. The artifacts from this upper component make up the vast majority of all recovered material from the site. This component yielded 87% (168.8 g) of faunal bone, 69% of lithic material (n=102, including 5 points or tools) (Figure 5.29), and all of the ceramic material (Figure 5.30). The faunal remains (n=459) include unidentified large and medium mammal bones, notably American beaver and white-tailed deer, as well as turtle remains (see Chapter 10). Most of the turtle carapace fragments were significantly burned and were very small in size. Ramsey and Jacobson identified that all bones with clear evidence of butchering from the site were recovered from this site component (Chapter 10). Moreover, 93 bones showed carnivore modification. Although difficult to determine with certainty, it is possible this represents the presence of domesticated dogs. Only 40% of recovered mussel shell came from this provenience but given that only 16 of the 73 units at site 41DN580 targeted the upper component, it still constitutes a notable shell to volume ratio. Thirty-two of the shells and fragments exhibit modifications (see Figure 5.27; Chapter 11). Some have been used for scraping, others have been cut into angular pieces, and several exhibit evidence of battering and notching. There are lateral abrasions on the exterior of several of these specimens that suggest use as tools; cut specimens without use-wear may be adornment preforms. One small, polished bone fragment is possibly from a bone needle or awl (Figure 5.31). This artifact is a highly polished, tapered cylinder with a clean snap fracture on the narrow end, and a step fracture on the wide end. Along one surface is a cut or scraped section. This needle fragment was associated with large, modified shell fragments with heavy battering and polish. Together, it’s possible these artifacts indicate hide processing was taking place here. Also worth noting is that the mussel shell species represented in this component appears to be different from that represented in the Middle Archaic component. Although most specimens are not complete enough to identify to the species level, species in the upper component include threeridge, yellow sandshell, bank climber, bleufer, and Texas lilliput, while the predominant Archaic period species, notably from Feature 18 (see below), are Texas lilliput. This difference in species breadth in each assemblage could be a function of differential preservation. However, it could also signal a shift in resource focus over time, as it fits broader site patterning across the north-central Texas region (Todd 2014). This upper component is the only area of the site where ceramic sherds were present. Fifty- nine ceramic sherds were collected from this site component. These are relatively thick, heavily Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 55

This is consistent with Late Prehistoric and early Contact period ceramics from the north-central Texas region known as Nocona Plain ware, and possibly relate to the still poorly defined Henrietta Phase (see Chapter 9). Acacia collected a number of charcoal samples from the upper component; these were sent to Beta Analytic for processing. The results are presented in Table 5.26 (Ramsey 2009; Reimer et al. 2020). These radiocarbon dates place this component solidly within the Late Prehistoric period. Additionally, two macrobotanical samples included ash wood charcoal (Fraxinus sp.), black walnut nutshell (Juglans nigra), and walnut wood charcoal (Juglans sp.) (see Bush, Chapter 11). Figure 5.27. ## Page 84

carbon sample was collected from just below the feature’s FCR. A soil sample was also collected from this area. While difficult to see in resulting photographs, Feature 16 FCR were slightly canted inwards to an off-center depression. This is not as pronounced as other earth ovens uncovered by Acacia, nor was the FCR stacked as deep. Feature 16 appears more like a rock-lined pit or griddle than it does an earth oven. The dominance of large sandstone tablets lends additional credence to the interpretation of this feature as a griddle. Functionally, a rock-lined pit is in the same ‘family’ as an earth oven. Rocks are quite literally used to line a depression or pit and a fire is lit above. These features are designed to increase heat retention and reduce fuel usage. While typically interpreted as cooking features, these could also result from other behaviors (used for warmth, sweat baths, etc.). Griddles, on the other hand, would have been constructed around the center of the heating element, possibly over coals, and foodstuffs would have been placed directly on the hot rocks. ## Page 87

top of one another within an area of about 50-70 cm (Figures 5.36-5.38; Tables 5.33-5.34). Scattered, small to medium pieces of FCR ring the shell drop area, and while not in a clear cluster or pattern, are certainly associated with the same ancient surface. The feature was excavated in Unit 83, which was expanded to the east and south to capture the whole feature up to the trench wall. On the east edge of the feature, and immediately abutting the trench wall, archeologists observed a circle of discolored soil. This stain contains a darker, looser sediment which excavators believe may represent a small ash pile. It is possible that this could represent a posthole, although the shape (with a curved or dome-shaped profile) is not believed to fit this interpretation. Acacia collected a sample of this discolored soil for further analysis. Macrobotanical analysis of the light fraction from this sample revealed vervain seed and grasses, but not a great deal of other paleobotanical information. Nearly all of the mussel shell recovered from this feature are Toxolasma texasiense (Texas lilliput) (see Chapter 11; Figure 5.38). This possibly indicates both environmental conditions and foraging choice. In addition to the mussel shell, 5 faunal bone fragments were recovered from this feature. All are identified as medium or large mammal bones (Chapter 10). However, this feature could not be fully explored as it extended into the trench wall. Within the shell drop area southwest of the discolored soil, excavators uncovered an Edwards Plateau chert unifacial tool with wear along one edge (Figures 5.33, 5.39; Chapter 8). Ayala (Chapter 8) indicates this may have been a hafted scraper or adze, giving us tantalizing insights into specific tool use. This heavily utilized but relatively small tool could have been hafted and used to forage and collect mussel shells from the creek, and/or to open them once back in camp. Together, these data lead us to believe this feature is the result of a single episode, interpreted as discard pile of processed, cooked, and consumed mussels. ## Page 92

Figure 5.41. Kent dart point from Feature 19 (Photo by Ayala, Chapter 8). Summary In sum, Acacia’s efforts at 41DN580 resulted in the identification of 19 features through the excavation of 32.38 m3 across 85 units in six trenches (Table 5.37). These features represent two major components dating to the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. A total of 694 pieces of FCR, 299 g of mussel shell, 148 lithics, 388 faunal bone fragments, and 59 ceramic sherds were collected (Appendix B). Two of these features fit into Category 3, meaning they are formal cooking features, one a rock- lined roasting pit and the other a more typical earth oven. Seven features are identified as Category 2 clusters of FCR that, while clearly the remains of discrete events, do not have the formal characteristics of the cook features from Category 3. Archeologists identified six features within Category 1, and these represent loose, nonpatterned scatters of FCR. Additionally, there are two features whose primary expression was not through FCR and so they do not fit well within the categories defined by Acacia for analytical purposes. These are Feature 14, which was later identified as a separate Late Prehistoric site component, and Feature 18, which is a cluster of mussel shells.
