## Page 96

6. R F I 41DN624 ESULTS OF IELD NVESTIGATIONS AT Roughly a kilometer southeast of 41DN580, site 41DL624 is on the south/west floodplain of Hickory Creek (Figure 6.1). At 41DN624 Acacia excavated 13 features through a combined total of 25.32 m3 in 66, 1 x 1 m test units, as well as eight 50 x 50 cm control units (Figures 6.2-6.5; Table 6.1). The site area spans US 377 and the BNSF railroad, which bisects the site from northeast to southwest. This extremely level plane has been used for agricultural production for at least the past six decades, if not longer. However, while mowed, the field was not under active cultivation during excavation efforts. Known disturbances near the site include the railroad, built in the late 1800s, and US 377, which was commissioned in the 1930s. Multiple utility lines parallel these transportation routes. There is also a gas pipeline that runs just outside the site boundary to the west. All of these infrastructure developments are subject to ongoing maintenance and upkeep. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 72

While originally recorded as a single site, given the knowledge of hindsight, 41DN624 should probably be divided into two separate sites. Therefore, the following discussion breaks the site into two areas: 41DN624.1 representing the remains on the north side of US 377, and 41DN624.2 representing the remains on the south side of US 377 (see Figure 6.2). Acacia’s testing efforts opened Trenches A, B, and C at 41DN624.1 on the north side of US 377 while Trenches D, E, F, and G are on the south side at 41DN624.2. In total across both sites, testing efforts excavated eight 1 x 1 m test units along with three 50 x 50 cm control units. Acacia hand- excavated a total of 5.05 m3, with another 1.93 m3 of soil collected from column samples. Artifacts collected include a total of 15 lithics (mostly small chert flakes, no formal tools), 853 pieces of mussel shell, and 2 faunal bone fragments. At 41DN624.1, archeologists excavated Trenches A, B, and C and recorded two features (Features 1 and 2). Trench A (4.5 x 9.5 m) was shallow, mechanically scraped down to 1.35 m below the surface. Feature 1 was exposed at the bottom of Trench A but was repeatedly submerged during heavy rains. Due to the standing water for the duration of fieldwork, Feature 1 was cataloged, but not investigated. Briefly, this feature was characterized by an amorphous collection of 7-8 medium to large sized tabular FCR scattered across an area about a meter in diameter. The feature did not exhibit a discrete shape, nor was there any soil discoloration or associated materials. This was the only feature observed in Trench A. 41DN624.1 Trench B extended off the west side of Trench A and was mechanically excavated to a depth of about 3.3 m below the surface (Figure 6.6). Archeologists observed Feature 2 in Trench B at about 1.3 m below surface (171.592 amsl) and excavated it in Units 1 and 2. This feature is a scatter of tabular sandstone FCR on a single surface. An unusually high number of lithics (n=5) were recovered near this feature. Detailed descriptions of the features are presented below. Acacia excavated Trench C at the northern end of the site area. While archeologists did not observe any features or materials during mechanical excavations, Acacia excavated two units (Units 3 and 5) in the hopes of identifying additional features (Table 6.3). Figure 6.6. Action shot of 41DN624 Trench B during testing; camera facing southeast. The quantity of any interpretable cultural materials found during testing at 41DN624.1 was low. Fourteen pieces of lithic debitage and about 460 g of mussel shell were collected from across four test units. The amount of debitage is certainly interesting, especially given the lack of associated features and general scarcity of lithic materials across the site. However, these were found at varying elevations across multiple units, so while they likely support our hypothesis of repeated site occupations, their lack of associations with any other materials/features limits data potential. Therefore, at the end of testing efforts, Acacia recommended (and regulatory agencies concurred) that no additional work is warranted at 41DN624.1. South of US 377 at 41DN624.2, Acacia machine excavated four trenches, D, E, F, and G (Figures 6.2-6.5), hand excavated four 1 x 1 m units, and three 40 x 40 cm soundings. Based on survey data, investigators predicted that 41DN624.2 would have no intact features or deposits south of US 377. Thus, trenching in this area was designed to sample deposits to confirm this initial hypothesis. As luck would have it, our initial predictions were wrong and investigators found a rather large and intact feature, Feature 3, in Trench E. Trenches D and F were opened at the northern and southern ends of the previously defined site area. No features were observed in Trench D (2.5 x 7.7 m). Although some scattered FCR and mussel shell were noted, these did not form a discernable pattern, cluster, or feature. Trench F (2.5 x 6 m) contained no cultural materials, suggesting it is outside the southern site boundary. Therefore, no hand-excavated units were opened in either trench. Between Trenches D and F, Acacia excavated the L-shaped Trench E. Mechanical excavation encountered a substantial concentration of FCR at a soil change about 55-60 cm below the surface, designated Feature 3. It is a circular earth oven composed of thin tabular sandstone with a central depression. This feature was located at an elevation of 172.113 m amsl, or about 50-80 cm below Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 80

Data Recovery Based on the results of testing efforts in coordination with the THC, all data recovery efforts were undertaken at 41DN624.2 south of US 377. Mechanical scraping covered 1,050 m2 of the interceptor easement in two main blocks: Block A and Block B (BA and BB) (Figure 6.2-6.5, 6.7). Machine scraping generally stopped about 40-60 cm below the ground surface, however, four areas (Trenches H-K) were excavated deeper to provide better exposure of the sediment from the surface to channel deposits, as well as to assess whether older archeological components might be present at this portion of 41DN624.2. In addition to the three features identified during testing, data recovery efforts identified a further ten features, although overall quantities of artifacts are low. Notably, stone tools and tool debris were primarily confined to one area of the site. While faunal bone and freshwater mussel shells were present throughout the site and closely associated with features, the preservation of these materials is poor. ## Page 106

Over the course of fieldwork, Acacia made minor adjustments to the original field methods and level of effort in response to the actual conditions encountered, and the THC was notified of these changes. In terms of total excavated volume, Acacia exceeded the proposed level of effort, excavating more than 5 m3 beyond the targeted 15 m3 for a total volume of 20.2 m3. Going into the data recovery, Acacia believed that Feature 3 could be an isolated occurrence as survey and testing found little data to indicate that other features were present. Therefore, Acacia planned to excavate 5 m3 around Feature 3 plus 10 m3 across the rest of the site. Additionally, control units were proposed along a transect line through the site at 5-m intervals. However, as luck would have it, the machine scraping of the ROW revealed many more features than expected. These features were distributed throughout the two scraped blocks. To respond to these unanticipated field conditions, Acacia notified the THC with a request to modify the scope somewhat by diverting some of the excavation effort away from Feature 3 area to apply elsewhere at the site. In the end, Acacia exceeded the volumetric goal, excavating a total volume of 20.2 m3 across 58, 1 x 1 m units, and eight, 50 x 50 cm units (Figures 6.4-6.5). Acacia placed seven new units around Feature 3, as well as continued excavations on Units 6-9 started during testing for a total volume of 4.1 m3 in that area. Additionally, as excavation units covering feature areas were relatively evenly distributed across the scraped easement, transect control unit placement was modified from every 5 m to every 10 m. None of the control units contained any artifacts or features. Acacia identified and fully excavated 10 new features along with the previously recorded Feature 3. In cases where artifacts or burned rock distribution associated with features seemed to continue beyond the initial units placed, wherever feasible, unit excavations were expanded in that area in an effort to capture associated debris and activity areas around the feature surface. Block A, roughly 512 m2 in size, was mechanically scraped to remove the top 50-75 cm of soil. Trenches I and J were excavated within the larger scraped block. These efforts exposed the area around Feature 3 as well as the four newly identified Features 4-7. Archeologists excavated 29, 1 x 1 m units within this block (Units 6-28, 31-34, 43-44), with four, 50 x 50 cm control units, CU 5-8. Trench I (14 x 3.75 m) was roughly in the center of Block A. Acacia opened seven contiguous units (Units 21-24, 31-33) in Trench I around Feature 6, a concentration of tabular sandstone. This feature is likely an earth oven remnant or stone-lined pit, and radiocarbon dates place it within the Middle Archaic period. Associated materials are mussel shell fragments and two lithic flakes (specimens 132-01 and 137-01). Trench J (13 x 4 m) makes up the northern end of Block A. During mechanical excavations, no cultural materials or features were observed in this trench. As several features were seen within Blocks A and B directly north and south of this trench, no units were opened here and our efforts concentrated on known features. At the southern end of the site area, Trench H extended from Block A 10 m to the south. Two units (Units 29-30) were excavated over a small exposure of FCR. These identified Feature 8, stratigraphically the lowest and therefore earliest Middle Archaic feature identified. No other features were identified in Trench H, and only mussel shell and FCR were recovered from around Feature 8. North of Block A, Acacia scraped Block B – another large area equal in size at 512 m2. This large block covered the previously excavated Trenches 15 and D, excavated during survey and testing Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 82

## Page 109

Feature 3 Feature 3 at 41DN624 was the largest earth oven we encountered during excavations. It was a meter and a half across and had a distinct, central basin shape when bisected (Figures 6.10-6.13; Tables 6.5-6.8). The top of the feature is at an elevation of 172.113, or about 53 cm below ground surface, and the base of the feature is 171.893 (75 cmbs). A block of eleven contiguous excavation units, Units 6-16, were placed around this feature and fully revealed it. Feature 3 consists of a circular and basin-shaped cooking feature with an outer ring of rock at a higher elevation than rocks in the center of the feature. The rocks are mostly angular tabular sandstone, stacked and arranged in a concentric ring around a central depression. Other rocks include fractured and irregularly shaped breccia or sedimentary conglomerates. FCR around the central basin is canted inward at notably steep angles. The outer ring is approximately 2 m north/south by 1.5 m east west. The central depression is about 45 cm in diameter. FCR spill out to the northeast forming an amorphous cluster that may be a rake-out pile. Radiocarbon samples from a bone found within this feature returned conventional dates at 2680 ± 30 BP, with calibrated age range at 2849-2750 cal BP (95.4%) (calibrated at 2σ with IntCal20 [Ramsey 2009; Reimer et al. 2020]), within the Late Archaic period. Artifacts associated with 41DN624 Feature 3 include mussel shell, burned faunal bone, and one lithic biface (Figure 6.15), showing an intensity of use above that seen at other features. Of the faunal remains associated with this feature, 41 bone fragments exhibited signs of carnivore modification, which may represent the provisioning of domesticated dogs (Ramsey, Jacobson, and Haliburton, Chapter 10). Unfortunately, however, the mussel shell was heavily fragmented and none were identifiable to the species level (Figure 6.16; Phillips, Chapter 11). Multiple paleobotanical samples from this feature were analyzed (Chapter 11). Carbonized plant material was identified as hardwood, but more specific identifications could not be made. Acacia opened a block of four contiguous excavation units during testing, Units 6-9, and fully revealed the feature itself. At that time the feature was bisected, and archeologists excavated two additional 10-cm levels in the south half of the feature. Acacia left the northern half of the feature in place at the end of testing efforts. During data recovery, investigators placed seven new units (Units 10-16) to the south and west of Feature 3, as well as excavated the north half of the feature in Units 6 and 7 (Figure 6.14). All units were excavated four or five levels each to depths of 171.78 and 171.87 m. These investigations uncovered a diffuse scatter of FCR, bone and shell in the adjacent units, mostly in Units 12 and 13 at the same elevation as the feature. These likely represent the activity area associated with the feature. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 85

Feature 5 Feature 5 was first identified during the initial mechanical scraping of the site (Figure 6.18; Tables 6.11-6.12). The top of a small cluster of large tabular burned sandstone was uncovered and marked as Feature 5. Four excavation units were placed around it with the goal of exposing additional buried elements of the feature. However, as it turned out, the feature was limited in size and integrity, with no discrete shape or associated debris. One small bone fragment, no lithic debris, and only 2.4 g of mussel shell were recovered. And again, like other contexts, the mussel shell is small and fragmented, unidentifiable to the species level. We are interpreting it as a feature remnant. Due to its very small size and lack of integrity, this feature was not bisected, but all rocks and soil from directly under the larger rocks were recovered and saved as samples. ## Page 116

Feature 6 Archeologists identified Feature 6 at a lower elevation than most other features at 41DN624, within a Middle Archaic soil zone (Figures 6.19-3.20; Table 6.13-6.15). Acacia opened seven units in Trench I to explore this feature – Units 21-24, and 31-33. Feature 6 was an intact rock-lined hearth or earth oven feature. The main part of the feature is about 90 x 80 cm in size and consists of very tightly clustered, stacked, tabular sandstone, many of which are canted inward toward an interior depression. The feature is set within a shallow pit, the lowest portion of which is 12-20 cm lower than the rocks along the periphery. The sandstone rocks comprising Feature 6 are heavily burned, and many are fractured in place with thin flakes actively sloughing off during excavation. These exfoliated fragments account for a good portion of the smaller FCR weighed and counted during feature excavation. It is evident that most of the rocks comprising this feature were originally medium to large in size, with the largest rocks placed along the outside edges of the feature and smaller to medium sized rocks used to fill in and stack the periphery. The bottoms of the rocks were highly fire-reddened or blackened, oftentimes staining the earth below them. This feature is very similar in composition and overall shape to 41DN580 Feature 16, which is also comprised nearly exclusively of large sandstone tablets. A loose scatter of burned sandstone slabs and rocks spills out from the feature to the northeast and southwest. The scatter around the discrete oven feature may represent either rake out or possibly displacement from flood events. Small, unburned gravels were noted in the matrix around the feature, as well as in soil matrix under the feature, with density of natural gravels increasing with depth. This feature also exhibited a large quantity (434.4 grams) of mussel shell fragments around its periphery, and at the same elevation (roughly 171.380 m amsl) in all adjacent units. Five of these are nearly whole shells of the same species, Amblema plicata (Phillips, Chapter 11). Two associated lithics are specimen 132-01 and 137-01. 132-01 is a tertiary flak of Edwards Plateau chert with light use-wear, while 137-01 is a secondary flak of Uvalde chert, also with light use-wear (Figure 6.21; Ayala, Chapter 8). A sample of burned sediment (Beta No. 624821) returned radiocarbon dates at 4900 ± 30 BP, with calibrated 2σ ranges at 5564-5584 (88.5%), 5714-5681 (6.9%) BP (Ramsey 2009; Reimer et al. 2020). Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 92

Feature 7 Feature 7 is a small circular concentration of mostly medium sized tabular sandstone in Units 34 and 43 (Figure 6.22; Tables 6.16-6.17). As with Feature 6, many of the larger rocks were found to be cracked in place, exfoliated during excavation, and account for the majority of the smaller sandstone FCR collected from this feature. Burned soil was evident along the southern edge of the feature, as well as underneath several of the larger rocks. One large, possible griddle stone at the east exterior edge of the feature exhibited red residue underneath it and staining the soil below it. This is likely due to the high iron content of the rock itself. Bisection and profiling revealed that these FCR lined a shallow 10-cm deep pit. Investigators collected 9.7 g of mussel shell fragments, but no lithic debris or faunal bone were present. The mussel shell is unidentifiable Unionidae. It is a circular burned rock concentration over a meter in diameter surrounded by a diffuse FCR scatter extending outward another meter around the main concentration (Figures 6.25- 6.26; Tables 6.20-6.22). The feature is 60-70 cm below the surface and was excavated in Units 35-42. The FCR in this feature is primarily limestone with a small amount of sandstone, as well as limited quartzite and other materials. One sandstone boulder located at the southwest edge of the feature measures more than 30 cm across (collected). Rocks within the main concentration, as well as the surrounding scatter, are generally arranged one rock deep, although excavators did note some tabular sandstone rocks underlying the chunky limestone rocks forming the main concentration in Units 37 and 40. below the ground surface. Excavation around these concentrations revealed them to be just that – loose concentrations of burned rock, scattered together with a notable quantity of bone, a large amount of whole (or nearly whole) mussel shell, and a significant amount lithic material (Figures 6.30-6.33). In fact, 56 of the 62 total pieces (90%) of chipped stone from data recovery at 41DN624 came from the 14 units around Features 10 and 11, primarily Units 46-48 and 61 (Figures 6.32-6.33; see discussion in Chapter 8). Of the 56 lithics from Feature 10/11, 36 (64%) are Edwards Plateau chert. These are mostly tertiary flakes with light use-wear. One biface fragment and one Godley point also came from this context (Chapter 8). Additionally, this area contained the highest density of shell from the site, weighing 443 g. The specimens identifiable to the species level are primarily Amblema plicata, as well as six examples of Toxolasma texasiense (Chapter 11). Vertebrate faunal material from this context is heavily weathered and fragmented medium-large mammal bone (Chapter 10). Interestingly, however, 96.6% of the bone from this context shows signs of carnivore modification. When combined with the heavy weathering, this could indicate either the provisioning of domesticated dogs, or significant post-abandonment scavenging (see Chapter 10). Feature 10 was ultimately documented as a loose collection of tabular sandstone adjacent to a defined mussel shell concentration (Figures 6.30-6.31). One of the tabular sandstone pieces is large and smooth enough to be a possible a metate and was collected. A broken projectile point, Godley type, was recovered on the surface near Unit 46 prior to test unit excavation (Figure 6.32). Figure 6.29. 41DN624 Feature 10 facing east. ## Page 127

Ultimately the importance of Features 10 and 11 (Table 6.23) and the area around them lies not with their morphology but as an apparent discrete activity area where lithic tools were used and resharpened. The lithic debitage recovered from this area in Units 45-57, 61-63 are small tertiary flakes from tool retouching. And the disproportionate density of bone, whole shell, and lithics certainly suggests that some form of specialized processing took place in this area that was not happening elsewhere around the site. Additionally, if we assume that Feature 9 is associated with the activity area of Features 10 and 11, this area likely represents a single occupation. This occupation surface accounts not only for 90% of the site’s lithic material, but also 58% of the faunal bone (64% of which has carnivore modifications) (see Chapters 7 and 9). ## Page 128

periphery with smaller sandstone pieces stacked over them. Many rocks in the upper layers are canted inward toward a central depression. The topmost rocks in the center of the feature are limestone that are so highly burned, they have turned into a crumbly slake that falls apart once dislodged from their locations. The sandstone rocks at the base of the pit are also highly burned and fragmented. Burned soil underlies the rocks and carbonized material is interspersed around and between the FCR. Acacia recovered three charcoal samples from the feature at an elevation of 171.785 m. It is evident that the rocks were initially fired from below. Organic material from multiple flotation samples contained hardwood and Oak (Chapter 11). Since so many of the rocks were either cracked in place or broke during excavation, the number of small rocks (>2 cm) recovered from this feature was disproportionately high, and likely does not reflect the actual number of smaller rocks originally used. The small FCR were weighed but not individually counted, as their number definitely exceeds 500. Although a small amount of mussel shell was noted in situ around the feature, the total occurrence/weight was not notable. A projectile point fragment (Specimen 384-01) was adjacent to Feature 12 (Figure 6.35). The point is broken and made of a pinkish gray Ogallala quartzite. It is possibly a Godley or Trinity type point, but its base has broken off making identification uncertain (Chapter 8). No bone was found in any of the units surrounding Feature 12. These data tell us quite a bit about the construction of this feature. First, a small pit was dug and a fire built up in it. Likely once the fire was somewhat smaller or reduced to coals, the pit was lined with tabular sandstone slabs which were layered with additional hardwood fuel around a central depression. Limestone rocks at the top of the feature may have been used for stone-boing activities taking place while other foods were slow-cooking. In addition to possible packets of foodstuffs wrapped and placed across the rocks, the central depression could have contained a higher volume of foods, possibly items that needed a longer roasting time or possibly a higher temperature. Based on the near absence of faunal remains near the feature, we can speculate that this oven was primarily used to cook plants, and/or that any faunal processing and consumption was taking place elsewhere during this occupation, away from this feature. ## Page 131

Feature 13 Feature 13 is less than 3 m north of Feature 12 and is a loose group of burned sandstone and limestone that lack discrete shape (Figure 6.39; Tables 6.26-6.27). Excavated in Units 65 and 66, the FCR are small pieces. The surrounding matrix was uniform in color and composition throughout the level and below the FCR. None of the sediment around the rocks exhibited signs of burning. This feature appears to be a continuation of the lithic scatter area around Features 10 and 11. Acacia recovered a small broken projectile point with barbed shoulders, possibly a Scallorn, from Unit 65 (specimen 376-01), as well as a complete Darl point (specimen 838-02; Figures 6.40-6.41). The Darl point is heavily refurbished and made of Edwards Plateau chert. There are also two lithic flakes from this context, both are small tertiary retouching flakes (Chapter 8). Additionally, unidentifiable Unionidae shell fragments were recovered throughout the top two levels from each of the test units around Feature 13. No other artifacts are associated with the feature. ## Page 133

Summary During both testing and data recovery efforts at 41DN624, Acacia’s archeologists documented a total of 13 features and excavated 25.32 m3 in 66 units, and eight control units (Table 5.7). These efforts documented 623 pieces of FCR, 62 lithics, 2482.2 g of freshwater mussel shell, and 95 faunal bone fragments (Appendix B). All recovered materials and features date to the Middle and Late Archaic periods. Of these 13 features, three were Category 3 earth ovens, three fit into Category 2, and five were classified as Category 1. Two features, 10 and 11 are uncategorized, as there were very few associated FCR and Acacia believes these represent an activity area rather than two discrete features. Together, Features 9-11 likely represent a single occupation, the central area of the campsite, with an activity area surrounded by cook features. The lithic assemblage (Chapter 8) shows that many activities likely involved scraping tool use, and the possible ground stone suggests other types of plant processing were taking place. Together, these give us a clearer picture of what daily life at these sites was like. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 109

## Page 137

7. S G R UMMARY EOARCHAEOLOGICAL ESULTS By Ken Lawrence, M.A. and Ashley Eyeington, M.A. SWCA Project Description - Background SWCA conducted a geoarchaeological investigation of sites 41DL580 and 41DL624 that included documenting the encountered stratigraphic and cultural deposits at each site, appropriate matrix sampling and analyses, and providing a report of these results. The interpretation of these investigations and recommendations is the subject of this report, which is done in conformance with reporting standards of the THC and CTA reporting guidelines. Previous Regional Geoarchaeological Research To provide context for the project area, a review of previous geoarchaeological investigations in the region relevant to the project area was conducted. The most extensive geoarchaeological investigations within the Upper Trinity River basin occurred about 13 mi (21 km) northeast of 41DN580 and 41DN624 for the Ray Roberts-Lewisville Reservoir Project in Cooke, Denton, and Grayson Counties (Prikryl and Yates 1987; Ferring and Yates 1997). The creation of these reservoirs from the impoundment of segments of the Elm Fork River generated archeological investigations extending over two decades by a variety of interdisciplinary researchers (e.g., Southern Methodist University [SMU], Environmental Consultants, Inc., USACE Fort Worth District, and University of North Texas). These seminal investigations have set the foundation for subsequent investigations within the Trinity River basin and northern Texas. Among the many notable accomplishments from this research was the discovery and investigation of the Aubrey Clovis site (41DN479), which is situated on the Elm Fork River and was identified to have an intact stratigraphy extending into the Pleistocene (Ferring 1990a, 1990b, 1991, 1992, 1994, 1995a, 1995b, 2000, 2001; Humphrey and Ferring 1994). Most significant, the site has a Paleoindian occupation with well-dated stratigraphy that suggests it is one of the oldest Clovis sites currently known (Ferring 2001). In addition, the extensive investigations at the Aubrey Clovis site have provided a robust radiocarbon dataset and information from past environments. A summary of this research is provided followed by other subsequent investigations in the Trinity River basin. In summarizing the alluvial history of the Upper Trinity River basin of which Hickory Creek is a part, Ferring (1994) recognized four morphostratigraphic units (i.e., landforms) composed of deposits from six alloformations. The morphostratigraphic units identified from oldest to youngest include the Stewart Creek Terrace, Hickory Street Terrace, Denton Creek Terrace, and the Floodplain that are interpreted to encompass the Middle Pleistocene up to the present. The Stewart Creek Terrace, which is composed of Irving alloformation deposits, and the Hickory Street Terrace, which is composed of the Coppell alloformation deposits, are indicated to date to the Pleistocene, sometime around 30,000 years ago (Ferring 1994; Ferring and Yates 1997). Ferring (1990a) indicates that the Hickory Street Terrace has been identified by previous researchers as having several designations through the years. The more recent Denton Creek Terrace is composed of Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 113

## Page 138

deposits from the Carrollton alloformation that contain Pleistocene faunal remains (e.g., Bison antiquus) and is interpreted to date to roughly 30,000 to 20,000 years ago (Ferring 1994:47-48). Ferring (1994) indicates that the Aubrey alloformation dates to the Late Pleistocene-Holocene transition. The terminus ante quem for this alloformation is from the Aubrey Clovis site (41DN479), which initially calibrated to 17,030 calibrated (cal) years (yr) before present (BP) (SMU-2236) and terminates sometime after 14,410 cal yr BP (Ferring 1994; Ferring and Yates 1997). The initial calibration of the overlying Sanger alloformation begins in the Late Pleistocene prior to 13,460 cal yr BP (AA-5274) and extends to sometime after 7,550 cal yr BP (SMU-2339) (Ferring 2001:Table 3.2). Ferring (1994:58–59) notes that the Sanger alloformation is capped by a moderately developed buried soil that in several locations has been eroded by the Pilot Point alloformation. The Pilot Point deposits began prior to 4,470 cal yr BP (SMU-2401) and terminated sometime after 1,676 cal yr BP (Beta-14963). A well-developed cumulic soil identified as the West Fork soil frequently caps the Pilot Point alloformation interpreted to encompass the last 4,000 years. Beginning in the Late Pleistocene, the alluvial history of the Upper Trinity River basin, as defined by Ferring (1994:147–149), has a period of stasis with no discernable geomorphic activity occurring between 14,000 to 11,000 years ago (17,000–13,000 calibrated). Specifically, Ferring (1994:147) notes that no alluvial or colluvial deposition or evidence of a disconformity is associated with this period. Subsequent to 11,000 years ago (13,000 calibrated), a period of rapid alluviation occurs in the basin, initiating a phase of valley filling. Interestingly, this period of rapid alluviation occurred shortly after the Clovis occupation at the Aubrey Clovis site and continued until 7,500 years ago (7,550 calibrated) (Ferring 1994:148). This event is inferred to be associated with a shift to a moister (i.e., mesic) climate. By the middle of the Holocene, a shift to a drier (xeric) climate occurred as evidenced by soil development in the Sanger alloformation and eolian deposits in some of the uplands of the upper basin of the Trinity River (Ferring 1994:148). These xeric conditions seemingly continued until approximately 4,500 years ago when a period of rapid alluviation occurred and the deposition of the Pilot Point alloformation began (Ferring 1994:148–149). The rapid alluviation is particularly apparent between 3,000 to 2,000 years ago (Ferring 1994:149). In contrast to other researchers, Ferring (1994) notes that alluviation in the Upper Trinity River basin does not correlate with arid conditions. Instead, Ferring (1994:150–153) noted in this basin that the fluvial response to moist conditions was rapid alluviation and/or erosion while drier conditions led to stability and soil development and that the primary internal influence on a landscape’s evolution is the underlying bedrock, which affects the vegetation. Specifically, the calcareous loams and clay loams derived from weathered limestone support a prairie environment that is more resistant to erosion. Conversely, the non-calcareous soils derived from sandstone and shale supports a mixed forest environment that has a lower threshold for erosion. Two primary external influences identified are the climate and changes in sea level. Although no examples are provided, eustatic influence is not proposed here as a possible influence on the upper extent of the basin. Regarding overall archeological potential within the upper basin, Ferring and Yates (1986, 1997) indicate that archeological sites occur in two principal contexts (i.e., terraces and upon or below floodplains). For the terraces, Ferring and Yates (1997) propose that the Trinity River terraces between Dallas and Valley View are Late Pleistocene in age. As such, any archeological sites less than 11,000 Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 114

Particle Size (Texture) Analysis To examine the texture of the matrix at the two sites, select samples collected during the 2021 significance test excavations were submitted to Texas A&M Soil Characterization Laboratory. At the laboratory, the samples were removed from their initial shipping containers, placed in aluminum or other non-porous, non-corrodible shallow containers and oven dried at 65 C (+2 C) in a forced air oven for 16 hours or until dry. Following oven drying, samples were pulverized using an open-mesh- bottom hammer-style soil pulverizer. All soil exiting the pulverizer was screened to remove all particles greater than a 2-millimeter (mm) diameter. The texture analyses used the pipette method and identified the percentages of coarse fragments (>2.00 mm), sand (2.00–0.05 mm), silt (0.05–0.002 mm), and clay (<0.002 mm). The data from these analyses are summarized in the report. Calcium Carbonate Equivalent Select samples collected during the 2021 significance test excavations were submitted to Texas A&M Soil Characterization Laboratory. At the laboratory, a small (1.7 g) portion of the <2-mm matrix of each soil/sediment sample was then dried overnight at 105˚C, subsequently ground in a mortar and pestle, and used to determine the calcium carbonate equivalent (CCE) by means of a Chittick apparatus (Dreimani 1962; Machette 1986). The dried and ground samples were weighed and placed into a small (250 [milliliter] ml) Erlenmeyer flask. Once attached to the Chittick apparatus, the liquid level in the measuring burette was set to -10 ml, then the stopcock was closed to prevent off gassing, and the leveling bulb was lowered to establish a vacuum inside the sample chamber. Subsequently, the barometric pressure and room temperature were recorded. Then 10 ml of 50 percent hydrochloric acid (HCl) was delivered to the sample flask and was periodically agitated until the reaction was complete (about 1–2 minutes). The leveling bulb was then raised to the elevation of the liquid level of the sample in the burette. The volume of gas evolved was then measured and the calcium carbonate equivalent was calculated. The data from these analyses are summarized in the report. Organic Carbon and Stable Carbon Isotopic Analysis Carbon is found in soils in two forms consisting organic carbon and inorganic carbon (Kolb 2017; Milne 2023). The organic carbon or soil organic matter is derived from the natural decomposition of flora and fauna and by extension human activities including their byproducts like food and waste (Kolb 2017). However, the most significant anthropogenic alteration of organic matter is thermal activity (Kolb 2017:16). Inorganic carbon can be produced by flora that contains crystals (e.g., opaline Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 118


---

## Page 143

silica and calcium oxalate), but primarily comes from parent materials like carbonate rock (Kolb 2017). The measurement of organic carbon within soil organic matter typically decreases vertically with depth in a soil profile (Nordt and Holliday 2017). In addition to possibly identifying areas of enhanced anthropogenic activity in a profile, the measurement of organic carbon may identify unconformities expressed as paleosols within sedimentary deposits. Measurements of the stable carbon isotope (δ13C) composition of the soil organic matter can also provide information on the structure of past plant communities since the uptake of the heavier 13C isotope during photosynthesis differs between C3 (e.g., arboreal species) and C4 (e.g., warm season grasses) plants (Nordt 2001; Nordt and Holliday 2017; Vogel 1980; Weiner 2010). The determination of δ13C has also been used for analyzing past climates (Mandel et al. 2007; Nordt et al. 1994, 2002, 2007). Of particular interest for this project is the δ13C VPDB (Vienna Pee Dee Belemnite) or the carbon stable isotope standard derived from a Cretaceous-age formation in North Carolina. This metric can be used to interpret regional flora communities for paleoenvironmental and subsistence or diet reconstructions (Ehleringer and Monson 1993; Lohse et al. 2014b; Nordt 2001; Weiner 2010). Generally, the ratio of 13C to 12C (i.e., δ13C) can indicate whether C3 or C4 plant communities were more abundant. C3 flora (e.g., trees, shrubs, and cool season grasses) are adapted to more temperate climates and have a lower percentage of δ13C isotopes around -27‰ parts per thousand (Boutton 1991a, 1991b; Ehleringer 1991; Hoppe et al. 2006; Julien et al. 2012; Lohse et al. 2014b; Nordt 2001; Nordt and Holliday 2017). The C4 plants (e.g., warm season grasses) occur in arid environments and have a higher percentage of δ13C around -13‰ (Boutton 1991b; Ehleringer 1991; Hoppe et al. 2006; Julien et al. 2012; Lohse et al. 2014b; Nordt 2001; Nordt and Holliday 2017). Put simply and in relation to this project, an increase in C3 plants should indicate a wetter more temperate environment while a decrease exhibited in increasing C4 biomass is indicative of drier and warmer conditions (Mandel et al. 2007:56). Nordt and Holliday (2017:903) note that δ13C around -20‰ could most likely indicate a mixed community of C3 and C4 biomass. However, other researchers in the area have selected the δ13C value -19‰ as the demarcation of a mixed C3 and C4 biomass (Hall et al. 2011:542). For the purposes of these investigations, the δ13C value of -20‰ is considered the threshold for a mixed C3 and C4 biomass. A distinction must be made when considering δ13C for interpreting paleoenvironments when using data from 14C analyses from radiocarbon laboratories. Specifically, the δ13C correction 14C/12C ratios during the analyses are typically not as accurate as that conducted at a stable carbon isotope geochemistry laboratory (Nordt and Holliday 2017:905). Put simply, the resulting δ13C from the radiocarbon analyses may not accurately reflect past environmental data and warrants some caution (Collins and Bousman 2015:6; Nordt and Holliday 2017:905). In the context of these investigations, the δ13C values derived from humate dating from Beta Analytic were compared against δ13C samples from the Keck-NSF Laboratory from the same elevations. In each instance (n=9), the humate dating δ13C values were +-2‰ different than the δ13C values from the Keck-NSF Laboratory. Although these data are still useful, the humate dating δ13C values from 41DN580 and 41DN624 were not included in the δ13C analyses. The δ13C VPDB values provided by Keck-NSF Laboratory were converted to percentages of C3 and C4 plant biomass. The equation uses the interpreted mean δ13C values for C3 and C4 and is presented below (Bousman et al. 1990). Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 119

Magnetic Susceptibility (MS) Analysis Magnetic Susceptibility (MS) analyses of soils have been utilized for archeological investigations for several decades, and have largely been directed toward surveys (e.g., Crowther and Barker 1995; Dalan 1996, 2008; Rosendahl et al. 2014; Van Leusen et al. 2014; Wiewel and Kvamme 2014). More recently, these investigations have focused on archeological site formation and associated depositional processes (Dalan 2006, 2008). These analyses have assisted in identifying buried or thermally altered soils associated with cultural activities, as well as identifying the horizontal extent of cultural features (e.g., Dalan and Banerjee 1998; Dalan and Bevan 2002; Dinckal et al. 2022; Ellwood et al. 1995; Frederick 2010; Jones and Leffler 2003; Mauldin and Figueroa 2006; Nickels 2010; Peters and Thompson 1999; Rivers et al. 2004). Extensive reviews of the processes of environmental magnetism and particularly the application of MS have been produced (e.g., Dearing 1999a, 1999b; Gale and Hoare 1991:201–229; Maher et al. 1999; Thompson and Oldfield 1986; Verosub and Roberts 1995). Briefly, however, magnetic minerals are prevalent in the natural environment and are sensitive to environmental changes (Gale and Hoare 1991:202). The measurement of MS, χ (Chi), is a quantification of the “magnetisability” of the material (Dalan 2008; Dalan and Banerjee 1998; Dearing 1999b:5; Gale and Hoare 1991:202–204). The mineralology, the size and shape of the grains, internal stress, and other factors can initially influence the susceptibility value (Dearing 1999a, 1999b; Gale and Hoare 1991:204). However, of relevance to this discussion, factors including organic content, pedogenesis, thermal alteration, and cultural activities (e.g., ash-charcoal and refuse) can subsequently alter (usually increase) the susceptibility values. The implications of using MS for archeological research is that when examining either vertical or horizontal areas, the susceptibility values can assist in identifying cultural activity areas that may otherwise be blurred at a macro level. MS analysis has been used to define the limits of cultural features and living spaces in excavation blocks (e.g., Mauldin and Figueroa 2006; Wiewel and Kvamme 2014). Vertically, the MS results have been applied to recognizing and delineating cultural horizons (e.g., Frederick 2010, 2012; Lawrence and Frederick 2012). For the significance test investigations at 41DN580, MS samples were collected from profile walls of Trenches B and C. During the data recovery investigations, MS samples were also collected from the profile walls of Trenches D and E excavation areas. At 41DN624 during the significance test excavations, samples were collected from Trench E. For the data recovery investigations at 41DN624, MS samples were collected from Trenches H and J and select samples were collected in proximity to Feature 7 and near some FCR in the profile wall of Trench K. As both sites, the MS samples were typically collected up profile in systematic 5-cm intervals. Each of the samples were mapped into the profile, effectively correlating them to site stratigraphy and excavation elevation. The select samples were placed in 8-cc inert plastic cubes and correlated with the respective profile stratigraphy. These samples were subsequently analyzed using a Bartington MS2 meter and MS2B dual frequency sensor to examine both low (χlf) and high (χhf) frequency (470 and 4700 Hz, respectively) MS. The cube samples were measured at the high sensitivity setting (i.e., 0.1) compared to the normal sensitivity setting (i.e., 1.0). The high sensitivity setting was necessary since the frequency dependency of the MS samples were also calculated (Gale and Hoare 1991:223– 224). The values for each cube sample were catalogued twice at both the low and high frequencies to provide an average value using the Système International scale. Each of the χlf, χhf, and the average values were recorded, as well as each sample’s weight in an Excel table. After every five readings, the Bartington MS2 meter was “zeroed” out to recalibrate the meter. The cube samples from this analysis were subsequently calculated using the methods outlined by Gale and Hoare (1991:223–226). Briefly however, the primary metric for recognizing MS values of interest is the coefficient of frequency dependency (χfd). This calculation is indicated as: χfd= 100 [(χlf-χhf)/ χlf] This calculation uses χlf as the ‘normal’ sensitivity value and contrasts it with the χhf value to reveal significant values of difference in percentages (Dearing 1999a:47, 1999b:17–18; Gale and Hoare 1991:226). Elevated values of χfd can represent concentrations of fine to ultrafine magnetic grains (e.g., maghemite), which are commonly associated with pedogenesis (Dalan 2006:164; 2008:22; Dinckal et al. 2022:846). Conversely, low values of χfd can represent multidomain grains which can be associated with anthropogenic influences (Tiwow et al. 2021). Several factors may cause an increase in χlf values including biological (e.g., bacteria) or inorganic (e.g., natural weathering of iron minerals) processes. In an archeological context, an increase in χlf values may reflect cultural activities from thermal features and general refuse (Dalan 2008; Dalan and Banerjee 1998; Frederick 2012). Ideally, when applied to a vertical profile on an archeological site, collected in systematic intervals (e.g., 2–3 cm), and contrasted with cultural data (e.g., artifact frequencies), this analysis can provide valuable data to interpret site formation and cultural activities. Radiocarbon Analyses Radiocarbon analysis was also conducted during the investigations to assist in providing chronostratigraphic data. Due to the paucity of charcoal samples for AMS analyses at 41DN580 and 41DN624, most of the chronometric analyses at these sites were done on bulk humate samples of sediment. During the significance test excavations at 41DN580, three samples of charred material and five samples of bulk humate were analyzed. For the data recovery excavations at 41DN580, two samples of charred material, one bone fragment, and five samples of bulk humate were analyzed for an overall total of 17 analyzed assays at 41DN580. During the significance test excavations at 41DN624, one sample of charred material and four bulk humate samples were analyzed. For the data recovery excavations at 41DN624, one sample of charred material and seven samples of bulk humate were analyzed for a total of 13 analyzed assays examined at the site. All of the samples were sent to Beta Analytic, Inc., who conducted the analyses. Notably, radiocarbon years (14C) are not calendar years, but rather a measurement of remaining 14C isotopes (Bartlein et al. 1995; Blackwell and Buck 2008; Blackwell et al. 2006; Blockley et al. 2007; McCormac and Baillie 1993; Mock and Bartlein 1995; Ramsey 2008a, 2008b, 2009:337; Stuiver and Suess 1966). Consequently, the 14C years must be converted to a calendrical format (i.e., calibrated) for general interpretation and comparison (Mook and Waterbolk 1985:20; Taylor and Bar-Yosef 2014). This study uses the nomenclature proposed by Nordt (1992) and the journal of American Antiquity guidelines for distinguishing between uncalibrated radiocarbon and calibrated radiocarbon results. Specifically, the results of these analyses are here reported in both conventional radiocarbon age (14C yr BP) and the calendar calibrated (cal BP) results. The Gregorian calendar year AD 1950 is recognized as the beginning point of BP (Hua 2009; Mook and Waterbolk 1985; Stuiver and Polach 1977; Taylor 1997:67– 68; 2009). The data from these analyses are summarized in the report and provided in Appendix D. Optically Stimulated Luminescence Analysis Due to the sparse quantity of radiocarbon assays from both 41DN580 and 41DN624, OSL analyses were also conducted during the data recovery investigations at these sites. Detailed histories and principles regarding luminescence dating, which includes OSL, are extensively covered by previous researchers (e.g., Aitken 1998; Bateman 2019a; Mahan and DeWitt 2019; Malainey 2010; Nelson et al. 2015) and are not elaborated here. Briefly, however, luminescence dating can provide an age estimate of the last exposure of quartz or feldspar minerals to light (e.g., sunlight) or heat. Considering that quartz and feldspar are the two most prevalent minerals on the Earth’s crust and that luminescence dating can date samples between 25 and 300,000 years in age, the implications for archeological chronostratigraphy is obvious (Rittenour 2008). Several paired sets of OSL samples were collected for analyses at both 41DN580 and 41DN624. The approach was to target stratigraphic contexts at both sites to bridge the gap between the lower resolution chronometric assays (i.e., organic sediment) to the higher resolution assays (i.e., charcoal assays) at each site. These samples were paired (i.e., two samples collected in the same location) to provide a reserve should some unforeseen mishap in analyses occur. collected from the stratigraphy of Trench D. At 41DN624, two paired sets were collected from Trench H and two paired sets were collected from Trench J. These samples were collected using methods outlined by Nelson et al. (2015) and Bateman (2019b) that involves driving a 20-cm-long and 3.8-cm-diameter opaque metal tube horizontally into a clean profile. The interior and exterior ends were capped and sealed immediately after extraction to prevent the sample getting exposed to sunlight. Prior to sample tube extraction, an environmental dose rate sample was collected within a 30-cm radius around the tube and placed in a quart-size bag and sealed. Chronometric Modelling The chronometric data obtained from the significance test and data recovery radiocarbon analyses were examined in a variety of ways with statistical modelling. The conventional radiocarbon results from Beta Analytic, Inc., were recalibrated and subsequently examined with Bayesian modeling. Briefly, the calibration software (e.g., OxCal, Bcal, and Calib), interprets the conventional 14C data with a probability distribution (Banning 2000; Ramsey 1995, 1998, 2001, 2008a, 2009). The calibration software plots the 14C dating results onto the calibration curve (for this research the recently updated IntCal20 curve was used) and then characterizes the probability of the interpolated outcome (Ramsey 1995, 1998, 2001, 2008a, 2008b, 2009; Reimer et al. 2020). More than a half dozen software packages are available for calibration, but the one used for the 41DN580 and 41DN624 analyses was OxCal Version 4.4. The analyses were primarily conducted using default settings with output set at both 68.2 percent (1σ) and 95.4 percent (2 σ) and rounded to the nearest decade for a minimum of 30,000 iterations. One major benefit of this program is that it can incorporate Bayesian statistics into the characterization of the dating results, which can include radiocarbon. Bayesian statistics enables a researcher to incorporate new information as well as accounting for prior information to provide the most probable result. The technique uses Baye’s theorem that expresses the uncertainty of an event or set of parameters occurring before and subsequent to the results of an analysis (Buck 2004; Buck et al. 1996; Christian 1994). Put another way, the Bayesian analysis of chronometric data considers all possibilities of the outcome (prior) with the measured data (likelihood), and then determines the probability of those results occurring in relation to the other parameters (Bayliss and Ramsey 2004; Blackwell and Buck 2008; Buck 2004; Buck et al. 1991, 1992a, 1992b, 1994, 1996, 2006; Christian 1994; Heaton et al. 2009; Ilan 2001; Lulewicz 2018; Ramsey 2009). A prior probability can be inferred from relative dates (e.g., stratigraphic position) and then compared Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 123


---

## Page 148

with the likelihood probability that is available from the absolute dates (e.g., 14C or OSL dates), which culminates in the determination of the posterior probability. When comparing multiple events simultaneously, the large number of individual combinations that are considered for each outcome (iteration) can become infinite. To aid in these analyses by calibration software, a sampling algorithm, such as the Metropolis-Hastings or equivalent, is typically used (Ramsey 2009). Metropolis-Hastings is an algorithm of the Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, which randomly examines each event across a defined distribution, gradually increasing the confidence of the result (Breyer 2010; Heaton et al. 2009; Ramsey 2009). Further, the implementation of MCMC allows for the inclusion of the uncertainty of multiple factors that can allow for the comparison of points as well as their deviations on the curve (Buck and Blackwell 2004:1101; Everitt 2002; Upton and Cook 2006). The chronometric assays from each site were each examined with regards to their respective stratigraphic horizon and vertical position. These OxCal analyses compared both the radiocarbon results using the Phase model (under the Sequential setting) and the Deposition model (under the Poisson distribution P_Sequence setting) (Ramsey 2008a, 2009). The sequential setting allows for sets of chronometric data to be grouped in a sequence (i.e., stratigraphic) and contrasted both within the group and against other groups (Ramsey 2009). Further, the sequential setting operates under the assumption that another group (i.e., horizon) cannot be temporally contiguous or overlapping (Ramsey 2009). The P_Sequence in the Deposition model assumes the deposition is a function of another parameter, typically depth (Ramsey 2008a). The intent of using this suite of modelling techniques were twofold. The first was to determine how secure each assay correlated with their respective depth and against the other assays. Considering that most of the chronometric assays were on bulk humate this outlier review was an important factor to establish. Secondly, the modelling assisted in quantifying the rates of sedimentation, which could also be used in evaluating integrity of the cultural deposits at the sites. A summary of the results of these analyses are discussed below. These geoarcheological investigations involved examining, sampling, and documenting multiple profiles across the site. To supplement the profile data from the significant test investigations, the data recovery investigations focused on portions of the site that provided the best representative and deepest stratigraphy. Organic Carbon and Stable Carbon Isotope δ13C Analysis Organic Carbon analyses at 41DN580 in Trench D excavations revealed a steady decrease with depth, but there were a few notable fluctuations (Figure 7.10). Optically Stimulated Luminescence Analysis As mentioned previously, OSL analyses were also conducted during the investigations at 41DN580. Two OSL single grain samples from the Trench D profile were analyzed to assist in the chronometric data for the site. One sample (D02, USU-3870) was collected near the top of Zone IV Bk1 horizon while the second sample (D01, USU-3869) was collected from the Zone VI Bk3 horizon near the base of the excavations (see Figure 7.7). These samples bracketed the geomatrix humate samples to assist in providing some resolution to the chronometric data. Due to the high overdispersion (OD) values exceeding 20%, the age of the samples was analyzed using the Central Age Model (CAM) advocated by Galbraith and Roberts (2012). Sample D02, USU-3870 at 173.3 m elevation returned a 1σ age of 5,320±480 BP with an OD value of 25+3% (Appendix F). Further down, sample D01, USU-3869 at 172.2 m elevation returned a 1σ age of 7,480±680 BP with an OD value of 26+3% (Appendix F). For context, single grain OD values between 9–20% in sedimentary settings like 41DN580 are considered to have been well bleached during deposition (Mahan and DeWitt 2019:20). However, single grain OD values exceeding 20% may indicate the mixing of grains of various ages from post-depositional processes or the partial resetting of grains (Bateman et al. 2003). Accordingly, these samples are interpreted to have been well bleached during initial deposition but have experienced some partial post-depositional mixing. Radiocarbon Analysis During significance test excavation at 41DN580 five geomatrix humate samples from Trench A were submitted for analyses between 174.33–172.25 m elev. (57–265 cmbs) and three AMS charcoal assays were submitted for analyses from three of the excavated thermal features (i.e., Features 3, 5, and 8). These eight chronometric samples were supplemented with an additional nine samples from the data recovery excavations for a total of 17 assays (Table 7.2). Five of the data recovery radiocarbon samples were collected from Trench D between 173.13–172.07 m elev. (130–236 cmbs). These organic sediment samples were collected from contexts to fill in the gaps of the significance test excavations and date the lowest contexts at 41DN580. Of the remaining four data recovery excavation radiocarbon samples, three consisted of charcoal (Beta-619325–619327) and one organic sediment assay (Beta- 624819) and all collected in proximity to identified features. The chronometric dates for all 17 samples were examined with statistical modelling. The dates of the features and the elevations of these samples were integrated with the humate chronometric data that indicate the deposits between 174.48–172.07 m elevation ranged from 7300–1100 BP (Table 7.2). Although the samples were collected in several locations across 41DN580, the results of the chronometric assays returned an overall good elevational and stratigraphic correlation. Put simply, with only one exception (Beta-619325) the assays were in a good sequence regarding their elevation and age compared to the other samples. The one exception (Beta-619325) fit well within the appropriate stratigraphic zone (i.e., Zone II), but its elevation was slightly below a sample (Beta- 597405) collected from Trench A at the top of Zone III. This difference in elevations between these samples, separated by over 10 m distance, may be attributed to the slight topographic difference across the site. When comparing these dates solely by stratigraphic position, the ages of the samples fell into an excellent sequence. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 142

## Page 172

Calculations were conducted of the combined chronometric data to determine an approximate deposition rate at 41DN580. Based on the current data from all 17 radiocarbon and two OSL assays, the overall average deposition rate at 41DN580 is 3.4 cm per 100 years. These overall average rates of sedimentation at 41DN580 would be categorized as Slow under Ferring’s (1986:261) sedimentation categories. Using the OxCal Deposition Model output, some initial calculations of sedimentation by stratigraphic zone were also conducted using the assays in excellent vertical context. Specifically, the assays from Trenches A and D were used for the lower strata and the assays from Trench E were used for the upper strata modelling. Beginning in Zone VI (modelled ages of ~7300–6800 cal BP), the rates of deposition from Sample 580.D02 to the modelled boundary change suggests an average of 2.4 cm per 100 years (see Figure 7.14). The overlying Zone V (modelled ages of ~6800–4800 cal BP), the rates of deposition from Sample 580.A10 to the modelled boundary change suggests an average of 3.7 cm per 100 years. This period of deposition encompasses Features 3, 5, and 8 (see Figure 7.14). The overlying Zone IV (modelled ages of ~4000–2800 cal BP) extends from the modelled boundary change of Zone IV/V upward to the modelled boundary change of Zone III/IV and includes Sample 580.A06 and has an average of 5.2 cm per 100 years, almost doubling that observed in Zone V. For the Zone III sedimentation rate calculations, the lone Zone III assay from Trench A (sample 580.A04) suggests a modelled age of ~2000–1300 cal BP for the upper and lower limits for the horizon. These data suggest an average of 4.2 cm per 100 years. Finally in Zone II (modelled ages of ~1300–600 cal BP) extends from the modelled boundary change of Zone II/III and upward through the three charcoal assays in Zone II and suggests an average of 4.4 cm per 100 years (see Figure 7.15). Additionally, calculations were performed of the charred material of the examined features (Features 3, 5, 8, and Trench E Zone II charcoal) at 41DN580. This examination was conducted to try and determine approximate spans of occupation and the duration between Feature 3 and Feature 8. The modelling was also conducted to assess if the Trench E Zone II charcoal were likely to be one or multiple activities. These data were modelled under the OxCal v4.4.4 Phase tool using the Span and Interval query function. The chronometric data for Features 5 and 8 were interpreted to be a single phase and the span (i.e., span of the dated events) was calculated. Specifically, the modelled span for the data of Features 5 and 8 indicates a span of 0–234 years (2 σ). This suggests that the activities encompassing these two features occurred within less than 234 years. However, based on the vertical proximity of these two features (roughly 6 cm apart in elevation), these features are interpreted to be generally concurrent. Since the Span of activities for Feature 3 occupation is limited to one date, the current interpretation for this cultural zone is solely based on the Feature 3 date. For the determination of the interval between Feature 3 and Feature 8 to determine the length of time between these cultural zones, the span of these dates is 1029–1421 years apart based on 2 σ modelled dates. This suggests a minimum of interval of roughly 1000 years between the occupations. Similarly, span modelling was conducted on cultural features of 41DN580 to quantify the possible periods and duration of activity. The modelled span for the analyzed feature data in the Sanger deposits (i.e., Features 5 and 8) indicates a span of 0–232 years (2 σ) between 5290–4960 BP. Although limited to the dates from two features, this data may reflect a single occupation or very limited occupations during that period. ## Page 173

The modelled span for the feature data for the Pilot Point and West Fork deposits are a bit more dispersed. The assays from Feature 3, 580.301, 580.174, and 580.304 have a span of 3300 years (2 σ) between 4000–690 BP. However, when you isolate the assays from 580.301, 580.174, and 580.304 there is an overlap between 740–720 BP with a span of 0–210 years (2 σ). These data suggest at least two periods of activity during the Pilot Point-West Fork alloformation. The earliest, associated with Feature 3 would be between 4000–3700 BP while the latter would be between 800–700 BP. 41DN580 Synthesis The deposits at 41DN580 are interpreted to encompass the Pilot Point-West Fork and Sanger alloformations commonly encountered in the Trinity River basin of which the site is a part (Abbott 2011; Ferring 1990a, 1990b, 1991, 1992, 1994). Ferring (1994) indicates the Pilot Point deposits began deposition prior to calibrated 4470 BP (SMU-2401) and terminated sometime after calibrated 1676 BP (Beta-14963). However, Frederick et al. (2006:32) observe that other research along the Trinity River dates the upper limits of the Pilot Point alloformation more recently as 300 years BP. Underlying the Pilot Point alloformation is the occasionally recognized Sanger alloformation that is capped by the Arlington soil. The deposition of the Sanger alloformation has been dated elsewhere to be between 13,400–7,500 cal BP followed by a period of stability (Arlington soil) to be generally between 7500– 4500 cal BP (Ferring 1994; Frederick and McKee 2019). The oldest humate date from 41DN580 (Beta- 62775) returned a 2σ calibrated date of 7790–7620 BP while the modelled age of the deepest OSL sample (USU3869) returned a date of 7090–6905 BP. These data securely place the 41DN580 deposits as beginning in the Middle Holocene and extending to the present. As noted previously, most of the chronometric data at 41DN580 was obtained from bulk humate (organic sediment), which is a factor that warrants some discussion. Abbott (2008) provides an excellent summary on the limits of using “humate ages” uncritically and without caution. Briefly, this analysis provides an average time of death for a large variety of organic materials contained within the soil (e.g., plant material, carbonized remains, cellulose, lipids, etc.). Abbott (2008:18) indicates that humate ages for soils in upland settings provides an average age of all the organics in the system sometimes referred to as ‘mean residence time’. In this situation, young carbon is continually being mixed with the older decaying carbon and frequently date younger than the actual age of deposition (Birkeland 1999:137–140). Within a lowland setting, such as site 41DN580, the humate samples incorporate the organisms in the vicinity of the sample as well as organisms from the surrounding uplands. Abbott (2008:18) indicates the humate samples in lowland settings commonly date older than their age of deposition. It is cautioned that it is not the radiocarbon analyses of humate samples that may be incorrect, but rather the interpretation (and expectations) of the researcher that may be in error (Abbott 2008:19). Considering how narrow the Hickory Creek valley is that encompasses 41DN580, the influence of upland organics likely affected chronometric data to some degree. However, based on the strong correlation of ages compared to their depths illustrated in the regression model (see Figure 7.16) the influence of upland organics on the humate ages appears to have been consistent. Further, the deeper humate dates compared with the single grain OSL assays compare remarkably well despite some apparent post-depositional mixing. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 149

## Page 174

Interestingly, the deposits at 41DN580 exhibited no clear evidence of a buried soil or any erosional disconformities to clearly demarcate the boundary between the Pilot Point and Sanger alloformations. The overall average deposition rate at 41DN580 is 3.4 cm per 100 years (see Figures 7.14 and 7.15). These data suggest a gradual, cumulic deposition for the site that would be categorized as a Slow sedimentation category (Ferring 1986:261; Yates and Ferring 1986:189). The occupations at 41DN580 as indicated by the cultural features (i.e., site furniture) appear to suggest minimally three periods of primary occupation (see Figures 7.11 and 7.12). The oldest in Zones IV and V (Bk1 and Bk2 horizons) encompassing Features 5, 8, and possibly Features 15–17 roughly ~5000–4800 BP. The next oldest in Zone IV (Bk1 horizon) encompassing Feature 3 and possibly Features 4–6 at roughly ~4000– 3800 BP. Finally, the most recent prehistoric occupation in the partially truncated Zone II (A horizon) encompassing Feature 14 at roughly ~750–700 BP. Results Of Investigations 41DN624 As previously mentioned geoarchaeological field investigations for the significance test excavations (Trenches A–E) were conducted in May 2021 followed by data recovery investigations occurred in November 2021 (Figures 7.17-7.19). The data recovery investigations (Trenches F–K) focused on the southern portion of the site, particularly around Trench E. These geoarcheological investigations involved examining, sampling, and documenting multiple profiles across the site. To supplement the profile data from the significant test investigations, the data recovery investigations focused on portions of the site that provided the best representative and deepest stratigraphy. Site Stratigraphy The profile of 41DN624 was provided by Trench E during significance test excavations and Trenches H, I, J, and K during the data recovery excavations (Figures 7.18-7.19). All of these exposures were examined and documented as well as exposed excavation units and the stratigraphy across the site was relatively consistent. Detailed profile descriptions are presented in Appendix C. The profile of Trench J provided the deepest exposure extending from 172.64–170.67 m elevation and contained six horizons (Figures 7.20–7.23). The remaining site profiles contained all or most of the observed horizons and varied depending on depth of excavation (Figure 7.24). The surface horizon at Trench J extended to 21 cmbs (172.49 m elevation) and consisted of dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) loam with a friable consistency and subangular blocky structure (see Figure 7.22). The lower boundary of Zone I was clear and wavy and designated as an Ap horizon. The underlying horizon (Zone II) extended to 42 cmbs (172.28 m elevation) consisted of brown (10YR 4/3) silty clay loam with a friable consistency and subangular blocky structure with a clear and smooth lower boundary. The chronometric data for the underlying horizon suggests that Zone II may correlate with the West Fork soil. The underlying third horizon (Zone III) extended to roughly 76 cmbs (171.94 m elevation) and consisted of yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) silt clay loam with a friable consistency and angular blocky structure, few subrounded pebbles and common CaCO3 filaments. The lower boundary of Zone III was gradual and smooth and was interpreted to be a Bk1 horizon. The chronometric data for Zone III correlates firmly within the recognized age of the Pilot Point Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 150

alloformation. The underlying Zone IV extended to 166 cmbs (171.04 m elevation) and consisted of yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) silt clay loam with a firm consistency and angular blocky parting to prismatic structure. This stratum contained many CaCO3 filaments, few Rabdotus snails, few 5–30 mm subrounded pebbles, cluster of mussel shell beginning at 133 cmbs (171.31 m elevation). The lower boundary of Zone IV was gradual and smooth and was interpreted to be a Bk2 horizon. The chronometric data for Zone IV correlates with the recognized age of the Sanger alloformation. The fifth horizon (Zone V) extended to 189 cmbs (170.81 m elevation) and consisted of yellowish brown to dark yellowish brown (10YR 5/4–4/4) silty clay with a firm consistency and prismatic structure. Zone V contained common 20–50 mm subrounded pebbles with vertical and horizontal orientation, and many CaCO3 filaments. The lower boundary of Zone V was abrupt and irregular and interpreted to be a Btk horizon. The chronometric data for Zone IV correlates with the recognized age of the Sanger alloformation. The lowest stratum observed at 41DN624 was Zone VI and extended below 203 cmbs (170.67 m elevation). Zone VI consists of a yellowish brown to dark yellowish brown (10YR 5/4–4/4) clay with a firm and angular blocky structure containing common many CaCO3 filaments, common 2–3 mm many CaCO3 masses, many matrix supported subrounded limestone and sandstone pebbles, and few mussel shell fragments. The lower boundary for Zone VI is unobserved and was interpreted to be a C horizon. The age of the Zone VI deposits is based on the OSL sample (7270+630 BP) from the overlying Zone V. Based on the abrupt contact between Zones V and VI it is uncertain how extensive and how many deposits are missing from erosion. Accordingly, the age of Zone VI is currently interpreted to be greater than 7500 BP. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 151

## Page 184

Geoarchaeological Analyses 41DN624 Particle Size Distribution A series of soil geomatrix samples were collected at 41DN624 to help characterize the site deposits. The geomatrix samples for the data recovery excavations were collected from Trench E (n=6) during the significance test excavations and utilized for the data recovery investigations (Table 17.3). The results of the particle size texture analyses conducted by the Texas A&M Soil Characterization Laboratory for Trench E the upper Zone I–III is a silty clay loam transitioning into a clay loam near the base of the excavation. The overall site deposits show a very slight coarsening upward of clast materials (Figure 7.25). There is a slight (1 percent) fraction of coarse clast materials (>2 mm) consisting of subrounded pebbles and gravels indicated in one sample of Zone III of Trench E. No other coarse materials were measured in the geomatrix samples of Trench E. Overall, the particle size distribution exhibits a generally continuous profile of alluvial deposits with a gradual transition from a silty clay loam into a clay loam down profile. No evident unconformities or dramatic fluctuations are present in these deposits. Calcium Carbonate Similar to the particle size analyses of the geomatrix samples from site 41DN624, the calcium carbonate (CaCO3) equivalent analysis shows no dramatic fluctuations (Table 7.3). The data indicates a gradual and steady increase of CaCO3 down profile (see Figure 7.25). Organic Carbon and Stable Carbon Isotope δ13C Analysis Organic Carbon analyses at 41DN624 in Trench J excavations revealed a large decrease in values in the upper Ap horizon followed by a steady decrease with depth (Figure 7.26). There are a few subtle fluctuations in the Bk1 and Bk2 horizons (see Figure 7.26). Although minimal, these fluctuations are roughly equivalent in elevation to cultural features near Trench J and may correlate with anthropogenic activity. The overall results of the stable carbon isotope (δ13C) analyses at 41DN624 ranged from a high -14.57‰ and a low -18.77‰ (see Figure 7.26; Appendix E). Although fluctuating, these data suggest that the environment for 41DN624 has been predominantly composed of C4 biomass with grasslands. Within the lower Btk horizon and overlying Bk2 horizon, the δ13C values show decreasing C4 biomass and the environment was approaching mixed grassland and arboreal for periods of time. Similar to 41DN580, the uppermost A horizon to the surface had decreasing C4 biomass and was returning to a mixed grassland and arboreal environment. Magnetic Susceptibility Two columns of MS samples were collected at 41DN624. One column was collected in Trench E (n=41) and one column from Trench J (n=60). The MS results from Trench E exhibits a steady and gradual decline in values down profile (see Figures 7.25 and 7.26). Interestingly, while no clear spike in MS values can be seen in Zone III where Feature 3 (roughly 172.11), the values remain steady through the zone. Feature 3 is a large thermal feature situated about 2 m south of the MS column. Therefore, it appears that cultural activities at 41DN624 have no evident correlation to the MS values. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 160

## Page 185

Overall, the Trench E MS column does not exhibit any unconformities, but rather a steady and gradual decrease in values down profile. Although the second MS column in Trench J exhibits a steady and gradual decline in values down profile, gradual decrease in values the samples exhibited a bit more variability. There are notable fluctuations in Zone II (172.29 m), Zone III (172.11 m), and Zone IV (~171.20–171.11 m) (see Figure 7.26). The subtle MS fluctuation in Zone II may be attributed to recent disturbance. The MS fluctuation in Zone III is at a comparable depth as Features 9–10 and are interpreted to be associated with cultural activities. The fluctuations in χlf and the χfd values near the base of Zone IV where not in proximity to any recognized cultural activities. These fluctuations are more likely attributed to pedogenesis commonly associated with an increase in χfd values (Dalan 2006:164; 2008:22; Dinckal et al. 2022:846). Overall, the Trench J MS column does not exhibit any clear unconformities, but rather a steady and gradual decrease in values down profile. Optically Stimulated Luminescence Analysis As mentioned previously OSL analyses were also conducted during the investigations at 41DN624. Two OSL single grain samples from the Trench J profile were analyzed to assist in the chronometric data for the site. One sample (J01, USU-3871) was collected near the base of Zone IV Bk2 horizon while the second sample (J02, USU-3872) was collected from the Zone V Btk horizon near the base of the excavations (see Figures 7.22 and 7.24). Notably, no OSL samples were collected from the lowermost stratum (Zone VI) due to the prevalence of large clast materials. The collected samples bracketed the geomatrix humate samples to assist in providing some resolution to the chronometric data. Due to the high overdispersion (OD) values exceeding 20%, the age of the samples was analyzed using the Central Age Model (CAM) advocated by Galbraith and Roberts (2012). Sample J01, USU-3871 at 171.2 m elevation returned a 1σ age of 6,860±650 BP with an OD value of 22+4% (Appendix F). Further down, sample J02, USU-3872 at 171.0 m elevation returned a 1σ age of 7,270±630 BP with an OD value of 24+2% (Appendix F). In sedimentary settings like 41DN624 single grain OD values between 9–20% are considered to have been well bleached during deposition (Mahan and DeWitt 2019:20). However, single grain OD values exceeding 20% may indicate the mixing of grains of various ages from post-depositional processes or the partial resetting of grains (Bateman et al. 2003, 2007). Accordingly, these samples are interpreted to have been well bleached during initial deposition but have experienced some partial post-depositional mixing. Regardless, the chronometric data for these samples were modelled with the radiocarbon assays to refine the chronometric data. Radiocarbon Analysis At 41DN624, twelve samples were analyzed to provide chronometric data for the site. Specifically, four geomatrix humate samples from Trench E between 172.53–171.63 m elevation, four geomatrix humate samples from Trench J between 171.43–170.80 m elevation, two AMS charcoal assays from Feature 3 (172.11 m) and Feature 12 (171.79 m), and two organic sediment samples from Feature 6 (171.53 m) and Feature 8 (171.38 m). Cumulatively, these assays (n=12) indicated deposits ranging between 5900–1390 BP (Table 7.4). Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 161

The overall results of the chronometric data returned a good elevational and stratigraphic correlation. Put simply, none of the assays were dramatically out of stratigraphic order regarding their elevation and age compared to the other samples.
