## Page 192

Further using the OxCal Deposition Model output, some initial calculations of sedimentation by respective stratigraphic zone were also conducted (see Figure 7.28). As with 41DN580, these preliminary sedimentation rates were conducted as a gross approximation based on the available data. Beginning in Zone V (modelled ages of ~8000–7100 cal BP), the rates of deposition from USU3872 up to the modelled boundary change at the top of Zone IV calculates an average of 3 cm per 100 years. In Zone IV (modelled ages of ~7100–4000 cal BP), the rates of deposition between the upper and lower modelled boundaries calculates an average of 1.7 cm per 100 years. The overlying Zone III (modelled ages of ~3700–2500 cal BP) and contains Feature 3 extends from the modelled boundary change of Zone III/IV to the top of Zone III and calculates an average of 7 cm per 100 years. In the upper Zone II (modelled ages of <1500 BP) calculates an average of 1.4 cm per 100 years. These rates of sedimentation would generally be designated as Slow under Ferring’s (1986:261) sedimentation categories. However, Zone III containing most of the cultural features encountered on the site (e.g., Features 3–5, 9, 10, and 12) with 7 cm per 100 years is approaching Moderate under Ferring’s (1986:261) sedimentation categories which is considered favorable for preserving isolable occupation surfaces. Span modelling was conducted on cultural features of 41DN624 to quantify the possible periods and duration of activity. The modelled span for the analyzed feature data in the Sanger deposits (i.e., Features 6 and 8) indicates a span of 0–259 years (2 σ) between 5900–5600 BP. Although limited to the dates from two features, this data may reflect a single occupation or very limited occupations during that period. For the Pilot Point and West Fork deposits, the modelled span data from the features (i.e., Features 3 and 12) indicates a span of 700–900 years (2 σ) between 3700–2700 BP. Similar to the cultural deposits observed at 41DN580, these data suggest at least two periods of activity during the Pilot Point-West Fork alloformation. The earliest, associated with Feature 12 would be between 3700–3500 BP while the latter for Feature 3 would be between 2900–2700 BP. 41DN624 Synthesis The deposits at 41DN624 are interpreted to encompass the Pilot Point and Sanger alloformations commonly encountered in the Trinity River basin of which the site is a part (Abbott 2011; Ferring 1990a, 1990b, 1991, 1992, 1994). The oldest humate date from 41DN624 (Beta-62775) returned a 2σ calibrated date of 5720–5580 BP while the modelled age of the deepest OSL sample (USU3872) returned a date of 8310–6090 BP. These data securely place the 41DN624 deposits as beginning in the Middle Holocene and extending to the present. Interestingly, the deposits at 41DN624 exhibited no clear evidence of a buried soil or any erosional disconformities to clearly demarcate the boundary between the Pilot Point and Sanger alloformations. The overall average deposition rate at 41DN624 is 2.5 cm per 100 years (see Figure 7.28). These data suggest a gradual, cumulic deposition for the site that would be categorized as a Slow sedimentation category (Ferring 1986:261; Yates and Ferring 1986:189). The overall occupations at 41DN624 as indicated by the cultural features (i.e., site furniture) appear to suggest minimally three periods of primary occupation (see Figures 7.24 and 7.27). The oldest in Zone IV (Bk2 horizon) within the Sanger alloformation there is one primary occupation indicated by Features 6–8 between ~5900– 5600 BP. Within the Pilot Point and West Fork alloformation there are likely two periods of primary Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 168

## Page 193

occupation. In Zone IV (Bk1 horizon) encompassed by Feature 12 and possibly Features 9 and 10 was between ~3700–3500 BP. The third primary occupation is indicated by Feature 3 and possibly Features 4–5 at roughly ~2900–2700 BP. 41DN580 and 41DN624 Regional Comparisons The deposits at 41DN580 and 41DN624 on Hickory Creek are interpreted to encompass most of the Holocene with cultural activity primarily occurring within the latter Sanger alloformation deposits and throughout the Pilot Point-West Fork alloformation. For context, the data from both 41DN580 and 41DN624 were compared with available data from other regional studies. For the stable carbon isotope (δ13C) and C3/C4 biomass comparisons, previous studies in the region were reviewed (Table 7.5). For more southern latitudes the Richard Beene Site in Bexar County, Hall’s Cave in Kerr County, and Owl Creek in Coryell County were examined (Mandel et al. 2007; Meier et al. 2014; Nordt et al. 2002; Waters et al. 2021). For studies closer to 41DN580 and 41DN624, Site 41TR170, 41TR198, and the Mercado Site (41TR203) in Tarrant County, Site 41DL203 in Dallas County, Site 41COL172 in Collin County, and Waxahachie Creek-1 Site (41EL246) in Ellis County were used (Frederick 2011; Hall et al. 2011; Lintz et al. 2008; Peter and Harrison 2011; Shipp et al. 2019; Short et al. 2021). Unfortunately, the comparison of regional rates of deposition was limited to only within the last 3000 years. Fortunately, there are many studies within proximity to 41DN580 and 41DN624 for comparison (Table 7.6). Specifically, the Mercado Site (41TR203) on the West Fork of the Trinity River (Frederick and McKee 2019), the Hardemann Midden Site (41DN612) on Denton Creek (Lawrence et al. 2020; Nielsen et al. 2021), site 41EL246 on the Waxahachie Creek (Frederick and Costa 2021), the Merrill Site (41DN99) on Isle du Bois Creek (Colvin 2013; Ferring and Yates 1997), and the Gemma Site (41CO150) on the Elm Fork of the Trinity River (Colvin 2013; Ferring and Yates 1997). Comparisons of 41DN580 and 41DN624 with the data from other regional investigations will be discussed in regard to alloformation period. Namely, the Sanger alloformation (~13000–4500 BP) and the Pilot Point-West Fork alloformation (~4500–300 BP). Sanger Alloformation Context Within the Sanger alloformation at 41DN580 the cultural activities most likely occurred between 5290–4960 BP while at 41DN624 the activities likely occurred between 5900–5600 BP. During this period, the stable carbon isotope (δ13C) data at these sites had values ranging from a high of -14‰ to a low of -17‰ (Table 7.5). These data suggest a mixed grassland and arboreal environment that transitioned to an increasing grassland environment through the Holocene. At the Richard Beene Site, the investigators examined the δ13C and C3/C4 biomass of buried soils and noted from 14,000–12,000 BP values of -22–25‰ suggesting an arboreal habitat (Mandel et al. 2007: Figure 3.20; Nordt et al. 2002: Figure 3). Between 12,000–7800 BP the vegetation appears to have become increasingly mixed with values of -20–21.5‰ to more grasslands from 7800–4500 BP with values of -18–20‰ (Mandel et al. 2007:Figure 3.20; Nordt et al. 2002:Figure 3). At Fort Hood in Central Texas, researchers examined a profile on Owl Creek, a tributary of the Leon River within the Brazos River basin (Meier et al. 2014). Between 14,000–12,000 BP, the researchers identified an arboreal environment with values of -24 to -26‰ that shifted to increasing C4 values of -19 to -21‰ until 9500 BP (Meier et al. 2014:162–166). From 9500 BP to the present, the environment with values of -20 to -21‰ was mixed grasslands and timber becoming increasingly arboraceous in the recent past (Meier et al. 2014:162–166). Overall, the regional δ13C studies suggest the Late Pleistocene had an arboreal environment with a steady increase of mixed arboreal and grasslands into the Holocene. Notably, Bousman (1998:210) does report that pollen stratigraphic records from several bogs and rock shelters in Texas suggest several periods of low arboreal pollen from the Late Pleistocene into the Holocene. These low percentages of arboreal pollen imply open grassland habitats at 16,500 BP, 12,500 BP, 9000 BP, 7000– 4000 BP, 1500 BP, and 800–500 BP (Bousman 1998:210). ## Page 202

Regarding 41DN580, except for the uppermost horizons at the site where erosion and dredge material are present, the deposits have excellent integrity. Similarly, except for slight disturbance at the ground surface, the deposits at 41DN624 have excellent integrity. The geoarchaeological analyses of the site matrices and chronometric data for these sites on Hickory Creek are interpreted to encompass almost the entire Holocene. Although not initially recognized during the significance test excavations, the data recovery investigations determined the site deposits at both sites contained Sanger alloformation deposits capped by Pilot Point-West Fork alloformation up to the present. While there are some recognized periods of variable rates of deposition for both sites, the overall average is a gradual, cumulic rate of deposition. The context of the encountered features and chronometric modelling at both sites suggest at least one distinct period of activity in the Middle Archaic within the latter portions of the Sanger alloformation and minimally two distinct periods of activity in the Late Prehistoric throughout the Pilot Point-West Fork alloformation. The low quantities of cultural materials at both sites surrounding an apparent prevalence of thermal features is notable. This may be attributed to the scarcity of serviceable lithic raw material in the region to produce commonly recognized cultural materials. However, the presence of the thermal features in combination with the “low visibility” of cultural debris at the sites could be attributed to natural processes. Specifically, one of Ferring’s (1986) observations was that sedimentation rates in a fluvial basin (both high and low) can affect the density of a site’s assemblage. The higher the accumulation of sediment the more isolable and separated activity areas and occupations will be. Conversely, slower rates of accumulation will trend more to sites with a palimpsest as well as hinder the preservation of organic materials (Colvin 2013; Ferring 1986). The sedimentation rates at these sites were categorized as Slow and comparable or even lower than other sites in the region with similar sized drainages. Both 41DN580 and 41DN624 match almost all the criteria for sites potentially having poor integrity outlined by Ferring (1986:263–265). Yet, the subtle vertical and horizontal separation of the encountered cultural features at these sites suggests otherwise and is paradoxical. Other sites in the region (i.e., Hardemann Midden Site) had Slow deposition, relatively poor preservation, and limited cultural materials (Nielsen et al. 2020). In contrast to 41DN580 and 41DN624, the Hardemann Midden Site did have substantial overlapping activities that mixed the cultural occupations. Therefore, the occupations at 41DN580 and 41DN624 may in fact be discrete and isolable, but within a Slow sedimentation context. Although these sites likely suffered from poor preservation of organic materials, the cultural features and materials have good integrity. Recommendations The depth and breadth of the alluvial deposits at both sites was surprising. Specifically, both sites had intact, older Holocene alluvium at a much shallower depth than anticipated. The cultural deposits within the older alluvium provided an excellent glimpse of Middle Archaic cultural activities. This period in the Holocene has been previously recognized in the region to have a comparatively lower frequency of archeological sites than the other cultural periods (e.g., Collins 2004:115; McKinney 1981; Prikryl 1990:73–74). Although the cultural materials at both sites are sparse, the cultural materials, features, and data derived from their analyses was extremely informative. ## Page 203

opportunities are assuredly available at yet unidentified sites if the exploration approach considers the possibility. Therefore, several recommendations for future investigations are proposed. Future investigations, particularly on moderate sized tributary drainage valleys in the upper reaches of the Trinity River basin, should consider the possibility of encountering early and middle Holocene deposits. In settings similar to 41DN580 and 41DN624 the older Holocene deposits may be more easily reachable compared to further downstream in the basin where they become more deeply buried. Simply put, the location of a project area and the investigative approach is recommended to be heavily considered and tailored with respect to its placement within a larger drainage system. Next, systematic chronometric sampling (when conducted) should ideally have a tight vertical resolution (~5 cm) uniform spacing for better control and data yield. Among the potential benefits will be assisting the identification between cultural and natural transformations to a site (Schiffer 1996). Additionally, rates of deposition may be calculated and compared to other studies in the region. The metrics for Ferring’s (1986) system of rates of sedimentation may need to be refined. Specifically, the threshold of Slow to Very Rapid categories may need to be adjusted (i.e., decreased) for the smaller drainages. Admittedly, Ferring (1986:261) notes that the terminology is to facilitate conversation and by extension comparison and research. This is not in dispute, but rather some thought may need to be directed towards some standardized refinements. Considering that both 41DN580 and 41DN624 did exhibit the criteria for a site with Slow deposition (e.g., poor preservation) the current system of rates of sedimentation may be appropriate. However, this system is recommended to be further tested and refined if necessary. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 179

Ayala and Katharine Pontillo Introduction & Background Some of the most difficult and useful knowledge to acquire in chipped stone analysis is how various kinds of tools were made and used. In this study, we examine the lithic material from 41DN580 and 41DN624 including tools and tool-making debris, identify the stage of manufacture, and draw on patterns of use and flake scar signatures to infer modifications on flakes for expedient tool craft. No micro-debitage was present in the examined heavy fraction from flotation samples; all recovered material was collected during excavations. The greater proportion of the lithic material represents the exhaustive curation of small, chipped stone flakes and bifacial thinning or margin trimming flakes to quickly craft opportunistic scraping, cutting, and abrading tools. The stimulus for such tools is situational with no requirement and need of extensive pre-planning. A Contemporary Review of the Uvalde Gravels Understanding the geographic position of these sites is paramount in comprehending much of the source stone material available to Prehistoric peoples and the manners in which it is leveraged. The northern prairies and cross timbers of Texas are nestled on the farthest margin of the West Gulf Coastal Plain, with a surface geology consisting of several Upper Cretaceous formations. From east to west these are the Austin Chalk, Eagle Ford, and Woodbine (Prikryl 1990). Within the soils of the cross timbers and prairies are Uvalde Gravel deposits, which date to the Miocene and originate from New Mexico. Comprising cherts, quartzites, igneous rocks, metamorphic rocks, vein quartz, and silicified wood, these gravel deposits are often considered remnants of ancient streams that no longer exist. Steve Stoutamire and Mike McBride shed light on the origins of the Uvalde Gravels in their publication in the Texas Archaeological Society Bulletin (2020). They focused on the purple Uvalde Gravel quartzites, crucial for understanding the origins of these gravel deposits. The transport of quartzites began around 16 million years ago with the erosion of New Mexico quartzites, carried eastward by braided streams as gravel-to-boulder size pieces. These were then deposited within the Ogallala Formation. Subsequently, the early erosion of the Ogallala Formation led to the redeposition of gravels into the Uvalde/Willis gravel depo centers during the Late Pliocene. Finally, during the Pleistocene, the erosion of the Ogallala Formation edges occurred, with central and lower Texas streams forming new drainage areas that cut new river valleys. As a result, today’s streams erode though Uvalde/Willis deposits, carrying material downstream to form Pleistocene/Holocene river terraces. The cherts within the Uvalde/Willis Gravels primarily come from Cretaceous Edwards Limestone, Texas Pennsylvanian and Cambrian Limestone, and the mountains of New Mexico, following similar erosional and depositional sequences and pathways as the quartzites (Stoutamire and McBride 2020). Consequently, in the field one finds well rounded chert gravels (Figure 8.1). The lithic assemblages within the Hickory Creek sites demonstrate a significant reliance on Uvalde Gravel Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 180

Key Terms Terms are often used in archeological reporting without definitions, causing a loss in meanings through a type of expected universal understanding. However, commonly understood terms and meanings may not fit the context of all studies, particular technical perspectives, or the theoretical position of all analysts. “Terminology and definitions that are adequate for one analysis are not always applicable to another” (Odell 1979:332). Consequently, the authors feel it important to be transparent about the meanings connected to terms in this report. Theoretically, much of the authors’ perspectives come from specific schools of thought and method such in Behavioral Science, Cognitive Anthropology, Symbolic Anthropology, Linguistics, the Chaîne Opératoire school of thought, and Human Behavioral Ecology. Technology – the co-emergence of cognitive and social information relating to knowledge acquisition, the performance of manufacture, the final materialized cultural product and its waste byproducts (debitage), and the manners in which such products are used in human lifeways. Thus, ancient technology (as a modern object of scientific analysis) is a keystone toward discovering the processes of manufacture and its life history in ancient socio-cultural contexts. Behavior – utilitarian, adaptive, and symbolic thought and actions to fulfill individual and social needs within a socio-cultural network. Technological Behavior – behaviors specific to meeting technological needs that can be utilitarian, adaptive, and/or symbolic needs. Importantly, knowledge acquisition and physical processes in the manufacture of technology may be symbolic in themselves. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 181

Unidirectional Modification – flake removal signatures that are a byproduct of modifications or usage that initiate and release in a single direction (multiple techniques and usage can cause this). Resultant flake scars are only present on one face of an edge or margin. Bidirectional Modification - flake removal signatures that are a byproduct of modifications or usage that initiate and release on both faces from the margin (multiple techniques and usage can cause this). Resultant flake scars are only present on both faces/sides of an edge or margin. Chipped Stone Behaviors Contextualized Hunter-gatherer life is often characterized by opportunism, leading to the creation of various functional tools from a single flake that can be utilized for numerous tasks including scraping, cutting, gouging, perforating, or shaping shafts though notching and denticulation, as well as for butchering purposes. Given that the majority of cultural material in these site investigations was hypothesized to consist of heavily curated chipped stone flakes, the primary objectives of the analysis in this study were twofold: first, to understand the techniques used in crafting the tools and creating specific types of flakes; and second, to identify the types of edge modifications performed. These modifications encompassed various techniques such as scraper retouch, abrupt retouch, invasive retouch, notches and denticulations, burinations, battering, bifacial rotary retouch, and intentional breaks (Hayden 2022). Finally, any significant chipped stone behaviors associated with the major features, primarily Feature 14 from 41DN580 and Feature 10/11 from 41DN624, are examined to either confirm or refute potential theoretical models of Middle and Late Archaic mobility patterns of North Texas. Preliminary insights into this aspect are provided based on the limited lithic evidence and site context available. Methodology All material culture relating to chipped stone behaviors underwent multiple rounds of study to extract as much behavioral information as possible within natural time constraints. While all avenues of analysis could not be pursued, we hope more in-depth use-wear analysis can be done in the future for 41DN580. Nonetheless, interpretations rely on substantive data. Each artifact underwent visual analysis, including examination under microscopes and both short-wave and long-wave ultraviolet light. We initially sorted and described artifacts based on several basic properties, beginning with notations of color, banding, quality of the crystal grain structure, subcortex color, and microfossil signatures of the chippable stone materials. The presence or absence of edge-modification was assessed. Specimens were isolated based on their morphology from manufacture and the nature of the edge modifications or lack thereof. Materials were fluoresced using an Analytikjena short- wave/long-wave ultraviolet light to confirm or negate the presence of Edwards Chert materials known to have unique orange-yellow hue signatures. We then performed high-resolution observational analysis using a Zeiss Stemi SV 6 microscope at low-to-medium power (250-500x) to identify subtle cultural modification across all tool classes. Over 500 high-resolution scans were taken at 6,900 dots per inch² (dpi), alongside microscopic photographs from the Zeiss Stemi microscope, mounted with an iPhone 11 Pro Max camera. ## Page 207

Bifaces and bifacially worked artifacts were classified according to the manufacturing stage, functional tool type, and established named types where possible. Identifications of manufacturing stage followed the TxDOT Chipped Stone Analytical Protocol (2014), which divides bifacial reduction into five categories. These five stages are: 1) initial package reduction; 2) blank preparation; 3) preform shaping and thinning; 4) final edge trimming and sharpening; and 5) rejuvenated forms. Most of the bifaces across both sites fall into stage 4 or 5. The fourth stage includes artifacts that have reached the end stage of manufacture, and often enter the archeological record due to breakage, caching, being lost or otherwise abandoned (TxDOT 2014:6). The fifth and final stage of reduction includes rejuvenated and exhausted forms that have notable edge retouching or remodeling and/or evidence of a secondary production and use trajectory in contrast to its initial form (TxDOT 2014:6). Named point typology typically followed Turner, Hester, and McReynolds (2011; also see Davis 1995). Debitage was sorted into shatter and flake subgroups, and flakes were identified as primary, secondary, or tertiary based on the amount of extant cortex. Primary flakes contain approximately 90% or more cortex on the dorsal surface; secondary flakes contain 1-90% cortex; tertiary flakes have no cortex and include interior flakes and bifacial thinning flakes. Shatter was noted when the dorsal and ventral surfaces cannot be identified on typically angular pieces with or without cortex. Material color and other notes specific to the stage of reduction or use were also recorded. Additionally, the chronology of each specimen was noted based on elevation and relative position within the site and soil profile. Tables presenting the results of all analyses are in Appendix B. Analysis – Site 41DN624 There are 63 total lithic artifacts from 41DN624: 50 modified/used flakes, 7 formal tools (points, knives, scrapers, perforators, etc.), and 3 “other” (neither flaked stone or a formal tool). All artifacts were preliminarily analyzed to identify the type (flake, tool, biface, shatter, etc.) and stage of reduction (primary, secondary, tertiary, formal tool, etc.). Fifty-eight artifacts were analyzed in more detail to include fluorescence, material sourcing, and type of use-wear. There are no primary flakes from 41DN624, and the majority of lithics (n=48) are tertiary flakes (Figure 8.2). All artifact data is presented in Appendix B; below are the results of detailed analysis of 58 artifacts. From the total assemblage at 41DN624.2 (south of Hwy 377), 91.5% of the specimens were recovered from Block B (Table 8.1). This represents 74% of the overall assemblage from the site. The area defined as Feature 10/11 (in/around units 45-55, 57, 61-64) accounts for 39 specimens, 62% of the total assemblage (Table 8.2; Appendix B). As most units were also feature-focused, the recovered lithic material is also associated with documented features. Observations, including microscopic examination and UV fluorescence of 58 artifacts showed that 45 (77.5%) is Edwards Plateau chert. Of the remaining 13 artifacts, 17% are Uvalde Chert locally and regionally sourced in Denton County. Three flakes make up the remaining 5% and are categorized as “other”: one flake is chalcedony, one is silicified sandstone, and one is a quartzite projectile point (specimen 384-01; Tables 8.3-8.4). ## Page 212

Table 8.4. Source Material Counts. Material Qty. Edwards Plateau 45 Uvalde Chert 10 Chalcedony 1 Silicified Sandstone 1 Quartzite 1 Analysis revealed that six artifacts are refurbished bifaces and/or projectile points and 56 are flakes. Almost all of the flakes are relatively small in size, ≥17 mm to ≤24 mm. They have dorsal faces with an arris that typically runs longitudinally from the platform to the distal end, a trait common in skilled bifacial thinning procedures. Most are tertiary flakes meant to shape blanks or refurbish bifaces and points. Most of these flakes had small, concentrated platforms, very flat, thin or no bulb of percussion, along with a small lip on the ventral edge of the platforms which are often the results of indirect, punch percussion. Although 56 artifacts are flakes, only 3 were unused/modified pieces of debitage. The remaining flakes have unidirectional or bidirectional flaking on one or both margins, with light to heavy use or controlled modifications through chipping and pressure techniques. Thus, the flake assemblage represents situational and expedient tasks. A significant portion of the modified/used flake material appears to have been used once, by few individuals, and possibly single individuals for single encampments. One overshot flake (271-01) exists in the assembly (Figures 8.4-8.6). A brief review of this flake type is necessary to place the specimen in a proper temporal, technological, and cultural context. Overshot flakes can be an accidental byproduct or a controlled product. Thus far, there are two well- known formal technological systems in prehistory that incorporate controlled, overshot flaking into their bifacial, lanceolate technologies: the Solutrean of southern Europe (Upper Paleolithic) and Clovis of the Americas (Upper Paleolithic) (Bradley et al. 2010; Stanford and Bradley 2012). On specimen 271- 01, flake scares on the dorsal face of the platform represent a failed attempt in strategic mass removal. The second attempt succeeded. In profile the bulb of percussion is thin and flat. Additionally, the platform is lipped. Based upon experimental work by the authors, these combined traits are most common when incorporating indirect, punch percussion techniques, and less common with direct, billet percussion. Indirect percussion can be accomplished in a multitude of ways, such as using a deer antler beam (all the tines are trimmed), a short antler tine punch (drift), or the combination of slotting a stick inside the soft interior of a large deer antler tine that incorporates a leg-assisted technique. However, through the battery of our experimental sessions using all of the above-mentioned indirect percussion techniques, leg-assisted punch percussion and antler beam punch percussion provide the best-fit techniques that produce these lipped-platforms with shallow, and thin bulbs of percussion. Other significant technological signatures and traits to assess are the flake scar patterns and signatures on the dorsal face, along with the flake’s longitudinal cross-section. The flake scar signatures are not consistent with controlled, methodical over-shot bifacial thinning. Instead, the flake scars denote early-phase, opportunistic flaking by an experienced and knowledgeable flintknapper. Thus, though controlled and skillfully removed after a single error, this overshot flake does not fit or Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 188

## Page 241

Behaviors Associated with Lithic Artifacts and Features Data recovery associated with hearth features can provide expanded opportunities for lifeway and site-function understandings. For this reason, after specimen analyses were completed, contextual data relating to features was examined for any possible, unique chipped stone behaviors. Within site 41DN624 some features have lithics and some do not. Out of a total of 13 features in the site, the significant features are 3 and 10/11. Feature 3 is a large, well-defined feature, with cooking and consumption evidence (bone, charcoal, and mussel shell). Features 10 and 11 represent an activity area that contained numerous flake tools, but the associated behaviors (scraping and cutting tasks) mirror behaviors found distant and disconnected from the features. The eight edge- modification behaviors that the analysts looked for (scraper retouch, abrupt retouch, invasive retouch, notches and denticulations, burinations, battering, bifacial rotary retouch, and intentional breaks) revealed what appears to be very short-term, rarely repeated, expedient scraping and cutting tasks, two of the eight possible edge-modification behaviors. On a macro level, a total of 63 lithic pieces were present at the site, 40 of these were recovered from Features 10 and 11 (Table 8.5). All specimens from Feature 10/11 were modified/utilized, while within the overall site assemblage, 89% of all flakes are utilized. Nonetheless, the overall assemblage is small. Due to such a small assemblage and the nature of their use and modifications, the interpretation is that these features likely represent single events. Complimenting this, the chipped stone material around each feature likely represents the archeological capture of single, momentary stays of individuals performing few, functional tasks before moving on. In terms of the nature of these brief stops along Hickory Creek, the scant evidence of biface and dart point manufacture, the refurbishing of points and knives, along with the numerical degree of flake tools and the nature of their modifications, the ancient, brief stays appear to involve animal and plant processing, along with an aquatic food focus. ## Page 242

Analysis – Site 41DN580 There were 136 total artifacts recovered from site 41DN580: 65 modified/used flakes, 8 tools (points, knives, bifacial tools, scrapers, etc.), and 63 “other” (unused flakes, shatter, etc.). Of the 136 lithics, 74 artifacts were analyzed in more detail (all angular pieces and shatter were excluded). Appendix B presents the results of all analyses. From the total assemblage, all lithic artifacts were recovered from the most northern sections of the site; none were found in Trench D. These include 12 bifacial tools or points, and 121 flakes; the majority are tertiary flakes (n=82), followed by secondary (n=27), and few primary flakes (n=13) (see Figures 8.41-8.42). In particular, 77% of the assemblage (n=105) came from units in the Late Prehistoric period component outside the margins of Block E (Table 8.6). ## Page 243

Figure 8.41. Examples of primary flakes from 41DN580. Figure 8.42. Examples of secondary and tertiary flakes from 41DN580. Fluorescence of 74 artifacts showed that 58% of the materials (n=43) are a variety of chert from Uvalde Gravels. Of the remaining artifacts, 32.4% (n=24) are from the Edwards Plateau, 9.5% are categorized as “other”. In the “other” category, microscopic analysis identified three flakes of silicified sandstone and one of Ogallala quartzite. The silicified sandstone and quartzite are locally sourced in Denton County. Site 41DN580 had more artifacts recovered from deeper, Middle Archaic components Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 219

Specimen 258-01 is a Colbert or Hayes arrow point that was attempted on poor quality chert from an unknown source (Figures 8.62-8.63). There is barb loss and heavy stacking on the margin from unsuccessful pressure work. The lateral edges of this point are recurved. The existing barb is wide but the stem is not typically straight like a Colbert arrow point. The stem of this arrow point appears to have more of a diamond shape which is common with Hayes arrow points. Specimen 424- 01 is a Kent dart point made on chert from an unknown source (Figures 8.64-8.65). The body is asymmetrical and there is only one defined shoulder which is weak. This is a poorly made dart point on poor quality material. Specimen 338-01 is a small adze or a scraper (Figures 8.66-8.68), manufactured on Edwards Plateau chert. One margin is heavily beveled through intentional modification of a flintknapper. The other has evidence of use-wear. This tool might have been used for multiple functions. Specimen 232-01 (Figure 8.69) is a fragment of a biface or projectile point that was manufactured on chert that is of an unknown source. ## Page 264

material is novaculite from the Arkansas/Oklahoma region of the United States. This spall does have polish along the margin where the cutting edge is present. Specimen 170-01 (Figures 8.70-8.71) is an Alba arrow point manufactured on poor quality chert from an unknown source. This point is triangular in shape, although the distal end has been snapped off. The lateral margins are slightly concave. It has shoulders and a stem that are parallel. Specimen 301-01 (Figures 8.72-8.73) is a snapped distal end of a biface or projectile point. Manufactured on chert from an unknown source, the basal edge has been refurbished and thinned down. The body is triangular and on one face there are finishing pressure flakes in lateral pattern. There is a pot lid on one face of this tool indicating it was exposed to high heat. Specimen 304-04 (Figures 8.73-8.75) is likely a small preform for a Fresno arrow point. The body is triangular and small in size. Both faces have chevron patterned finishing flakes that extend down the body of the point. The basal edge is not ground and has a platform still present, leaving the point unfinished. This point was manufactured on chert from an unknown source. Specimen 207-12 (Figures 8.76-8.77) is a longer, prismatic flake that has characteristics similar to a burin spall. There are two platforms on both distal and proximal ends. This tool has one edge that has been modified and heavily used. There is a lateral flake on one face that was removed in the opposite direction of the spall on the ventral face. All three edges have evidence of use-wear. This tool was manufactured on chert of an unknown source. Specimen 31-01 (Figures 8.78-8.79) is a scraper that was manufactured on Edwards Plateau chert. One margin is modified and heavily beveled. The working edge has evidence of heavy use. Specimen 10-01 (Figures 8.80-8.81) is a refurbished specimen that fits morphologically in the ranges of either a Marshall or a Bell point fragment. The flake scars are more aligned with Marshall dart point thinning and notching techniques. The distal snap occurred from high force-loads, possibly an impact fracture. Such examples highlight the challenges in classificatory work. Some refurbished dart points, when they are greatly reduced, are quite similar in dimensions, leaving only the flaking technology to reveal their temporal and cultural root. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 240

Behaviors Associated with Lithic Artifacts and Features Out of all the features in 41DN580, Feature 14 (the Late Prehistoric component) is the most significant, contributing 105 pieces (71%) to the total lithic assemblage (Tables 8.10-8.11). Originally recorded as a feature during investigations, continuing excavations revealed Feature 14 is a cultural component dated to Late Prehistoric. Of the 58 Late Prehistoric specimens with an identified material source, 14 are Edwards Plateau chert, and 38 are on Uvalde chert. When we break out these categories further, all 14 of the Edwards chert specimens are flakes, 11 tertiary and 3 secondary; there are no primary flakes, bifaces, or formal tools made from Edwards chert in the Late Prehistoric site component. All points and bifaces, as well as at least 32 flakes (7 heat-treated), from this component are made of Uvalde Gravel chert. This data indicates that Edwards chert tools and materials were present at the site, were reduced to produce expedient flake tools, and further suggests the bulk of Edwards material was heavily curated and reused, leaving only the few utilized flakes behind. The activities represented by the used flakes in this component (Feature 14) are like 41DN624, except for the considerable amount of polish signatures on flakes. It is uncertain what specific activity is the cause of the polishing, though the current hypothesis is that the kind of light, reflective, and fluid-like appearance on some edges is the result of frictional heat and the spreading of plant opal. Further analysis and experiments would be required to affirm or disaffirm this hypothesis. Overall, the flake tools and significant amounts of polish on flake margins suggests a wider array of flake tool tasks than the task signatures on flakes connected to the primary features in 41DN624. Additionally, while Uvalde Chert is the primary source of material for Late Prehistoric period lithics, 14 pieces (13.7%) are identified as Edwards Chert. The primary type of Edwards Chert in Feature 14 is the Georgetown variety, a light-medium gray, fine-grain chert. This fits Prikryl’s (1990) explanations of source-stone use and selectivity over time. Prikryl (1990:83) argued that Late Prehistoric societies favored quality cherts instead of improving local medium-to-poor quality cherts Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 260

Below, we discuss implications of the patterns and observations made above, including the types of behaviors indicated by the lithic assemblage, what the abundance of certain materials and tool types at each site indicates, and presents possible interpretations for why so much of the 41DN580 assemblage is present in the Late Prehistoric component (Feature 14). Climatic and ecological data could provide valuable insights into the nature of short-term encampments along Hickory Creek during the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. While some climatological data present conflicting views, much of our current understandings come from studies conducted in the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s (Baker and Penteado-Orellana 1977; Bond 1966; Bryant 1977a, 1977b; Bryant and Shafer 1977; Holloway et al. 1985). It seems evident that significant ecological transitions to more arid conditions occurred during the onset of the Middle Archaic, and again during the Late Prehistoric period. These transitions influenced human behaviors, including the utilization of flaked stone, and how localities were leveraged during climactic and ecological changes. Humans are highly adaptable, adjusting their tools and behaviors to suit changing environmental conditions. Notably, these climactic conditions align with periods of population growth and the increased presence of plant processing tools and features (Brownlow et al. 1999). We see this reflected in the types of stone tools and the use-wear on them, as well as the increasingly localized material procurement practices which suggest decreasing mobility patterns over time (e.g., Lintz et al. 2008; Tinsley and Dayton 2011; Todd 2014; alternately, see Prikryl 1990). ## Page 286

While we cannot specifically correlate this lithic data with broad climactic patterns noted above, it is worth noting that similar resource processing activities were taking place at both sites and across long periods of time. With additional localized and fine-grained environmental data, this could be used to explore more specific human-environment interactions and potentially get at issues of seasonality across time. To better understand the types of use-wear documented at 41DN580 and 41DN624, four individuals modified 37 experimentally produced flakes on silicified sandstone, chalcedony, and chert. They performed two timed episodes of scraping on juniper and oak wood, as well as mussel shell. Time was determined in the number of scrapings, where ‘light use’ equals two scrapes, and ‘moderate use’ equals twenty scrapes. The two woods constitute soft and hard material, oak being much harder than juniper. The experiment was implemented to seek possible distinct use-wear and polish signatures on the stone sources, analogous to the Hickory Creek site materials. Overall, the study revealed that use-wear signatures rarely occur with two scrapes on soft or hard wood, or mussel. Thus, it is important to consider this when interpreting degrees of use-wear on lithic tools. Another crucial aspect to consider regarding the Hickory Creek sites is the procurement and processing of lithic material from locational and behavioral perspectives. The Hickory Creek locality boasts an abundance of Ogallala quartzite and Uvalde gravels. However, when comparing the assemblages of both sites across different periods, the evidence suggests there is a difference in choice and material use between the Archaic and Late Prehistoric site components. Data shows that Archaic period people favored higher quality Edwards Chert over nearby Uvalde Gravel chert varieties, while the Late Prehistoric component comprises primarily Uvalde chert. This shift may be influenced by factors such as group alliances, mobility, trade, social forces, or individual choice that may have hindered the investment in improving local chert stone through thermal alteration. Further investigations in this region of Texas are therefore crucial for understanding patterns in life-way behaviors during the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. At 41DN580, evidence suggests cutting and scraping activities were common, and the high polish on many specimens and across time periods (Archaic and Late Prehistoric) suggests significant plant processing was a focus of the site’s many occupants. This polish is present most frequently on tertiary flakes but is also present on at least two bifaces and several secondary flakes. Unlike 41DN624, this type of use-wear is seen across all material types, but still suggests a reliance on expedient flake tools for many activities. Edwards chert debitage at 41DN580 is most numerous from 174.4-174.6 m amsl (n=14), at the top of the Late Prehistoric site component. In the Archaic assemblage, while there is a slight decrease in the number of Edwards lithics they make up a much higher proportion of the assemblage (n=10, 38.5%). However, the overall assemblage for the earlier Archaic components is much smaller (n=28), which could have an impact on the diversity of materials present. There is no geological cause recognized that accounts for differential distribution of chert types, which is best explained by material source choice. These patterns show that local Uvalde Gravel cherts were more common in the Late Prehistoric, while earlier deposits are marked by the favor and reliance on Edwards chert. One notable datapoint is the presence of novaculite among the source stone specimens in both the Middle Archaic and Late Prehistoric assemblages at 41DN580. Novaculite, which has appeared in Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 262

## Page 288

flakes as opposed to formal tools could suggest that high-quality materials and tools were highly curated and therefore taken when people moved on from the site leaving behind only exhausted and expedient tools. Another behavioral component meriting review is the fracture and refurbishment signatures on projectile point technologies (see Appendix B). Refurbishing on projectile points in both sites across time periods is extensive and heavy, some points are completely exhausted. Additionally, the manner of reduction on some specimens may indicate a dual purpose. First, the use of points as a possible source of flakes for flake tools. This may be particularly true for the few or absent Edwards tools but the notable count of Edwards flakes, especially at site 41DN624. Second, projectile points indicate breakage with no associative evidence of new manufacturing, such as primary and secondary flake debitage. Freshly made dart and arrow points are not present in these assemblages. Discards from different time periods without associated manufacturing suggests that favored manufacturing areas were elsewhere, and the Hickory Creek sites functioned as short-term staging areas. Again, this gives the overall impression that high-quality lithic materials from more distant sources were heavily curated across occupations, while locally available cherts were primarily used during the Late Prehistoric habitation of 41DN580 for both expedient flake tools and to make small bifaces. Human behaviors across time at the Hickory Creek sites show a consistent use of short-term camps from the Late Archaic through the Late Prehistoric periods. These camps, often accommodating only a few people or single individuals passing through, demonstrate a reliance on tool kit usage and stone tool craft for expedient tasks, not specialized hafted knife or projectile weaponry. Instead, significant manufacturing is not archeologically visible at these sites, suggesting a highly mobile strategy involving transportable clutches of thinning flakes. Conclusion Some of the most difficult and useful knowledge to acquire in chipped stone analysis is how various kinds of tools were manufactured and used by their makers, and what their presence in the archeological context can say regarding chronologies and technological behaviors. Sites 41DN624 and 41DN580 contain Middle Archaic to Late Prehistoric cultural components with fire cracked rock, mussel shells, and bone, with low densities of chipped stone material. Evidence for Middle Archaic occupation is meager and difficult to leverage for any significant insight. The greater proportion of the lithic material represents the exhaustive curation of small, chipped stone flakes, the intentional modification of spalls, and bifacial thinning or margin trimming flakes to quickly craft opportunistic scraping, cutting and abrading tools. Many of the Transitional period flake tools also have polish related to vegetal processing. All the flake tools for both sites suggest a mobility strategy for traveling with a clutch of usable thinning flakes for flake tools. A much smaller proportion of the lithic material at both sites involves the refurbishing and modification of projectile weaponry and knives (arrow and dart points), which require a greater investment to complete. Feature data aids the view that the Hickory Creek locality was an established short-stop locality. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 264

## Page 292

One of the sherds from 41DN580 has parallel brushing marks on the vessel exterior surface (Figure 9.3). These marks, made with swathes of grass bundles dragged across the wet vessel surface, would have run vertically from near the vessel rim to the vessel base. Such decorated vessels are present in other Late Prehistoric shell-tempered ceramic assemblages in the Southern Plains, including Henrietta phase sites such as Harrell (Perttula 2016) and Henderson (41CY6) (Perttula 2020). We may dub these Nocona Brushed, and suspect they were first made after ca. AD 1200-1250. Summary of the Assemblage The ceramic vessel sherd assemblage from 41DN580 is comprised of a small sample of sherds from a few plain shell- tempered Nocona Plain jars with flat bases. These jars have been fired and cooled predominantly in a reducing or low oxygen environment, occasionally smoothed on their exterior surface, and were made with thick vessel walls. These are sturdy cooking jars. One of these jar sherds is from a Nocona Brushed vessel. Finally, three calibrated radiocarbon dates have been Figure 9.3. Parallel brushed shell- obtained on the deposits from 41DN580 with the shell- tempered body sherd, TU 40, Feature 14, 20-30 cm bd, Lot 207. tempered ceramics, providing data on the likely age of the assemblage. At two sigma, the highest probabilities are AD 1221-1282, 1156-1262, and AD 1120-1222. These dates overlap in the early 13th century, suggesting the Nocona Plain and Nocona Brushed ceramics represent an early Late Prehistoric use of the site as well as the early manufacture of shell-tempered ceramics in this part of the Southern Plains. Radiocarbon Dates from Sites on the Little Elm Fork of the Trinity at Lake Lewisville with Shell-Tempered Ceramics Shell-tempered ceramics are a common feature of Late Prehistoric, Henrietta phase, sites at Lake Lewisville (Brown and Lebo 1991; Ferring and Yates 1998), especially at sites such as 41DN27 and 41DN372. There are a few radiocarbon dates (n=7) on these Henrietta phase sites and ceramics, but they are younger than the shell-tempered component at 41DN580. Using Version 8.2 of Calib.org (accessed September 11, 2022), the Lake Lewisville sites have age ranges on shell-tempered ceramics that range from AD 1212-1421 (with a median probability of AD 1307) to AD 1290-1496 (with a median probability of AD 1405). The shell-tempered Nocona Plain and Nocona Brushed sherds from 41DN580 are apparently at least three or more generations older than the shell-tempered assemblages at the sites at Lake Lewisville. Haliburton Identification and Analysis All bones analyzed for this study were identified through use of the Center for Archaeological Studies (CAS) Vertebrate Comparative Collection at Texas State University, the analyst’s private faunal collection, use of loan specimens from the University of Tennessee’s Department of Anthropology’s Vertebrate Comparative Skeletal Collection, and assorted identification manuals and articles (Cohen and Serjeantson 1996; Cox McLain Environmental Consultants 2019; France 2009; Jacobson 2004; Olsen 1964, 1968, 1972; Schmidly and Bradley 2016; Romer 1997; Peterson 1988; Nagorsen 2002), as well as various online virtual osteological databases (Idaho Virtual Museum 2020; The University of Michigan Museum of Zooarchaeology n.d.; The University of North Texas Digital Library 2011a, 2011b, 2011c, 2011d, 2011e, 2011f). Taxonomic classification follows Sisson et al. (1975), Hillson (1996), and Adams and Crabtree (2012) for mammals, Olsen (1968) for reptiles and amphibians, Peterson (1988) for birds, and Page and Burr (1991) for fish. All identification and analysis were conducted by James O. Ramsey, M.A., under the supervision of Dr. Jodi Jacobson. All bone was identified to the most specific taxonomic level possible. When diagnostic characteristics were not as variable, for example presence of a character which had been noted as defining only 65 percent of the time in a species, identifications to species were listed as “compares favorably” or “c.f.” For example, in the case above a species determination would have been listed as c.f. Odocoileus virginianus. In addition, given the location and temporal association of the site, some identifications where characteristics to differentiate between them and a similar North American species were absent, taxonomic designation may have determined based on known and assumed distributions. Invertebrate remains were analyzed separately (see Chapter 11), although there were a few specimens that appeared in the faunal assemblage analyzed by CAS. Invertebrate remains were identified through use of limited material in the analysts’ private faunal collection and identification manuals and online resources such as Georgia Biodiversity Portal (2020), Elm Fork Natural Heritage Museum (2021), Parmalee and Bogan (1998), Cox McLain Environmental Consultants (2019), The University of North Texas Digital Library (2011a, 2011b, 2011c, 2011d, 2011e, 2011f), The University of Michigan Museum of Zoology (n.d.), NatureServe (2021), and Leal (2020). All invertebrates were identified to the most specific taxonomic level possible. Many marine bivalves were identified to the order; however, some were identified to genus and species. Like the bone, when characteristics precluded identifying to species the identification was listed as “compares favorably” or “c.f.”. Any animal bone not discernible to class based on fragmentation to a degree enough that the bone could be consistent with multiple classes and was indiscernible to a specific class was left at the greater level of phylum vertebrata. An example of this is thin fragments of cortical bone not equally consistent with bird, amphibian, or fish, so designation would be left at the broader but accurate level of vertebrata. As not all animal bones were identifiable beyond class, size categories were used to Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 270

## Page 295

differentiate the various bones for analytical purposes. Size categories by class or other taxonomic level are useful for understanding human subsistence strategies and prey choice preference (high biomass versus low biomass) within an environment. Size categories may also give an indication of an environment’s overall species richness (Lawton 1990). The size categories for mammals included large (e.g., bison, elk, black bear), medium-large (e.g., deer, pronghorn antelope), medium (e.g., coyote, dog, raccoon, bobcat), small-medium (e.g., opossum, beaver, skunk), small (e.g., rabbit, squirrel), very small mammal (e.g., wood rat, hispid cotton rat, vole), and microtine mammal (e.g. mouse, shrew). Size categories for birds included large (e.g., swan, great blue heron), medium-large (e.g., goose, turkey), medium (e.g., mallard duck, caracara, red-tailed hawk), small (e.g. dove, grackle, screech owl), and very small (e.g., golden-cheeked warbler, finch, bluebird). Size categories for reptiles included medium (e.g., rat snakes, river cooter, re-eared slider), small (e.g., racers, box turtle, musk turtle), and very small (e.g., gecko, earth snake). Artiodactyla bones not identifiable to species were subdivided into large (e.g., bison, cow, elk), medium-large (e.g., white-tailed deer, mule deer, pronghorn antelope) and medium or larger (any artiodactyl such as bison or deer of a size larger than a sheep or goat). Enough specimens were classifiable to the family Muridae (rats, mice, and voles), but not to species that subcategories of very small Muridae (e.g., cotton rats, wood rats, prairie vole) and microtine Muridae (e.g., plains harvest mouse, Texas mouse, northern pygmy mouse) were included. Bones not identifiable beyond the level of class and/or identifiable to order or family but with taxa within those that vary in size so can still benefit from additional information refining to animal body size to aid in differentiating possible taxa represented. For instance, within the order Carnivora there are many shared characteristics on bones which may make differentiation to more specific taxa difficult with fragmentary bone given shared characteristics, but where could have a wide range of animals within that order including taxa greater in size such as bear, mountain lion or wolf, or medium-sized taxa such as coyote or bobcat, small-medium fox, skunk, or raccoon, or small weasel or mink. The ability to differentiate whether a larger predator animal may have been present (mountain lion or wolf) versus a relatively smaller carnivore more typical for scavenging (raccoon or weasel) can provide interpretive value. In addition, while positive identification to a specific size of taxa, for example small mammal, may not always be possible with fragmentary bone due to inter and intra- species variation, changes in body size through development and aging, shifts in animal taxa sizes over time with different climatic variables, hybridization, and sexual dimorphism of any given taxa, broader grouping ranges, e.g., small/small-medium and medium-large/large, medium or larger, can still provide interpretive value on human subsistence strategies and whether relying primarily on overall larger taxa (sheep/goat size and larger) or if more dependence needed to be placed on smaller taxa such as rabbits, squirrels, etc. For example, a juvenile bison's long bone diaphysis can be comparable size-wise to a large adult deer and, without epiphyseal evidence, cannot be separated further from fragmentary samples. While broad, it provides information on the environment, tool adaptations, and subsistence strategies that may have been needed based on what was available when hunting (Jacobson 2023; Outram 1998, 1999, 2001). In addition to taxonomic and elemental identifications, data including the portion of element present; degree of fusion; age or sex of animal indicators; cultural modifications to the bone (cuts, Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 271

Breakage and Completeness Bone is a unique material in that it contains two major components: an inorganic component (primarily hydroxyapatite) that contributes to its rigidity and an organic component (primarily Type I collagen) that permits some degree of elasticity. After an organism’s death, the organic component gradually decomposes, ultimately changing the biomechanical properties of the bone. Consequently, the form of bone fractures in “fresh” bone (i.e., that with higher amounts of collagen) often appear very different from fractures to more “dry” bone (i.e., where the majority of collagen has decomposed) (Lyman 1994). In addition to distinguishing between fresh and dry breaks, fresh fracture types can be further divided into spiral and other green breaks (e.g., oblique fractures). Spiral fractures are often the result of percussion impacts and are generally considered to be indicative of intentional cultural breakage. Other green breaks may be produced by alternative taphonomic agents, such as carnivore gnawing. Carnivore gnawing can occasionally produce spiral Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 276

## Page 303

Brown discoloration indicates short-term and lower heat burning, such as exposure to a grass fire or campfire for less than six minutes (Lyman 1994). Blackened bone has been carbonized and would indicate prolonged exposure to a grass fire or campfire. Grey and white bone has been fully calcined which means that it has lost all organic matter and become plastically deformed. Combined, gray and calcined bone make up 68.3% (n=179) of thermally altered bone. These bones’ prolonged exposure to heat could be due to a couple of different mechanisms of burning, including the disposal of food waste and fuel for anthropogenic fires, among others (Lyman 1994). A large amount of the calcined, gray, and blackened mammal bone was from medium or larger sized mammals (n=28, 51.9.0%) (Table 10.7). Of the calcined, gray, and blackened mammal bone (n=54), 7 bones (13.0%) exhibited a fresh break of some type. The large amount and frequency of thermal modification present on medium and larger mammal bones combined with the high rates of comminution suggest that intensive bone processing was occurring. Typically, burning and comminution are linked with processing for bone grease extraction and disposal of fragments either within the fire or with ember remains of the fire (Jacobson in press), but the high degree and frequency of calcination requires a more intensive examination as it is not as consistent with that interpretation. The skeletal frequency analysis of burn bone and which elements and taxa were identifiable is also not as typical of a bone grease processing cause. All of the burned bone (n=262, 100% of the burned vertebrate bone) was recovered from units associated with Feature 14, the Late Prehistoric site component. Burned turtle shell fragments are present within the site (Tables 10.8-10.9; Figure 10.5). The high amount of burned turtle shell (n=40, 66.7% of the turtle assemblage from 41DN580) suggests that their remains are primarily the result of food consumption or a byproduct during food preparation (roasting). For thermally modified turtle carapace fragments, the majority of specimens were calcined or gray. The opposite is true for thermally modified turtle plastrons where most specimens were discolored black or brown. Since a relatively large amount of turtle carapace fragments were unburned, it is also possible that they were used as tools (bowl or ladle) for cooking, or for creating rattles, or other cultural use in addition to being consumed. In addition, one turtle carapace specimen was recorded as exhibiting black discoloration on the exterior and brown discoloration on the interior. The rest of burned turtle shell fragments were consistent colors on both sides of the specimen. Given the degree of alteration for the carapace and plastron, one interpretation would be that the “bowl” of the turtle was placed directly in the fire and subjected to direct heat for whole turtle roasting or as an expedient container for cooking and the plastron as a “lid” or top that was exposed to high enough indirect heat and smoke for charring in most cases, though enough heat for calcination in others. Cut marks were identified on a deer (Odocoileus sp.) metapodial on the caudal surface of the condyles. Cut marks in this area are suggestive of skinning the hide during the initial processing of the carcass. Cut marks were also identified on an American beaver (Castor canadensis) femur on the lateral side of the major trochanter and along the diaphysis. Several cut marks were also identified on a small/small-medium mammal long bone. The same beaver femur also exhibited several chop marks on the minor trochanter. The cut marks on the major trochanter and chop marks on the minor trochanter are likely associated with severing the iliofemoral ligament connecting the femur to the pelvis to disarticulate the femur. The cut marks along the diaphysis are likely the result of removing the meat from the bone. A single percussion mark was identified on an artiodactyl long bone. Percussion marks are created when a fresh bone is struck with a stone or other heavy object and is typically done to break open the bone to access the medullary cavity for marrow, to break bone down the bone in preparation for rendering bone grease, or during processing to crush joints and separate carcass portions. A higher degree of percussion impacts would be anticipated if bone processing for marrow or bone grease were occurring at the site. The overall low frequency of butchering marks could be a result of the high comminution and thermal alteration of the bone. Identification is more difficult on smaller fragments and cut marks would create weak points where bones are more likely to fracture while being heated or, if broken, obscuring the cuts. All bone exhibiting butchering modification were recorded from Units 41 and 67, which are adjacent to one another and associated with the Late Prehistoric site component. All burned bone was also recovered from this component. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 282

The scale rankings weathering from 0 to 5, where 0 represents a bone with some flesh still attached and 5 would be a disintegrating bone with large splinters. Typically, all archeological material would be minimally assigned a 2 or 3 ranking. Usually, bone assigned a ranking of 5 was exposed to sun and the elements for a prolonged time prior to burial, whereas bones with a ranking of 2 or 3 would have been buried at or shortly after discard. Weathering on bone from 41DN580 is summarized in Figure 10.7. The highest-ranking weathering stage was stage 3 which included 42.8% (n=213) of the bones. Eleven bones (2.2%) were assigned a weathering stage of less than 3 and 274 bones (55.0%) were assigned a weathering stage of greater than 3. Overall, 487 bones (97.8%) were assigned a weathering stage of 3 or greater. This pattern of weathering is consistent with expectations for thermally modified bone since the crystalline structure of carbonized or calcined bone has already been altered and partially mineralized; weathering affects the same crystalline structure and is therefore limited by the change that has already occurred (Steiner et al. 1995). Burned bone tends to survive better than unburnt or only slightly thermally modified bone (Mays 1998). Boiling, however, causes accelerated deterioration of bone (Roberts et al. 2002). These results support burning as a primary cause of the high amount of fragmentation. Carnivore and Rodent Modification Potential signs of carnivore modification include gnaw marks and scoring/pitting, puncture marks from the canines, scrapes from incisors, and the polish, striations, and angled but abraded edges consistent with scatological or other digestive erosion. Carnivore modifications differ from rodent modifications in the size of the gnaw marks, scoring, punctures, whereas rodent modifications are often smaller and narrow, occur sporadically, and often in sets of two (see Figure 10.12). Gnaw marks resemble cut marks but are often shallower and narrower, rounded out, and sometimes have an initial indention from incisors where the mark began (Haynes 1983). Carnivore modification was identified on 110 bones (22.1% of the vertebrate assemblage) from 41DN580 (Tables 10.13-10.14). No elements were identified exhibiting rodent modification. The proportion of bone recovered from 41DN580 exhibiting carnivore modification (22.1% of the vertebrate assemblage) is relatively consistent with other sites that have been argued to contain evidence of domesticated dogs. Morey and Klippel (1991) documented a high degree of carnivore modified deer bone at a site in East Tennessee, the Hayes Site (40ML139), a Middle Archaic Shell Midden site with a presence of dog burials. Greater than 25 percent of the deer bone at the site had evidence of carnivore modification. At the Jayroe Site (41HM51) in Hamilton County, Texas, over 26% of the bone had evidence for carnivore modification (Jacobson et al. 2019). The majority of bone exhibiting carnivore modification (n=93, 84.5%) was recovered from the concentration of units associated with Feature 14/the Late Prehistoric component. Additionally, although not recorded as a feature during the excavation, 16 bones (14.5%) were recovered from three adjacent units from a block of 12 units in the central portion of Block F. One bone (0.9%) was recovered from Unit 85 which is located between Blocks E and F and dates to the Late Prehistoric period. Although the entire extent of the site is not known, and only a small section was excavated within the Hickory Creek Interceptor easement, the large amount of bone with carnivore modification recovered from the Late Prehistoric component (n=93, 84.5%) indicates carnivores were able to easily access the site. This could indicate that the carnivore modification was the result of human-canid interaction and potential provisioning of domesticated dogs (Jacobson and Ramsey 2022). Moreover, since 14.5% of the carnivore modified bone was recovered from a concentration of units in Block F not associated with any features, this could suggest that carnivore scavenging also occurred. Further refining site use and spatial distribution of human activities would be required to determine what proportions of the site the carnivore modified bones are associated with and whether Block F represents the periphery of the site or an arbitrary boundary. Environment When possible, taxa were classified by habitat use (Figure 10.14). Only 5 specimens were able to be assigned to specific habitats. Recorded habitats include woodlands/riparian, scrub brush, and aquatic. Woodland/riparian species identified in the faunal assemblage include white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus, n=1). Scrub brush species identified in the assemblage include c.f. mule deer (O. hemionus, n=1). Aquatic species identified in the assemblage include American beaver (Castor canadensis, n=2), box turtle (Terrapene sp., n=3), indeterminate turtle (Testudines, n=57), and freshwater mussel (Unionidae, n=1). Although the geographic range of western box turtle (T. ornata), a non- aquatic turtle, overlaps the site, all turtle remains were assumed to be aquatic given the higher prevalence of aquatic turtle species present in the area. The mussel shells identified in the field during excavation of the site were not included in the present analysis. Since mussel shells were recorded as making up 93% of all cultural material, aquatic habitats would be the most highly represented (Boudreaux et al. 2022a). Given the inability to identify much of the assemblage to species given the comminution of bone, it is likely terrestrial species are under-represented and the percent would be slightly higher if the mammal bone identifiable to size of taxa alone was identifiable further. 70 60 50 40 P S IN 30 20 10 0 Woodland/Riparian Scrub Brush Aquatic Figure 10.14. Breakdown of bone NISP by species habitat use. Seasonality Although the seasonal use of a site can often be reconstructed based on a variety of indicators including seasons of death, the presence of hibernating or migrating species, or elements with seasonal growth patterns (i.e., fish otoliths, mussel shell, some teeth), the only indicator identified in the 41DN580 assemblage was the presence of hibernating species. All of the identified reptile specimens were turtle (n=60, 12.0% of the vertebrate assemblage), which hibernate at temperatures below 38-45 degrees Fahrenheit (Roots 2006), which indicates the site was used during warmer seasons (see Figure 10.5). In Denton County, modern averages indicate that the temperature does not drop below 45 degrees Fahrenheit from mid-March to mid-November (Weather Spark 2022) which suggests a spring, summer, and/or fall occupation of the site. Furthermore, as many amphibians and aquatic reptiles will estivate during times of drought, typically their presence suggests wetter season and absence would Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 290

The overall low frequency of butchering marks could be a result of the high comminution and thermal alteration of the bone. Of the carnivore modified bone, 93 bones (84.5%) were recovered from the Late Prehistoric component (Table 10.20). To better assess the issue of cultural versus natural breakage, degree of completeness was assessed based on taxa size (Table 10.29). Of the bone able to be assigned to degree of completeness (n=70), 68 bones (97.1%) were less than 5% complete. Of the remaining bone, 1 bone (1.4%) was 85-to- 100 percent complete and 1 bone (1.4%) was whole. Of note, the only whole bone identified in the 41DN624 assemblage was a deer (Odocoileus sp.) calcaneus which was actually two rejoining fragments with a dry break. The one bone assigned a degree of completeness of 5 was a deer central and 4th tarsal that exhibited slight fragmentation along the caudal surface. Given that the smaller taxa exhibit similarly low levels of completeness as larger taxa, the fragmentation of the site is likely primarily the result of natural taphonomic factors rather than intentional human modification. ## Page 323

domesticated dog. While archaeological evidence for domesticated dog in Texas is sparse, there are ethnographic (Hammond and Agapito 1940; Swanton 1942; Winship 1896), aDNA (Tito et al. 2011), and rock art evidence for domesticated dog in Texas dated to as early as 9,200 calBP at Hinds Cave in Val Verde County, Texas (Tito et al. 2011). Morey and Klippel (1991) documented a high degree of carnivore modified deer bone at a site in East Tennessee, the Hayes Site (40ML139), a Middle Archaic Shell Midden site with a presence of dog burials. Greater than 25% of the deer bone at the site had evidence of carnivore modification. In addition, they conducted actualistic studies feeding deer bone to a large domestic dog. They both picked up abandoned remains and retrieved bone from scat. They also found that the dog was able to efficiently fully consume softer spongy bone such as the pelves and the epiphyses of long bones, but shafts were frequently left behind. While not fed vertebrae, the vertebrae of deer and bison is similar in texture as the pelvis and as a bone with minimal bone grease return may have been discarded once meat had been successfully removed. The high degree of carnivore modification at other sites in Texas in conjunction with canid bone indicating an integrated use has been used to strongly suggest the presence of domesticated dogs. At the Jayroe Site (41HM51) in Hamilton County, Texas, over 26% of the bone had evidence for carnivore modification. In addition, there was a modified bone tool, which had canid gnaw marks on it, overlain by charring of the bone suggesting a cultural use, canid modification, cultural use sequence of events (Jacobson 2023; Jacobson et al. 2019). That finding was boosted by a Canid metapodial bone larger than a coyote but smaller than standard wolf and in keeping with known domesticated dog breeds utilized by Native Americans at contact. Similar findings of highly canid gnawed bone from within feature context at Smith Rockshelter (41TV42) in McKinney Falls inspired additional aDNA investigations, yet bone tested was either not adequate for results or inconclusive given close relationship and many shared DNA markers between coyote and domesticated dog (Jacobson and Ramsey 2022). Given the high degree of carnivore modification associated with this site, especially in Feature contexts, similar to suspected and/or confirmed domesticated dog presence elsewhere in Texas, considerations for whether material was scavenged by wild canids coming in after a short-term site was abandoned versus domesticated dog provisioning should be considered. ## Page 325

Features Thirteen features were identified at 41DN624, described in detail in Chapter 6. Faunal material was recovered from Features 3, 4, 5, 9, 10, and 11. Feature 3 is a circular earth oven. Feature 4 is a loosely defined concentration of burned limestone rocks interpreted as a hearth remnant. Large amounts of mussel shell were identified in the units immediately surrounding Feature 4. Feature 5 is a small, isolated concentration of tabular burned sandstone. Feature 9 is a large FCR concentration with a scatter extending outward another meter around the main concentration. Features 10 and 11 were immediately adjacent to one another and are loose concentrations of burned rock with a notable quantity of bone, mussel shell, and lithic material (Boudreaux et al. 2022b). Given their proximity to one another, Features 10 and 11 may represent a single activity area and are therefore discussed as a single feature (Feature 10/11) in the faunal analysis. Species Frequency A total of 195 specimens (99.0% of the 41DN624 assemblage) were recovered from or were closely associated with features. All faunal material recovered from feature contexts exhibited a very low level of identifiability with only 3 specimens (1.5%) identifiable beyond taxonomic Class (Table 10.34). These remains include a deer (Odocoileus sp.) calcaneus and tarsal and an artiodactyl metapodial fragment, all of which were recovered from Feature 3. Table 10.34. ## Page 329

Conclusion and Comparison The assemblages from 41DN580 and 41DN624 both exhibited relatively low rates of intentional butchering and breakage. 41DN580 contained a relatively high amount of burned bone. The butchering modification recorded from 41DN580 is consistent with activities such as disarticulating, defleshing, but is very minimal. Very little of the bone recovered from 41DN624 exhibits intentional breakage or thermal modification and none exhibits evidence of butchering such as cut, chop, or percussion marks. Given the extremely high rates of carnivore modification present at site 41DN624, it is possible that much of the evidence for intentional modification was obscured or destroyed, or that some of the bone does not have actual cultural association. Although intentional modification recorded from 41DN624 is low, Feature 9 contains most of the thermally modified bone and all of the fresh broken bone recovered from the site. A small amount of thermally modified bone was also recovered from Feature 10/11. Given the lack of other modification and the overall small sample size, it is difficult to interpret the use of the features and whether the bones were being processed, disposed of, or used as a fuel source. Both sites exhibit high rates of carnivore modification; however, 41DN624 exhibits extremely high rates of carnivore modification, totaling 57.4% identified in Features 3, 9, and 10/11 at 41DN624. Furthermore, 96.6% (n=56) of the bone recovered from Feature 10/11 exhibited carnivore modification. Overall, 22.1% of the bone recovered from 41DN580 exhibited carnivore modification and was recorded in Feature 14 and the Block F concentration. Carnivore modified bone was recovered from across 41DN580 while at 41DN624 it was associated with features. It is possible that the carnivore activity represents provisioning domesticated dogs; however, since the site appears to have been utilized for a relatively short period of time and wild carnivores may have scavenged the site after it was abandoned, no definitive assessment of the presence of domesticated dogs can be made. The absence of dog bone at a short-duration occupation site does not limit their presence if they were living as companions and help-mates to humans, especially at a short-term occupation site. Since both sites’ assemblages contain large amounts of mussel shell, it is possible that the primary functions of these sites were processing and cooking mussel shells with animal remains serving as a caloric supplement. For 41DN624, since there is very little evidence of intentional human modification of animal remains, the human inhabitants of the site may have been processing and consuming a larger amount of mussels than terrestrial animals. For 41DN580, humans were likely consuming a much higher amount of animal remains although still collecting and processing a large amount of mussels as well. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 305
