I F A 41DN580 NVERTEBRATE AUNAL NALYSIS OF 41DN624 AND By Lori Phillips, with discussion by Victoria Ingalls and Rachel Feit This chapter presents a description of the freshwater shellfish remains recovered during the archeological excavation of sites 41DN580 and 41DN624. Identification includes taxonomy, element, side, natural modifications, and cultural modifications. Taxonomic identification to the genus or species level was attempted when possible, but the majority of the invertebrate assemblage could only be identified to Unionidae or unidentifiable mollusc (e.g., Figures 11.1-11.2). When diagnostic features were obscured or difficult to distinguish, specimens were identified as “c.f.” meaning they compared favorably to a species. If a specimen could not be determined beyond genus, they were identified as “spp.”. When preservation permitted, taxonomic identification was aided by a comparative collection on loan from the Environmental Department of Freese and Nichols and virtual databases such as the Mussels of Texas (2023). Data is presented using two quantitative units, NISP (number of identified specimens) and MNI (minimum number of individuals) (Lyman 2008). MNI was calculated by the presence of non-repetitive elements that were identified to the genus or species level, in this case the umbo and/or psuedocardinal teeth of the left or right valve. NISP includes both identified and unidentified specimens, i.e., unidentifiable molluscs and those identified to the Family or more specific level. Figure 11.1. Figure 11.2. Mussel shell fragments with umbos, 41DL580 Unit 10 Level 2. Site 41DN580 A total of 2,851 invertebrate remains were analyzed from site 41DN580 (Table 11.1). The majority of the assemblage is composed of Unionidae, with Rabdotus and fossilized Exogyra comprising the remainder. The fossil Exogyra were not likely utilized by human inhabitants of the site, do not show signs of human modification, and likely represent natural deposition during bedrock formation so will not be discussed further. The Rabdotus specimens are all less than 5 cm in maximum length and do not show signs of cultural modifications or use. Over 90% of the assemblage could not be identified beyond Unionidae due to a high fragmentation rate and a lack of preserved identifiable features. Of the identifiable specimens, six genera were identified with Toxolasma texasiense (Texas lilliput) and Amblema plicata (Threeridge) the two most abundant bivalve species (Table 11.2; Figure 11.3). All identified species can be found in nearshore or main-channel environments with slow to moderate currents and are found in the area today, with one exception (Mussels of Texas 2023). Plectomerus dombeyanus (Bankclimber) is no longer found in modern streams in the area but has been documented in other north Texas archeological assemblages (Randklev and Wolverton 2011; Randklev et al. 2010). Five of the six identified genera, all burned shell, and the majority of modified shell come from this feature as well. Conversely, 75% of all Toxolasma species from 41DN580 come from Feature 18, a Middle Archaic mussel deposit. These shells do not show any signs of modifications or thermal alterations and may represent a discrete consumption or discarding event focused on Texas lilliput. Temporal changes within the site cannot be investigated due to large differences in sample sizes across the site, with the Late Prehistoric component being overrepresented compared to the earlier Middle to Late Archaic deposits. In zooarchaeological assemblages, species richness increases with larger sample sizes (Lyman 2008), therefore the higher taxonomic richness of the Late Prehistoric component is more likely driven by the much larger sample size than any real change in subsistence strategy or environmental changes compared to the much smaller Middle Archaic assemblage. Figure 11.4. Representative sample of thermally altered shell. Cultural modifications include cut edges and edge use-wear that may indicate shell usage as tools (Table 11.5). Edgewear was noted on Amblema plicata and one Toxolasma texasiense and found almost exclusively within Feature 14. Edgewear on these specimens are characterized by smoothed edges with vertical striations running ventral to dorsal. Many of these specimens also have small grooves along the margins as seen in Figure 11.5. While these specimens do not retain beveling similar to experimental and archeological shell scrapers (e.g., Dockall and Dockall 1996; Eyles 2004; Harris et al. 2015), it is possible a similar activity resulted in these striations and they may have functioned as expedient tools with a short use life. Additionally, two specimens had characteristics of cut and smoothed edges (Figure 11.5). No other modifications were noted on these specimens and their use is unknown. Table 11.5. Comparison The invertebrate assemblages from 41DN580 and 41DN624 are both highly fragmentary with low species identifiability. However, inhabitants of both sites were likely utilizing the same environments for freshwater shellfish procurement as indicated by the similarity in species documented at both sites. Amblema plicata, Lampsilis teres, and Toxolasma texasiense are present at both sites and are typically found within nearshore habitats with slow to moderate currents. Amblema plicata’s habitat ranges from the Lower Nueces River drainage to the Sabine and Red Rivers and can be found in a variety of aquatic habitats but most often within the banks and backwaters rivers with mud or sand substrates with still to moderate currents. Lampsilis teres have a wide distribution ranging from the Rio Grande to the Sabine and Red River drainages. Like Amblema, this species often inhabits streams or rivers with mud or sand substrates and slow to moderate currents. Lastly, Toxolasma texasiense has the same habitat range as Lampsilis and prefer the same slow to moderate currents of rivers (Mussels of Texas 2023). This also suggests these were important species through time being utilized in the Middle Archaic at 41DN624 and the Late Prehistoric at 41DN580. Thermal modifications are seen at both sites and likely indicate cooking and/or discard practices, though this is much more apparent at 41DN580 than 41DN624. Edgewear and cut shell pieces indicate some shell remains were utilized beyond subsistence and were possibly used as tools, such as scrapers. Several of the Feature 14 shells were burned suggesting mussels were collected and eaten in the camp. More significantly, there are 32 modified freshwater mussel shell specimens from this component. Modifications include scraping, polishing, cut edges, battering, and notching. These modified shells can be grouped in three primary categories: battered, cut and smoothed, and notched. Specimens with cut edges often have at least one other type of modification such as battering, polishing, nicking, and notching (Table 11.10). Most modifications are made on threeridge and bankclimber shells—in other words, the larger species. Of note is the absence of drill holes on any shells in the assemblage. Data from other sites show that small drill holes are most common on shell pendants and adornments, while larger holes occur on shells that were hafted and used as hammers, hoes, and adzes. Battered shells were likely broken open expediently, initially for food but also to be used later, possibly as digging implements or as adzes. There are six examples of large shells with battering and heavy use wear (Figure 11.7). On these large, thick shells, battering is primarily along one edge and side, conforming to typical expectations for hoes or adzes. However, unlike presumed hoes/adzes known from other sites, the 41DN580 examples do not have a hole that would allow them to be hafted, nor are there other indications that these were hafted another way. Additionally, there is not the type of polish or retouching expected if these were being used as adzes in woodworking. Although speculative, one possibility is that these were opportunistic tools used to dig up plant bulbs and tubers that were likely growing along the creek and floodplain, then discarded after use. Two specimens (Figure 11.7b and 11.7e) are fragmentary and it is possible that these pieces represent tool-making debris as opposed to an intentional tool. In the case of the fragmentary example from Lot 202, a small nick and groove are evident across the dorsal face extending from a battered edge of the shell to its outer margin (Figure 11.7e). A common means for cutting shell was the groove and snap method, whereby a groove would be sawn into the shell using a sharp tool, then snapped to form a clean break (Kozuck 2007). Of the cut shells, there are five shaped examples shown in Figure 11.11 that are distinct from the other modified shells in the assemblage. These five specimens show that cut edges were smoothed. However, none have the type of edge use-wear that would suggest they were used as tools. Comparable examples from the Harrell Site have been described as pendant blanks (Dial and Black 2002). Another thought is that the specimens with pointed tips (Figure 11.11a, b and e) were used as awls or gouges. The notched shells all have other modifications that include snapped edges, evidence of scraping or grinding, and likely represent a diversity of possible activities. Because of the variation in size and tasks these could represent, we hesitate to make a single interpretation of their use. For instance, the unprovenienced specimen labeled Collection 2 (Figure 11.12b) has been snapped, notched, smoothed, and polished. It also exhibits a groove along its dorsal beak suggestive of a tool still in the process of manufacture. Nonetheless, because of the comparability across sites with lithic tools, we suggest the tools with notches may have similar uses to ‘spokeshaves’, lithic tools used for cutting or scraping wood, edges of leather, sinew, or bone (Davis 1995). These typically have similar notches that exhibit various degrees of wear based on the material types they were used to process. Comparison with other Sites in Texas and Beyond The archeological record in North America and globally shows that people modified shells for both adornment and utilitarian tasks, especially in settings when other durable material resources such as lithic material were scarce (Cuenca-Solana et al. 2011; Schmidt et al. 2001). Shell tools can be made of marine or freshwater varieties, although in coastal environments marine shell is preferred because it is typically less susceptible to fragmentation. However, in parts of North America, freshwater shells are used as opportunistic tools, often for short or defined tasks because of their higher friability but ubiquity along perennial waterways (Cuenca-Solana et al. 2011; Dockall and Dockall 1996). It is well documented that Indigenous peoples across the Americas, particularly in coastal regioms, fashioned shells as personal adornments, including pendants, gorgets, earrings, hair ornaments, musical instruments, clothing accessories, and even engraved shell cups (Dockall and Dockall 1996; Dreiss 2024). Indigenous peoples also fashioned shells into tools. Shell tools were used for any number of tasks, including processing animals, plants, minerals and pigments, or as scoops, hoes, awls, net-weights, scrapers, adzes, polishers, or ceramic rib tools (e.g., Cuenca-Solana et al. 2011; Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 321

## Page 346

Lidour and Cuenca-Solana 2023). They were sturdy and easily worked, and since coastal regions where shell tools are most ubiquitous often lack good quality lithic raw materials, precontact peoples took full advantage of molluscan resources. Activities that required shell tools can often be identified through both macro- and microscopic use-wear analysis. Broadly, experimental studies show that, like lithic tools, micro-chipping flaking along edges and polish are typically seen when the tools were used repetitively on softer, organic materials, while irregular breakage, step fractures, grinding, and jagged splintering or delamination is caused by activities that require battering and heavy impacts. Worldwide, the most common use of shells is for scraping (Cuenca-Solana et al. 2011). This is typically evidenced by modification of one edge of a lateral margin on the inferior portion of the valve (Schmidt et al. 2001). Although scrapers can be hafted, they are most often hand-held tools. Similarly, hoes and adzes typically exhibit wear along one edge, although these wear marks are more dramatic and evidence the types of battering expected from heavy use. Additionally, hoes and adzes are often shaped and/or have drilled or pecked holes used for hafting and attachment to a handle/shaft (Dockall and Dockall 1996; Lamb 2011; Lidour and Cuenca-Solana 2023). In other regions of inland North America, shell ornaments and tools (both freshwater and imported marine shells) similar to the assemblage at 41DN580 are present at Mississippian period sites of the Midwest along major drainages. Examples have been found at sites in the Missouri, Mississippi, and Illinois River basins, for instance (Lamb 2011; McLeester 2019). In Texas, modified shells and shell tools occur most commonly in the coastal region (Figure 11.13), which exhibit the greatest variety of tool and adornment types on marine and freshwater mollusks (e.g., Black 1978; Ricklis 1995, 1996; Story 1968). Coastal sites with significant shell assemblages frequently include cemeteries (e.g., 41LK28, 41GV66, 41VT1). For example, the Mitchell Ridge site (41GV66) on Galveston Island was a seasonal camp site and burial ground occupied from approximately 1300 BP until the mid-eighteenth century (Ricklis and Black 2009). None of the shell items at the site were identified as tools but as personal adorments. Similarly, Morhiss Mound (41VT1) has an Archaic period cemetery where archeologists recovered more than 3,300 shell artifacts (Dockall and Dockall 1996). Among these were over 200 tools that include whelk shell hammers and adzes, as well as assorted cutting and scraping tools manufactured from marine and freshwater bivalves (Dockall and Black 2007). Most relevant to this study are notched and unifacially retouched bivalve cutting tools similar to stone tool forms. The whelk shell hammers exhibit use wear in the form of battering and polish from use. Beveled shell axes exhibit wear and fracture patterns suggestive of hafted wood working tools, like chipped stone Guadalupe and Clear Fork tools (Dockall and Black 2007). Remarkably, similar shell implements are documented not just in Late Prehistoric contexts, but at numerous Archaic period coastal sites including those along Oso Creek, which empties into the Nueces Bay system near Corpus Christi. The morphology of these shell tools indicates the use of direct percussion and cutting to create usable segments for tools and ornaments. Cutting was accomplished by tabular sandstone abraders and the groove and snap technique was used to segment shell into pieces. Other coastal sites with a significant number of modified shells include the Kent-Crane Site (41AS2), Blue Bayou (41VT94), Buckeye Knoll (41VT98), Live Oak (41AS3), Crestmont (41WH39), Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 322

## Page 347

Ferguson (41FB32), Ernest Witte (41AU36), and 41NU114, among others (Dockall and Dockall 1996; Feit and Goldstein 2019; Ricklis and Black 2009). Outside the coastal plain of Texas, shell ornaments and adornments on marine shell are often found in mortuary contexts only on Caddo sites and Late Prehistoric period sites, suggesting that marine shells were traded long distances between Indigenous groups starting around AD 1000. A few examples include items found at the Eli Moores Site (41BW2) in Bowie County, the Womack (41LR1) and Sanders (41LR2) sites in Lamar County, Olmos Dam (41BX1), in Bexar County, and the AC Saunders site (41AN19) in Anderson County. Tools made on freshwater shells are significantly rarer as one moves inland from the coast. There are scattered examples of freshwater shell tools in inland portions of Texas, although many of these are one-off examples and are only briefly mentioned in reports. For instance, a small number of shell tools were documented at site 41LK67 in the Choke Canyon Reservoir area of deep south Texas. Authors reported five intentionally modified specimens with snapped and/or smoothed edges from a Late Prehistoric component, but there is no discussion of their use (Brown et al. 1982:94-95). Notched freshwater mussel shell specimens were also reported by Shafer at 41CK76 and 41CK70 along the upper Colorado River basin (discussed in Dockall and Dockall 1996). However, outside of mortuary contexts and coastal contexts, the use of shells as tools, particularly freshwater mussels, seems to be rare and is not well documented. To some extent, this may be a problem with identification and reporting. Modifications on freshwater mussel shells may not always be recognized, and when they are, good documentation and analysis is often lacking. To date, there has been no attempt to systematically study the types of modifications on freshwater mussel shells or map their occurrence outside the coastal plain in Texas. Within Texas, the best comparison for freshwater mussel shell tool use occurs at the Harrell site (41YN1) in north Texas on the Clear Fork of the Brazos River in Young County, west of the City of Denton and sites 41DN580 and 41DL624. The Harrell site has a long history of occupation from roughly 5000 BP through the Late Prehistoric, likely after AD 1200 (Dial and Black 2002; Krieger 1946). Similar to 41DN580, Harrell had significant and repeated Archaic period occupations represented by scattered hearths and burned rock features suggesting repeated but likely short-term use. Importantly, the Harrell site’s similarities with 41DN580 also extend into the Late Prehistoric period, with comparable artifact and ceramic assemblages (Dial and Black 2002; Krieger 1946). During the Late Prehistoric II period from roughly AD 1200-1500, early Plains Villager groups made farming implements from deer and bison bone, antler, and less frequently shell. While only a few partial bison scapula hoes are present at the Harrell site, there are 33 mussel shells with heavy use-wear and battering along their edges, suggesting they may have been used as digging implements instead (Dial and Black 2002; Krieger 1946). Several of these also have pecked holes indicating they were hafted. Dial and Black postulate that bone hoes are rare at the site due to the availability of large, thick mussel shells to serve that purpose. In addition to the utilitarian implements, beads and other cut and perforated mussel shells from the site were probably worn as pendants and adornments. Some mussel shell pieces were oval disks cut from the flat sections of larger shells. These pieces may have been unfinished blanks for pendants or tools in the making. Summary To summarize, shells are a common feature of archeological sites across Texas. As a food source, both saltwater coastal varieties and inland freshwater mussels and clams were consumed by ancestral peoples throughout the world. Outside of consumption, native peoples along the Gulf Coast and coastal plains often converted saltwater marine shells into tools, personal ornaments, ritual objects, and as offerings for the honored dead. Evidence for use and trade of shell ornaments found in mortuary contexts is particularly well-documented throughout Texas regions. Broadly, shell tools are more common in areas where shells are abundant but lithic materials scarce, and also seem to replace bone tools in some situations. However, far less common is evidence for locally produced mussel shell tools at inland sites, particularly those in central and north-central Texas. For this reason, the worked shell assemblage at 41DN580 is rare. At Hickory Creek 41DN580, freshwater mussels available in the nearby creek were heated and consumed for food, used as expedient tools, and possibly for personal ornamentation, which correlates to a small body of evidence in Texas. On a functional level, the cut and smoothed edges of Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 324

some 41DN580 specimens may compare favorably to those interpreted from other sites to be pendant blanks, ornaments, or awls. Striations, nicking, evidence of battering, and notching on the Hickory Creek specimens may represent use-wear from digging or possibly scraping. Due to the absence of evidence for hafting, we think it is less likely these were chopping and woodworking tools such as adzes. While some shells could have been used as knives and cutting implements, the types of wear and modifications seen in the Hickory Creek assemblage do not align with expectations for those types of tools. Rather, most tools seem to have been employed for digging, cutting, scraping and smoothing. The idea that the 41DN580 shell tools were mostly expedient and used in place of bone or stone tools seems to align with other evidence of site/component function. Site 41DN580 appears to have been a short-term, repeated use campsite for most of its history, even during the Late Prehistoric component period. There is no other evidence for Late Prehistoric permanent structures, horticulture, or long-term occupation (see Chapter 16), despite a wide variety of artifact types not often seen at comparable sites (e.g., ceramics, shell tools, bone tools). Regional interactions and the place of 41DN580’s Late Prehistoric component are discussed further in Chapters 15 and 16 of this report. Regarding the shell artifacts of the Late Prehistoric component, there is scarce direct evidence (apart from the Harrell site) for the utilization of freshwater mussel and clam shells in the north Texas archeological record, and as such these artifacts represent an important research theme. The presence of modified mollusk remains at site 41DN580 broadens our understanding of the use and importance of freshwater mussel shells as tools by precontact groups. ## Page 351

Setting The two sites are located along Hickory Creek in central Denton County, Texas, in the Trinity River drainage, with site 41DN580 approximately one kilometer upstream (northwest) of site 41DN624. The area lies in the Grand Prairie section of the Cross Timbers region (Level III/IV Ecoregion 29d) where precontact vegetation was mixed grass prairie in the upland areas. Common grasses include big bluestem (Andropogon gerardii), yellow Indiangrass (Sorghastrum nutans), little bluestem (Schizachyrium scoparium), hairy grama (Bouteloua hirsuta), sideoats grama (Bouteloua curtipendula), Texas wintergrass (Nasella leucotricha), and Texas cupgrass (Eriochloa sericea) (Griffith et al. 2007). Honey mesquite (Prosopis glandulosa) and junipers (Juniperus spp.) are common in the uplands today but would have been less prevalent in the past (Griffith et al. 2007), when fires and a lack of fences confined trees mostly to riparian zones and river valleys. Mesquite would have been absent until perhaps 1,000 years ago. Common riparian trees would have included elms (Ulmus spp.), hackberies (Celtis spp.), green ash (Fraxinus pennsylvanica), bur oak (Quercus macrocarpa), Shumard oak (Q. shumardii), pecan and other hickories (Carya spp.), roughleaf dogwood (Cornus drummondii), soapberry (Sapindus saponaria), and American beautyberry (Callicarpa americana) (Bezanson 2000:115). Floodplains also support useful vines such as grapes (Vitis spp.) and Virginia creeper (Parthenocissus quinquefolia). Plants with edible bulbs such as camas (Camassia spp.) and wild onions and garlic (Allium spp.) grow on the banks. Oxbows, sloughs, marshes, and other wetlands associated with Denton Creek would have offered plant resources such as cattail (Typha spp.) and aquatic tubers or rhizomes including arrowhead (Sagittaria spp.) and spatterdock (Nuphar lutea) (Bezanson 2000:115-116; Diggs et al. 1999:45-48; Gould 1962). Mean annual precipitation in Denton County during the period 1951-1980 was 33.5 inches (851 mm). Precipitation has a bimodal distribution with modest peaks in May and September. The frost- free season averages 226 days and runs from March 27 through November 8 (NFIC 1987:465-466). Examination of the paleosol from which features were excavated at site 41DN580 indicates Middle Archaic conditions in the area were wetter than present (THC Site Form 1/25/22). The mix of upland grasses may have included more Indiangrass and perhaps also eastern gamagrass (Tripsacum dactyloides), which is currently at the western edge of its range in Denton County (Kartesz 2015). Riparian trees and other plants would have been better able to colonize terraces and uplands, and wetland areas with their attendant resources would have been more common than in recent times. Methods Macrobotanical and carbon samples were examined under a Leica S9i stereoscopic microscope at 6.1-55 X. Carbonized botanical material larger than about 1.0 mm was separated from soil, and plant parts were identified to the lowest possible taxonomic level by comparison to materials in the Macrobotanical Analysis comparative collection and through the use of standard reference works (e.g., Core et al. 1979; Hoadley 1990; InsideWood 2004; Panshin and de Zeeuw 1980; Wheeler 2011). Plant nomenclature follows the PLANTS Database (USDA, NRCS 2022). After identification, specimens were counted, labeled, recorded, and weighed on an Ohaus Scout II 200 x 0.01 g electronic balance. To retain suitability for radiocarbon dating, samples were placed on freshly washed Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 327


---

## Page 352

glassware when not in specimen containers, and they were handled only with rubber finger cots and metal forceps. Flotation samples were processed at Acacia. Heavy fractions were examined for carbonized botanical material at Acacia and sent to Macrobotanical Analysis where they were combined with the light fractions. Samples were sorted according to standard procedures in the Macrobotanical Analysis laboratory (Pearsall 2015). Each flotation light fraction was weighed on an Ohaus Scout II 200 x 0.01 g electronic balance before being size-sorted through a stack of graduated geologic mesh. All carbonized botanical materials that did not pass through the No. 10 mesh (2.00 mm square openings) were sorted under a Leica S9i stereozoom microscope at 6.1-55 X, then counted, weighed, recorded, and labeled. Gastropod fragments, soil particles, and uncarbonized botanical material larger than 2 mm (usually rootlets) were weighed, recorded, and labeled. Materials that fell through the 2 mm mesh were examined under a stereoscopic microscope at 6.1-55 X magnification. Due to the scarcity of carbonized botanical remains in these samples, any material that did not fall through the No. 25 mesh (0.71 mm square openings) was removed from residue, as were larger particles that did fall through that mesh size. Uncarbonized macrobotanical remains other than rootlets (seeds, juniper needles) were recorded on a presence/absence basis on laboratory forms. Wood charcoal identification was attempted for any specimen large enough to be picked up and snapped for a clean transverse section while wearing finger cots. Wood charcoal fragments were snapped to reveal a transverse section and examined under a stereoscopic microscope at 6.1-55 X magnification. When necessary, tangential or radial sections were examined for ray seriation, presence of spiral thickenings, types and sizes of intervessel pitting, and other characteristics. Botanical materials were identified to the lowest possible taxonomic level by comparison to materials in the Macrobotanical Analysis comparative collection and through the use of standard reference works (e.g., Core et al. 1979; Davis 1993; Hoadley 1990; InsideWood 2004; Martin and Barkley 1961; Musil 1963; Panshin and de Zeeuw 1980; Wheeler 2011). Plant nomenclature follows that of the PLANTS Database (USDA, NRCS 2022). Results Macrobotanical Samples Nine macrobotanical and carbon samples from site 41DN580 contained identifiable wood charcoal (Tables 12.2-12.3). The sample from Unit 64 Level 3 (Lot 301) consisted of a single specimen of ash wood charcoal (Fraxinus sp.) with approximately seven growth rings (Figure 12.1). The sample from Unit 68 Level 5 (Lot 304) contained a fragment of black walnut nutshell (Juglans nigra; Figure 12.2) and a fragment of walnut wood charcoal (Juglans sp.) with approximately two growth rings. Black walnuts are a potential food source for site inhabitants. The woods from carbon samples consisted of ash (Fraxinus sp.), elm (Ulmus sp.), black walnut (Juglans nigra), and a fragment belonging to the hickory/walnut family (Juglandaceae) that may be either walnut or pecan (Table 12.3). Examples of the wood charcoal recovered are shown in Figures 12.3-12.5. Ash, elm, and walnut trees are likely to have grown in the riparian area along Hickory Creek in Middle Archaic times. Flotation Samples Site 41NDN580 Twenty-one flotation samples were examined from 41DN580, seven from feature contexts (Features 5, 7, 8, 11, 17, and 18), four from units, and ten from Soil Column 2 (Table 12.4). Uncarbonized seeds and leaves are interpreted as modern, as conditions on the site are not conducive to the long-term preservation of botanical material (Lopinot and Brussell 1982; Miksicek 1987). In addition, the uncarbonized seeds represent weedy species expected in the soil seed bank near Hickory Creek (Keepax 1977). An uncarbonized pine wood fragment likely came from an archeological screen. Archeological plant remains in the flotation samples from site 41DN580 were sparse. The group of samples analyzed in 2022 had only 0.07 g of material sufficiently heavy to register on the scale. The calculated density of archeological plant remains for the 2022 samples is thus 0.0015 g per liter, nearly all of which comes from wood charcoal in Feature 5. Some of this wood charcoal could be provisionally identified as dewberry cane (Rubus sp.). The remainder of the wood charcoal in this and other features was identifiable only as hardwood. Wood charcoal from a typical sample is shown in Figure 12.6. Fragments of chenpod seeds (Chenopodium sp.), apparently carbonized, were recovered from three levels of a soil column taken from Units 1 and 10, near Features 3 and 4. Chenopod seeds are edible, as are the greens. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 332

Of the flotation samples processed in 2024, only three samples from site 41DN580 produced any carbonized plant materials at all: Features 11 and 18 and the 90-100 cm level of Column 2. Many plant fragments could be recognized as wood charcoal, but their small size prevented identification. An indicator of size is provided by the 14 wood charcoal fragments from Feature 18 that together weigh less than 0.01 g. Plant material recovered is consistent with the previous 2022 investigations. Site 41DN624 Eight flotation samples were examined from site 41DN624, all from feature context (Features 2, 3, 9, and 12) (Table 12.5). Uncarbonized plant remains from this site are interpreted modern due to the preservation conditions (poor) and the weedy nature of the uncarbonized seeds recovered (Keepax 1977; Lopinot and Brussell 1982; Miksicek 1987). Archeological plant remains consisted of wood charcoal, carbonized bark, and indeterminable carbonized botanical fragments. Most of the indeterminable fragments are likely pith from the interior of woody stems. Wood charcoal from a typical sample is shown in Figure 12.7. One category of carbonized plant remains, indeterminable fragments from Feature 3 Lot 78, was heavy enough to register on the scale. The calculated archeological plant density is thus 0.0005 g/l. Even though actual plant density is higher, the calculated density is still only about two percent of the density of archeological plant remains in the Hardeman Midden in southwestern Denton County (0.022 g/l), where wood charcoal and nutshell were recovered from burned rock features along with wild onion and camas bulb fragments (Bush 2020). Fragment size in the Feature 12 samples was also large enough to permit identification of thirteen wood charcoal fragments to the oak genus (Quercus) (Figure 12.8). Oaks would likely have been common in the site area during Middle Archaic times. Figure 121.7. No edible plant parts were recovered, although the presence of oak wood, presumably for fuel, implies the seasonal presence of acorn nuts. Summary Archeological plant remains at Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 were sparse and consisted primarily of wood charcoal. Ash, elm, and walnut wood charcoal were identified at site 41DN580. The two fragments of wood charcoal from macrobotanical samples at site 41DN580 were large enough to identify as ash and walnut, both expected trees for the riparian area along Hickory Creek. Black walnut nutshell and chenopod seed fragments indicate two potential food plants for inhabitants of site 41DN580, and the presence of burned dewberry cane suggests a possible third plant food item. If the dewberry cane reflects dewberry consumption, documented plant food resources for the site are walnuts, dewberry, and chenopod. Interestingly, all three plants are not available at the same time of year. Dewberry today ripens in mid-May to June but is no longer available by the time black walnuts ripen in late September or October (USDA, NRCS 2024). Chenopod plants flower April through September (Diggs et al. 1999), so their edible greens and early seeds are available during dewberry Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 338

P , P , S A OLLEN HYTOLITH AND TARCH NALYSIS FOR S 41DN580 ITE Linda Scott Cummings, PaleoResearch Institute Site 41DN580, a buried multicomponent site located on Hickory Creek in Denton, Texas, contains evidence of occupation from the middle Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. Four sediment samples collected from two of these periods were submitted for pollen, phytolith, and starch analysis. Methods Pollen and Starch Sediments often present unique challenges for pollen preservation and recovery, meaning that larger samples are required for land sediments than for pollen recovery from lake sediments or peat bogs. A chemical extraction technique based on flotation is the standard preparation technique used in this laboratory for recovering pollen grains from sediments. This particular process was developed for extracting pollen from soils where the ratio of pollen to inorganic material is relatively low. It is important to recognize that it is not the repetition of specific and individual steps in the laboratory, but rather mastery of the concepts of extraction and how the desired result is best achieved, given different sediment matrices, that results in successful recovery of pollen for analysis. Our pollen extraction method retains starch granules when they are present. Starch granules are a plant's mechanism for storing carbohydrates. Starches occur in numerous seeds, as well as in starchy roots and tubers. The primary categories of starches include the following: with or without visible hila, hilum centric or eccentric, hila patterns (dot, cracked, elongated), and shape of starch (angular, ellipse, circular, or lenticular). Some of these starch categories are typical of specific plants, while others are more common and tend to occur in many different types of plants. Hydrochloric acid (10%) was used to remove calcium carbonates in the sediment samples, after which they were screened through 250-micron mesh. Multiple water rinses, employing Stoke’s Law for settling time, were completed to return the sample to a neutral pH. A small quantity of sodium hexametaphosphate was used to suspend clay-sized particles prior to additional rinsing using Stoke’s Law. Finally, the samples were freeze-dried under vacuum. Once dry, the samples were mixed with sodium polytungstate (SPT), at a specific gravity of 1.8 g/ml, and centrifuged to separate the organic material including pollen and starch, which floats, from the inorganic remains and silica, which do not float. The light fraction was recovered and the process was repeated, as many times as necessary. This pollen-rich organic fraction was rinsed, and samples received a 25-minute treatment in hot hydrofluoric acid to remove remaining inorganic particles. The samples were acetylated for 10 minutes to remove extraneous organic matter. Samples were rinsed with RODI water to neutral. Due to the presence of large quantities of minute organic debris, the samples were centrifuged at high speeds for short intervals to remove this debris. Following this, a few drops of potassium hydroxide (KOH) were added to each sample, which was then stained lightly with safranin. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 340

## Page 365

A light microscope was used to count pollen at a magnification of 500x. Pollen preservation in these samples varied from good to poor. An extensive comparative reference housed at PaleoResearch Institute aided pollen identification to the family, genus, and species level, where possible. Phytolith and Starch Extraction from Sediment Extraction to recover both phytoliths and starch grains from the sediment samples is based primarily on our heavy liquid technique for pollen extraction. First, 15 ml of sediment from each sample was placed in a beaker with an oxidant such as bleach, then allowed to sit overnight. The next day the beakers containing samples were filled with water and allowed to settle by gravity (using Stokes Law) for one and one-half hours, after which the supernatant was poured off. This rinse was repeated four times to remove the bleach or oxidizing agent. The next step in organic removal was to introduce a small quantity of dilute potassium hydroxide (KOH), which was not allowed to sit long because it may damage the silica bodies. Additional rinses removed dissolved organics. Clays were removed using sodium hexametaphosphate and a repetition of the Stokes law settling. The samples then were freeze-dried using a vacuum system, then mixed with sodium polytungstate (SPT, density 2.1 g/ml) and centrifuged to separate the phytolith and starch grain fraction, which will float, from most of the inorganic silica fraction, which will not. The light fraction of each sample was retained and rinsed to remove the heavy liquid. The phytolith- and starch-rich fraction of each sample was rinsed in alcohol to remove any remaining water. Microscope slides were made by putting a drop of sample on a slide, allowing it to dry, then mixing with optical immersion oil prior to covering with a cover slip for counting with a light microscope at a magnification of 500x. A percentage and/or frequency diagram was produced using Tilia 2.0 and TGView 2.1.1. Results and Discussion Site 41DN580 exhibited evidence of at least three primary periods of occupations representing the Middle Archaic and Late Prehistoric. Samples were collected from the Middle Archaic component that represent a mussel shell feature (F. 18) and an FCR feature (F. 19) (Table 13.1). Middle Archaic component features are generally small, widely scattered clusters of fire-cracked rocks interpreted as hearths. Mussel shell fragments were abundant leading to the interpretation that the Middle Archaic features represent short-term or single use occupations by seasonally mobile groups who returned to this area over millennia, perhaps about 3000 years, to collect aquatic resources from the creek and occasionally process hunted terrestrial remains. Feature 18 is a discrete cluster of complete mussel shells comprising more than 50 valves, many of which were stacked on top of one another. Scattered, small to medium pieces of FCR ring the shell drop area. No bone was present. Soil samples were collected under the shells. The pollen record of sample 70 is co-dominated by Poaceae, High-spine Asteraceae, and Low-spine Asteraceae pollen (Figure 13.1; Table 13.2), representing grasses, various members of the sunflower family, and marshelder or related plants. Moderately small to small quantities of Carya, Juniperus, Maclura, Pinus, and Quercus pollen reflect hickory or pecan, juniper, Osage orange, pine, and oak trees growing in the vicinity or region of this site. If any of these differences represent economic activity it is possible the upper depth is associated with processing goosefoot, while the lower level is associated with processing a member of the sunflower family. However, it must be noted that both families of plants contain many members that are weedy, taking advantage of disturbed sediments. These signatures might be primarily environmental. The phytolith record for these two samples differs. The lower signature contains more grass short cells indicating that most of the grasses growing locally included cool season (Festucoid) and short (Chloridoid) grasses. Few tall (Panicoid) grass phytoliths were observed. Elongates and bulliforms were still present, as are trichomes. Dicots were noted, but did not contribute to understanding the local flora. A few sponge spicules, attesting to soil moisture, were observed. The upper sample contained fewer grass short cells indicating the presence of cool season and short grasses. Faunal remains from beaver, white tailed deer, turtle, rodents, and various mussel shell species were abundant. The pollen signature for this feature was dominated by Poaceae pollen, reflecting local growth of grasses, perhaps after abandonment of the feature. Moderate quantities of Low-spine Asteraceae and High-spine Asteraceae pollen represent various plants in the sunflower family that include marshelder and related plants and a large number of other plants that produce High-spine Asteraceae pollen. A smaller quantity of Amaranthaceae pollen represents goosefoot and related plants. Trees are represented by Carya, Maclura, Pinus, and Quercus pollen that indicate local or regional growth of hickory or pecan, Osage orange, pine, and oak trees. The phytolith signature includes primarily bulliform and elongate phytoliths, which are indicative of grasses (Figure 13.2). Grass short cells include rondel, trapeziform, Chloridoid saddles, and Panicoid bilobate forms indicating local grasses include primarily cool season (Festucoid) and short (Chloridoid) grasses. Given the fact that grasses in these two categories also may produce bilobates, it is difficult to ascertain whether or not the bilobates were produced in either cool season or short grasses or if they represent tall (Panicoid) grasses. 14. E S F A XPERIMENTAL TUDIES AND EATURE NALYSIS By Victoria Ingalls Worldwide, FCR represents one of the largest datasets for hunter-forager populations, but it is infrequently analyzed beyond presence/absence and the identification of features. This may be, in part, caused by the locally specific geologic and systemic contexts and by the perception by some that there is little to be learned from these features. Here, we add to the conversation with a discussion FCR from sites 41DN580 and 41DN624, our experimental study of local rock, and discuss feature types and possible behavioral correlates based on our results. Acacia’s 2021-2022 excavations at sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 found that site expression was primarily through the presence of FCR features. Across both sites, archeologists documented a total of 5,283 pieces of FCR (448.3 kg) in 32 features with a comparatively limited assemblage of other artifact classes. FCR represents 85% (n = 1168) of the lithic assemblage at site 41ND580, and 98.3% (n=4115) at site 41DN624. When we break it down by rock type, tabular sandstone rocks are the primary raw material used in FCR features at site 41DN624, constituting 66% of the FCR assemblage. While at site 41DN580, feature materials are split more evenly, with 43% sandstone and 45% limestone. Features ranged from scatters of FCR with little associated material, to more formal hearths and earth ovens (Figure 14.1). Collectively, our data suggest repeated but short-term occupation at both sites during the Middle and Late Archaic periods. Acacia’s preliminary analyses allowed us to group these features into three descriptive categories that relate to function and longevity of use. As described in Chapter 6, Category 1 includes non-patterned scatters of FCR (580 n=7; 624 n=6); these make up about a third to a half of all features at both sites. Category 2 includes tight, well-defined and typically circular clusters of burned rock without a distinct basin shape (580 n=7; 624 n=4). Category 3 includes basin-shaped earth ovens (580 n=2; 624 n=3). FCR making up the larger Type 2 and 3 features is primarily tabular sandstone, while many of the Type 1 features are primarily limestone or breccia. Although local clay soils are extremely deep, sandstone and limestone rocks are readily available from the nearby creek channel. It is also worth noting that chert is not common in the area, including in the creek channel gravels. With this in mind, we wanted to see if some simple experimentation would help refine our understanding of these features. Goals for this preliminary experimentation were to replicate some of the heat-alteration patterns seen in archeological features and investigate the degree of use-alteration and heat fracturing on local rocks. Examining these patterns will give us a better understanding of the temperature, conditions, and duration of heating which would allow us to interpolate behaviors from the archeological assemblage. This, combined with information related to feature type, size, and associated materials will help us contextualize the lifeways of Archaic peoples in the upper Trinity River Basin. ## Page 374

This experiment sought simply to establish to what degree intense heating would cause the visible alteration of individual rocks. Before the start of heating, we selected a representative sample 40 specimens to track throughout the process. Each was numbered, measured, weighed, photographed, and for each one we recorded a Munsell color for the cortex. Additionally, we noted if there were any existing cracks or other surface characteristics that may affect future fracture patterns. Then, we arranged our 40 rocks along with approximately 20 untracked rocks into a circular pit that was 25-30 cm deep and just over a meter in diameter, dug into the local loamy sand soil (Figure 14.3). These were arranged at random, and a fire was built on top. After the fire was lit, every 20 minutes archeologists took readings of the internal temperature, the temperature of the rocks at the exterior or the fire, as well as ambient air temperature, windspeed, and humidity (Figure 14.4). Fuel used included dry brush for kindling, and oak, pecan, and mesquite wood was added as necessary to raise and maintain internal temperature. Our initial goal was to slowly raise the temperature to a high of 1000˚C (or 1830˚F), allow the fire to burn down and create a coal bed which could be buried and allowed to slowly dry-cool. On the day of our experiment, the weather was a cool 58˚F and blustery, with a slight drizzle occurring off and on throughout the day. The fire was actively tended and stoked for five hours, during which time the average internal temperature was 660˚C, and the average of the exterior rocks was 192˚C. After this period, the hot coals were spread evenly across the feature, which was then covered with soil to approximate conditions in an earth oven. Thermal readings continued to be made at 20 minute intervals for several hours, after which time reading times were spaced out, especially in the overnight hours. In addition to the dry-cooled rocks, both sandstone and limestone rocks were used to observe fracture patterns resulting from stone-boiling (Figure 14.5). Photographs were taken as the process was repeated a total of five times. Temperatures were recorded for both the rock and water prior to emersion – the rock was heated to between 750 and 850˚C, while the water was allowed to cool between emersions to roughly 21˚C (or about 70˚F). ## Page 378

While researchers anticipated the reddening and discoloration based on the archeological assemblage, we also expected the rate of heat fracturing to be substantially higher. The fact that only three of the dry-cooled rocks fractured suggests that there was some variable we did not account for. It could be that our experiment did not achieve a high enough temperature to cause the expected fracturing, that fracturing was caused by repeated heating episodes, in damp or wet environments, or that the fracturing we documented in the field was not caused by the heat but rather time and taphonomic processes over the intervening millennia. As previous studies have shown (e.g., Neubauer 2018), wet-cooled FCR typically exhibit irregular and jagged fracture patterns with wavy interior surface. This held true for one of the two limestone stone boiling specimens, which fractured into twelve identifiable pieces and created a notable amount of sandy/gravel in the water container used during the experiment. During the first emersion, the stone exhibited a notable discoloration and reddening, and additional repetitions of heating and emersion produced similar reddening and fracturing. The second limestone rock also exhibited some discoloration but did not fracture at all throughout the experiment. Four pieces of sandstone were used for stone boiling. Three of the four rocks fractured on their second emersion, while the fourth did not fracture at all. These fractured in sheets along the rocks’ internal structure. All of the sandstone specimens also exhibited discoloration and a slight reddening. Discussion The results of this preliminary study showed that a thin bed of sandstone rocks with the fire built above (admittedly not the most heat efficient method) retained a temperature of over 200˚C (390˚F) for about seven hours after it was covered with soil, and over 100˚C (212˚F) for approximately 12 hours. This suggests that even a small amount of the local sandstone would be significant enough to create enough thermal longevity with a small fire to roast whatever local foodstuffs were being eaten. During stone-boiling experiments, it was anticipated that limestone would perform better than sandstone, and this generally held true. Both types of stone performed well as far as fracturing, taking on average more than four submersions to fracture in any significant way. There was some discoloration noted immediately, but investigators were again surprised by the lack of cracking or exfoliation. While both types of rock took this repeated drastic thermal stress without major fracturing, our limestone examples did raise the temperature of the water slightly more than the sandstone pieces, in the range of 15-20˚C as opposed to about 10-15˚C per immersion. This allows us to speculate that limestone may have been preferred over sandstone for stone-boiling. To look more closely at rock choice, we identified (where possible) the types of rock in each feature. Most features have a significant proportion of either limestone or sandstone over the other rock type, suggesting there was a preferential rock selection for different activities. Most Category 1 features were primarily limestone, whereas the Category 2 and 3 features tend to be constructed of tabular sandstone. The thermal properties of rocks depend on numerous factors including the mineralogical composition, structure and geometry of pores, grain sizes, shape and depth of cracks, and their concentration, as well as surface area to mass ratio (Neubauer 2018; Rostami et al. 2016; Sun et al. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 354


---

## Page 379

2016). While limestone is calcium carbonate, sandstone is primarily composed of quartz with various amounts of hematite/magnetite (giving the sandstone the classic reddish-orange color when heated) and other minerals. Sandstone is more readily available from local sources and tends to be more resistant to thermal shock and can withstand higher temperatures without fracturing or exploding. Sandstone has a lower thermal conductivity than limestone, which means it takes longer to heat up but retains heat for longer periods of time. This property can be advantageous for cooking tasks that require a slow and steady heat source. Limestone, on the other hand, is a denser and finer-grained rock that tends to have a higher thermal conductivity than sandstone. Meaning that it heats up more quickly, but also cools down faster, making it less efficient than sandstone for cooking tasks that require a consistent and sustained heat source. Finally, rock shape is likely reciprocally influenced by feature function. Tabular sandstone is easily stackable and can create dense areas of rock that, heated well, increased heat retention. This could also allow the feature’s creators to have more control over the form and shape of features, which may have been an important aspect of their construction. This is especially true if features are designed for a specific use. Alternately, the locally available limestone is typically chunky and less uniform, adding additional variables to feature construction. Features with more limestone content tend to be more sprawling, less well defined, and also suggest less intense burning episodes and period of use. Combining these data points leads us to suggest that some of our Category 1 features may in fact be the result of stone-boiling activities. Behaviorally, we would not expect FCR resulting from stone-boiling to necessarily be piled or arranged in any pattern, but rather discarded haphazardly as they either fractured or had fulfilled their purpose. Additionally, as noted above, the thermal behavioral characteristics of limestone make it a slightly better candidate for stone-boiling. We acknowledge that this was a preliminary experiment that did not have good control over many variables and was only conducted once. This experiment was also limited in the types of environmental conditions that it tested. For example, researchers did not test rocks for repeated firing, and we did not increase the moisture of the earth oven as would be expected if it was being used to cook. However, this simple experimental study offers a starting point and allows us to refine our preliminary interpretations of the behaviors that created these features. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 355

15. S D YNTHESIS AND ISCUSSION This chapter presents a summary of results and discussion of inter- and intra-site variability among sites 41DN580 and 41DN624. These are multicomponent Prehistoric residential camps on the floodplain of Hickory Creek in Denton, Texas. Acacia identified both sites within the Hickory Creek Interceptor project area during survey, and subsequently tested and mitigated each within the project easements. Stratified deposits at both sites indicate three recognizable periods of occupation. At site 41DN580, these include two Middle Archaic occupations and a third during the Late Prehistoric. Site 41DN624 has two distinct Middle Archaic components, along with a Late Archaic occupation. The assemblages and features documented in the investigated areas of the sites suggest these were temporary camps used periodically over several thousand years. THC recommended that both sites are eligible for SAL and NRHP listing. Acacia’s excavations were limited to the right-of-way for the Hickory Creek Interceptor line, and as such the exposures afforded only partial glimpses of each site. Previous surveys showed that 41DN580 extends outside the current project area to the east, and erosion along the artificial detention basin suggest it would have originally extended towards the north and west as well. Similarly, it would not be surprising if 41DN624 also extended outside the current easement. Overall, Acacia excavated 57.7 m3 of sediment across both sites through feature-focused units and control units placed in areas without visible features. During excavations, 19 features were documented at 41DN580, and 13 at 41DN624. All of the discrete features (i.e., site furniture) identified during this effort date to the Middle (5900-3500 BP) and Late (2900-2700 BP) Archaic. These are principally variously sized concentrations of FCR with some associated cultural material. The Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580, originally labeled Feature 14, was approximately 40 cm thick and while no discrete features were identified within this zone, this component contained more artifacts than all earlier occupations combined, including modified mussel shell implements, a bone needle fragment, ceramic sherds, as well as three arrow points. In addition to chronometric samples collected from each site, recovered Archaic diagnostic artifacts include Godley, Trinity, Darl, Kent, and Marshall dart points; Late Prehistoric diagnostics include Colbert/Hayes, Alba, and Fresno arrow points. Chronology and Context The primary goal of eligibility testing that carried through the data recovery efforts was to understand the chronology of the sites and how they fit into the broader Prehistoric patterns of north- central Texas. Pulling together the data presented here, there are at least three primary periods of occupation at each site (Chapter 7). Although separated by roughly a thousand years, modeled dates at 41DN580 indicate two Middle Archaic occupations (at roughly 5000-4800 cal BP, and 4000-3800 cal BP), while a third period of occupation dates to about 750-700 cal BP. Likewise, at 41DN624 there are two Middle Archaic periods of occupation (dating to about 5900-5600 and 3700-3500 cal BP), and a third Late Archaic (2900-2700 cal BP) occupation. Each of the Archaic period occupations are defined by typically small thermal features that have a limited assemblage of associated artifacts. Moreover, Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 356

This is linked in part to the component’s much younger age, increasing the probability of organic preservation. However, as we will discuss below, the Late Prehistoric represents a distinct change in tool use and technology, and quite possibly entirely new adaptations in resource optimization. The generalized refuse was scattered over an indistinct surface that, in addition to the artifacts described below, also had abundant flecks of carbon, burned clay, and other small inclusions, making this soil distinct from its surroundings. Artifacts recovered included a substantial amount of faunal material, 102 lithics, as well as all the site’s ceramic material. Lithic tools from this component include Alba, Colbert/Hayes, and Fresno points, two prismatic blades, bifacial thinning flakes, and many utilized flakes. Nearly all lithic materials show some amount of use-wear including battering, abrasion, polish, and scraping. The identifiable raw materials represented by these lithics include 35% Uvalde Chert (n=36), 13.7% Edwards chert (n=14), 3% silicified sandstone (n=3), 2% Nova chert (n=2), while a single example is Ogallala quartzite. Material types for the remainder are not identifiable to a source. Because the preservation of Late Prehistoric faunal material was so much greater than earlier components, this occupation accounts for 92% of the vertebrate and 40% of the invertebrate assemblages. This increased sample size also has higher taxonomic richness than earlier occupations, which is expected for larger samples (Lyman 2008). Identified species include white-tailed deer, mule deer, American beaver, and box turtle, as well as many other specimens only identifiable as ‘mammal’ (Ramsey, Jacobson, and Haliburton, Chapter 10). The greater species diversity in the Late Prehistoric assemblage does not necessarily indicate a change in subsistence patterns or environmental conditions compared to the Middle Archaic (though it remains a possibility) but is rather the result of greater Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 359

## Page 384

preservation (Phillips, Chapter 11). Just over half of the vertebrate remains have been burned, and all direct evidence of butchering at the site came from this component. Evidence of butchering includes cut marks identified on a deer (Odocoileus sp.) metapodial, cut and chop marks on an American beaver (Castor canadensis) femur, and percussion marks on an Artiodactyl long bone (Chapter 10). The cut and chop marks on the beaver femur are likely associated with primary disarticulation, while the cut marks on the deer metapodial diaphysis likely resulted from secondary processing/consumption. Moreover, all of the vertebrate remains identifiable as turtle came from this occupation. More than 66% of the turtle remains are burned, suggesting they were processed directly in a fire (Chapter 10). Vertebrate remains from this component also exhibit moderately high rates of carnivore modification (some 20% of Late Prehistoric bone); while this could indicate the presence of domesticated dogs, it could also be from carnivore scavenging. Invertebrate remains from this period of occupation were likewise more numerous than in any other site component. The majority are unidentifiable freshwater mussel shell fragments (n=1124), although like the vertebrate faunal, this component also produced a much wider breadth of identifiable species which include threeridge, yellow sandshell, bankclimber, bleufer, and Texas lilliput. Because of the differences in preservation rates between the Late Prehistoric and Archaic period components, this report cannot draw definitive conclusions concerning changes in subsistence strategies or environmental conditions from previous periods. However, nor can exploration of this question be discarded. The mussel shell data do suggest an intensification in use of that resource in the Late Prehistoric period. Unlike bone, mussel shell remains were preserved—and often well preserved—in the older Archaic period contexts. In fact, an entire intact feature of well-preserved freshwater mussel shells (Feature 18, mostly identified as Texas lilliput) was recorded in the Middle Archaic II component at site 41DN580, which implies conditions were sufficient to allow for preservation in place of a single discard event. Thus, the marked increase in mussel shell counts and weight in the Late Prehistoric component cannot be simply dismissed as preservation bias. Even more intriguing about these bivalves is that 32 of them were intentionally modified. Eighteen have cut and/or smoothed edges, and six show signs of battering, and at least six have use-related polish (Chapter 11). Some were likely expedient tools, and the heavy battering and use suggests they may have been used as hoes/digging implements, as scrapers (possibly for hides or wood), possibly ceramic smoothing tools, or in other ways. This alone suggests that an entirely new technological adaptation was occurring in the Late Prehistoric period, one possibly centered on plant and animal resource harvesting or horticulture, and possibly even related to ceramic production. The increased preservation extended to paleobotanical remains as well. Samples analyzed by Bush (Chapter 11) include ash and elm wood charcoal (Fraxinus sp. and Ulmus sp.), black walnut nutshell (Juglans nigra), walnut wood charcoal (Juglans sp.), and wood charcoal from the Juglandaceae family (likely walnut or pecan). These confirm the presence of tree species expected in the riparian environment, and while wood can be gathered at any time of the year, it does indicate the seasonal presence of walnuts and possibly pecans at the site. The paleobotanical results are discussed in more detail below. Like earlier periods, phytolith and pollen samples from this component are dominated by cool season short grasses (Cummings, Chapter 13). These results again indicate a moist environment Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 360

## Page 385

dominated by open grassland species including sunflowers, mustards, bull nettle, buckwheat, and goosefoot. Nearby tree species include oak, pine, pecan/hickory, and bois d’arc. Along with the walnut wood identified in paleobotanical samples, this suggests a likely fall season occupation that used the broad mosaic environment with abundant seasonally available resources, including a variety of nut species and cool season greens. Late Prehistoric ceramics were also present. These are coarse, shell-tempered sherds from thick-walled Nocona Plain and Nocona Brushed cooking jars (Perttula, Chapter 9). Investigations at Lake Lewisville sites have shown that shell-tempered ceramics are common in the Late Prehistoric period Henrietta phase (Brown and Lebo 1991; Ferring and Yates 1998; Krieger 1946), although few of these are securely dated. Nocona ceramics were first defined at the Harrell site (41YN1), where approximately 98% of the ceramic assemblage is shell tempered plainware (Bell and Brooks 2001; Texas Beyond History 2002). Nocona Plain is distinguished by simple, undecorated vessel forms frequently with thick walls and bases. It has been posited that Nocona Plains wares are likely locally made, although there is some debate whether this is the case, or whether they represent external influence from the Southern Plains or possibly Caddo regions (Crook and Houghston 2015). Ceramics appear at sites within the upper Trinity River basin by at least AD 1000 but are not typically abundant (Perttula et al. 1995; Todd 2014). Shell-tempered Nocona Plain ceramics typically do not appear at any sites in Texas until after AD 1250 (Todd 2014). However, most sites in North Texas with components from this period are not well dated or investigated. The Lake Lewisville sites have age ranges with median probabilities of AD 1307 and 1405 (Perttula, Chapter 9). Interestingly, the Late Prehistoric component from 41DN580 has modeled dates of AD 1200-1250, meaning these Nocona sherds are some of the earliest dated examples of shell-tempered pottery in north-central Texas. Together, the data from the Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580 align closely what Alex Krieger called the Henrietta phase of the Late Prehistoric in the Texas Rolling Plains. The Henrietta phase (sometimes called a focus, complex, or phenomenon) was originally defined as a component at the Harrell site (41YN1) along the Upper Brazos River in Young County, excavated by the WPA in the late 1930s, (Krieger 1946). Sites with Henrietta characteristics seem to cluster tightly along major waterways. They are found in the southernmost plains of Oklahoma south and along the Brazos, upper Trinity, and Red River drainages (Koszarek and Morgan 2017; Krieger 1946). These hunter- horticulturalists lived in small, semi-sedentary villages and traded with Caddo groups to the east, Plains peoples to the north, as well as Southwest cultural region groups to the west (Boyd 1997; Koszarek and Morgan 2017; Krieger 1946; Texas Beyond History 2002). Artifacts characteristic of Henrietta sites include bison bone hoes, bone awls, beveled knives, small arrow points (Fresno, Alba, Perdiz, Scallorn, and others), and Nocona ceramics (Boyd 1997; Koszarek and Morgan 2017; Krieger 1946; Texas Beyond History 2002). The Harrell site assemblage also includes mussel shell beads, shell pendants and adornments, as well as unfinished shell blanks for pendants (Krieger 1946). Although far less abundant, freshwater shell tools are also present at several Henrietta phase sites (Krieger 1946). At the Harrell site for example, there are very few bison bone hoes, but more than 30 mussel shells with heavy use-wear and battering (Dial and Black 2002; Krieger 1946). Krieger (1946:101-106, 138) identified the perforated and hafted shells with this substantial use-wear “hoes,” while unperforated Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 361

## Page 386

but battered or polished shells were called “hand hoes.” The differential use-wear on these two types of hoes suggests that locally available mussel shells were used as expedient tools for a variety of tasks. In sum, the Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580 represents an area of general refuse likely created during a fall season occupation. Occupants of the site discarded the remains of their meals, evidenced by butchered and burned faunal remains, expedient or spent tools of both lithic and shell, and discarded broken ceramic vessels. Materials are weathered and vertebrate faunal remains show evidence of carnivore activity, suggesting these materials were exposed for some time before being completely buried. Additionally, although materials were distributed vertically over roughly 40-50 cm, there was a distinct lens of material with slightly darker, more organic soil that likely represents the occupation surface. The vertical spread of these materials could be accounted for by the clayey nature of the soil and the distinct shrink-swell episodes caused by Texas’ famous wet-dry cycles. 41DN624 Chronological Summary Site 41DN624 shows a remarkable clustering of features and activity areas that are roughly contemporaneous (Figure 15.3). Modeled dates for site occupation indicate there are three periods of occupation (Table 15.2). The first is the “Middle Archaic I” (5900-5600 cal BP) within the Sanger formation; features from this period include 2, 6, 7, and 8. The second, Middle Archaic II occupation dates to about 3700-3500 cal BP and is defined by Features 9-13. The third occupation is dated to the Late Archaic, roughly 2900-2700 cal BP, in the Pilot Point formation. This occupation is represented by Features 3, 4, and 5, which cluster at the southern end of the site area. 41DN624 Middle Archaic I (5900-5600 cal BP) When all the site’s features are divided by period, the Middle Archaic I features are the most widely distributed across the site area. Feature 2 is on the north side of US 377 and is a Category 1 cluster of FCR, which by itself is not remarkable. However, in the units surrounding this feature, there are five flakes, an unusually large number of lithics for such a small feature. These included Edwards and Uvalde cherts, as well as silicified sandstone and chalcedony (Chapter 8). Four of these exhibit use-wear, suggesting they were expedient tools. Additionally, there is oak wood (Quercus sp.) in the flotation sample taken from this feature (Chapter 11). South of US 377, Features 6, 7, and 8 date to the Middle Archaic I. Features 7 and 8 are both Category 2 features; however, Feature 8 has a central, circular depression that puts it on the cusp of a Category 3 small earth oven. Mussel shell from Feature 8 included threeridge, pimpleback, Texas lilliput, and 80 unidentifiable mussel shell pieces (Chapter 11). Notably, the tabular sandstone comprising this feature were discolored only on the bottom faces indicating they were on top of the fire/heat. This suggests these flat stones may be a griddle. Other studies have shown thermal energy is retained and high temperatures reached more quickly if rocks are placed within and above the heating element. Thus, this construction method could have sped the rate or increased the temperature at which foods in this feature were cooked. Feature 7 is also unusual in that it is a small cluster of tabular FCR over a 10 cm deep ashy pit with practically no associated artifacts (these only include one unidentifiable mussel shell fragment). As with Feature 8, this could suggest this feature was a griddle, with the flat rocks placed over the fire. Finally, Feature 6 is a large Category 3 feature constructed almost entirely out of large sandstone slabs. These were notably larger than other features, with many FCR over 10 cm in original size (although many were cracked/fractured in place). As is typical, most of the invertebrate remains were unidentifiable mussel shell, although five threeridge specimens are present. 41DN624 Middle Archaic II (3700-3500 cal BP) Moving into the Pilot Point formation, the second period of occupation was during the late Middle Archaic from about 3700-3500 cal BP (“Middle Archaic II”) and is defined by Features 9-13. These five features are all at basically the same elevation and cluster in an area of about 160 m2. These are interpreted as multiple concurrent activity areas on a single living surface. At the southern end of this cluster is Features 12, a very nice little Category 3 earth oven with a distinct central depression. Carbonized material and burned soil were present throughout the feature, which comprised primarily small pieces of stacked tabular sandstone arranged within a shallow depression. The interspersed nature of the carbon and sandstone again gives us a glimpse into the oven’s construction techniques – the rocks were likely added over time as the fire burned down and more fuel was added. Near this earth oven was a heavily used and refurbished Godley or Trinity point made from Ogallala quartzite. No vertebrate faunal remains and few mussel shells were found near this feature. Feature 13 is about 2.5 m northeast of Feature 12 and comprises a very loose scatter of FCR, three lithics, and 31 freshwater mussel shell fragments (unidentifiable Unionidae). Lithic artifacts include a modified Uvalde chert flake with some use-wear, as well as a heavily refurbished Darl point of Edwards chert, and a heavily used projectile point, also made of Edwards chert, that is fragmentary and thus untyped. In the center of this activity area are Features 10 and 11. This area has the largest concentration of lithic material at the site, comprising 54 pieces, 35 of which have signs of use-wear. One point was recovered from this area – a Godley point on made from course-grained Uvalde Gravel chert; use- wear also indicates the point was used as a scraper and is heavily refurbished. Of these 54 lithics, 36 are identifiable as Edwards chert and two are Uvalde chert (Chapter 8). This distribution could suggest a preference for high-quality but distant lithic sources over poorer quality but more readily available local Uvalde chert, and/or could likewise imply high mobility over large territory that includes much of central Texas. Faunal remains are fairly well preserved in this area. Within this context, there are 58 faunal specimens representing medium/medium-large mammals, and 125 mussel shell specimens (13 threeridge, six Texas lilliput, and 106 unidentifiable Unionidae). Additionally, this area produced a single large tabular piece of sandstone that may be a metate. Together, this data may indicate that food-production and associated tasks in support of those happening at Features 9 and 12 took place here. This does not seem to represent the same kind of discard area seen in the Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580. At the northern end of the site and the Middle Archaic I activity area is Feature 9, which is unlike any other feature documented at the site. It does not exhibit the characteristic features of an earth oven, nor does it resemble the small scatters of FCR seen elsewhere at the site. All the stones from Feature 9 are on a single, flat surface, there is little to no soil staining, no carbonized organic matter, and no indication of a pit or depression. The rocks themselves are mostly rounded or angular, instead of tabular, like those in the earth oven features at site 41DN624. Simultaneously, however, this feature is about 130 cm in diameter, broader than other features at the site, with several small clusters (possibly rake-out piles) and a diffuse scatter of FCR extending outward around the feature. Together, the area around Features 9-13 represents multiple activities of the same camp/occupation. Features 9 and 12 were likely used for slow-cooking various foodstuffs, although Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 366
