## Page 393

Review of Research Questions and Findings The research objectives in the study of sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 were structured around first identifying chronology and major periods of use/occupation. Based on the sites’ chronology, Acacia hoped to compare differences in site content to better understand the context of these sites within the wider north-central Texas region. Acacia also proposed higher order research questions that sought to identify foraging and resource use strategies through the archeological record. If the record did reflect specific behavior adaptations could group size, mobility, and/or territory size be inferred? And how might they have changed over time? Below, we discuss these research questions and our findings in more detail. Research Issue 1: Foraging Strategies, Seasonality, and Site Reuse Acacia postulated that the data from sties 41DN580 and 41DN624 could show how Indigenous peoples of the region were using the landscape and its resources during the periods of site occupation. The presence of thermal features across both sites indicates sporadic, but repeated occupation of the area over roughly five thousand years, suggesting these were, in some respect, persistent places on the landscape. While palaeobotanical data from these sites was not as abundant as we would have hoped, we draw on several lines of evidence to discuss environmental conditions and possible associated foraging strategies. Riparian areas like Hickory Creek tend to promote woodland growth along their margins (i.e., riparian forest buffers) that may encourage a more diverse environmental mosaic. Given how sites in north-central Texas tend to cluster significantly along major drainages, these woodland riparian corridor environments were likely ideal locations for Indigenous groups, as they offered a wider breadth of resources and foraging opportunities than less diverse environments. Presumably, these areas and their resources could also buffer (to some degree) site occupants against climactic and environmental shifts that may have more dramatic impacts outside of riparian buffer zones. Paleobotanical (macrobotanicals, carbonized remains, and flotation samples) and pollen/phytolith data from most analyzed contexts were limited, primarily confirming common species within riparian and woodland areas (Chapters 11 and 12). At 41DN580, Late Prehistoric organic remains include elm, ash, black walnut wood and nutshell, as well as walnut or pecan (Juglandaceae) wood charcoal. Black walnut (Juglans nigra) grows well near waterways, as do related species of pecan and hickory (Juglandaceae). Pecan, hickory, and black walnut nuts become ripe in the fall, and in addition to a food source, the black walnut nutshell can be used to create a dark dye or stain. The black walnut shell could indicate that this occupation took place during the fall months. Ash and elm wood were also found in this component and are common species in woodland areas. As these are wood fragments from trees that do not produce edible resources, the presence of these trees does not add any additional information on seasonality (as wood resources can be gathered and used at any time of the year), although it does confirm these species were present during the Late Prehistoric period along the creek. Pollen from analyzed samples supports the presence of hickory/pecan, bois d’arc, pine, and oak trees in the immediate vicinity (Chapter 13). These samples Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 369


---

## Page 394

further indicate the presence of short, cool season grasses and other open area forbs and edible plants. Together, these data all point to a fall occupation of the site in the Late Prehistoric period. Moving earlier into the site’s occupational history, 41DN580 Middle Archaic II (4000-3800 cal BP) palaeobotanical remains of chenopod seeds from Features 3 and 6 possibly indicate a late summer or fall occupation (Chapter 11). Goosefoot (Chenopodium sp.) typically emerges in the spring and drops seeds in the late summer to early fall; it is very hearty, spreading easily but preferring nearly full sun, suggesting a relatively open habitat. The leaves can be eaten at any time of the year, although new growth leaves are preferable because of their milder taste. Nonetheless, it is difficult to tell if this was the primary foodstuff being processed in the feature, or if it was possibly part of the packing/wrapping materials for the food load (e.g., McAuliffe et al. 2023). The final identifiable palaeobotanical sample from 41DN580 is dewberry cane Feature 5 (Middle Archaic I, 5000-4800 cal BP). While the berries are typically ripe in late spring to early summer, the cane can be harvested at nearly any time of year for use in fiber crafts. The remaining palaeobotanical specimens from the site were either indeterminate carbonized botanicals, or unidentifiable wood charcoal flecks. Paylonological data from the Middle Archaic I period is dominated by low, cool season grasses as well as members of the sunflower family, and marshelder or related plants (Chapter 13). Tree pollen reflects the presence of oak, hickory/pecan, juniper, bois d’arc, and pine trees. The pollen and phytoliths thus suggest a likely fall or early spring occupation. In either season, there would have been abundant plant life in the riparian corridor. At 41DN624, the paleobotanical remains were much more limited, with only carbonized oak wood (Quercus sp.) being identifiable beyond indeterminate hardwood (Chapter 11). Although no edible plant material was recovered, the presence of oak again tells us these trees were present near the creek during the Middle Archaic and implies the seasonal availability of acorns in the fall. Although more specific data from this site is not available, given the consistency of species appearing in samples from 41DN580 over time and the sites’ proximity to each other, it is very likely that similar plant species are present at 41DN624. Faunal material likewise shows people at the sites were utilizing both riverine and terrestrial resources. Identified species include white-tailed deer, mule deer, American beaver, and box turtle, as well as mussel shells of threeridge, yellow sandshell, bankclimber, bleufer, and Texas lilliput varieties. These species are widely available and not seasonally dependent. This leaves the 41DN580 paleobotanical and pollen/phytolith samples the best evidence we have pertaining seasonality. These data suggest that the 41DN580 Middle Archaic peoples occupied the site in the late summer to fall, while the Late Prehistoric occupation may have taken place in the fall to winter months. As for foraging strategies, inhabitants appear to have been accessing a wide range of riverine and terrestrial resources from the mixed riparian/woodland/grassland environment along Hickory Creek. An interesting datapoint is the lack of faunal remains that can be securely identified as bison. While local scale bison population density would vary considerably over time, at the larger regional scale, evidence indicates that bison populations increase when grasslands expand (e.g., Kemp 2008; Lohse et al. 2014a). This absence could be caused by poor preservation of vertebrate faunal material, especially during the Archaic period occupations. Faunal remains in the “large mammal” category may well be bison bone that is too fragmented or deteriorated to confidently identify. However, Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 370

## Page 395

arguments based on preservation do not hold as well for the Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580. Given the level of good preservation and the species diversity within the Late Prehistoric assemblage, we surmise that bison would appear in the assemblage if they were a focus for site occupants. Therefore, we argue that the faunal assemblage’s absence of bison indicates a broad subsistence strategy focused on the mosaic of arboreal-grassland and riverine resources that did not inlcude not bison hunting. Cook-Stone Technology Paleoenvironmental data show multiple climatic changes between the Middle Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. These climatic changes would have influenced resource availability and therefore foraging strategies over the long term. Regional environmental data suggest that the environment during the Late Pleistocene was a predominantly arboreal environment with an increase in grassland and mixed arboreal and grassland environments through the Holocene (Lawrence and Eyeington, Chapter 7; Bousman 1998; Mandel et al. 2007; Meier et al. 2014; Nordt et al. 2002; Toomey 1993; Waters et al. 2021). As presented by Lawrence and Eyeington (Chapter 7), comparing these data with the Greenland ice core temperature data, site occupation within the Sanger alloformation correspond to periods of warmer global temperatures, as well as the expansion of grasslands. Occupation within the Pilot Point-West Fork alloformation from roughly 4000-2700 BP corresponds to a cooler period globally, when arboreal cover likely increased. The Late Prehistoric occupation took place during the Little Ice Age, when global temperatures cooled, and climactic shifts became unpredictable (Chapter 7). Geoarchaeological data from 41DN580 and 41DN624 mirror the global data, indicating increasing C4 (warmer grassland environment) throughout the Archaic deposits and then increasing C3 (cooler, more arboreal environment) within the last 300–500 years (Chapter 7). These climactic changes would have influenced local environmental conditions as well as some human behaviors. It is possible that earth-oven baking was a regionally specialized technological response that allowed local populations to intensify resource extraction and withstand long-term environmental changes. Although there is comparatively little data on Early Archaic (and earlier) populations in north- central Texas, regional populations are typically assumed to be smaller and ranging over larger territories based on site frequency and material source distribution. Populations likely increased through the Middle Archaic, and by the Late Archaic larger populations were living in smaller, more defined territories than in previous periods. This is supported by the increased number of Middle and especially Late Archaic sites, their typical locations along major waterways, and the increased reliance on local resources and increasing scarcity of nonlocal materials (lithic sources in particular). Additionally, regardless of local environment, earth oven density increases over time (Thoms 2023). Therefore, we can surmise that earth ovens indicate changes in resource use/extraction that reciprocally reinforced established trends in population growth and subsequently more intensive land use (e.g., more intensive site use and increased rates of site reoccupation over time) (Black and Creel 1997:302; Collins 2004; Dering 1999; Koenig and Miller 2023; Mauldin and Nickels 2001, 2003; Miller and Graves 2011; Thoms 2008, 2023; Vierra 2005; Willey and Phillips 1958). In other words, earth ovens allowed Archaic peoples to adapt to changing environmental, demographic, and social/political environments by increasing the breadth of potentially usable resources. In north-central Texas, Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 371


---

## Page 396

riparian mosaic environments would be ideal locations for this kind of intensification, as the diversity of localized resources would have been greater and, presumably, would more easily support larger social groups and regional populations. Binford (2001) and others (see Freeman et al. 2023; Johnson and Hard 2008) have suggested that hunter-foragers intensify resource use in a given region only if (other things beings equal) their mobility and residential options are constrained. Additionally, a recent study by Freeman et al. (2023) shows that for several Texas regions, social organization and resource extraction methods have more of an impact on a region’s population and carrying capacity than climactic predicters of ecosystem productivity. If these hypotheses hold for north-central Texas, we anticipate both resource and land use intensification at the same time as we see increased population growth. Earth oven plant processing was likely a strategy for resource intensification supporting demographic increases in lieu of the domesticates or horticultural intensification we see in other regions (Black and Creel 1997:302; Dering 1999; Koenig and Miller 2023; Thoms 2008). At the Hickory Creek sites, this pattern may hold true for the Early to Middle Archaic transition, when earth ovens and cook stone technologies appear, but the pattern and intensity of land use appears consistent from the Middle through the Late Archaic periods. It is in the Late Prehistoric period that there are substantive changes in land use and cultural practices. Earth ovens are often interpreted only in the sense of food processing, but if we move away from sole environmental considerations, ethnographic examples indicate the social interactions that necessitate and facilitate the use of these features are more significant in than the thing being processed. Much research of cook-stone technology and associated environmental factors in Texas has focused on the extremely large earth ovens or burned rock middens from central and western regions of the state. Large earth ovens are often associated with feasting activities or large-scale arid environment carbohydrate production (see Fish 2023; Koenig and Miller 2023; Thoms 2023). Similarly, burned rock middens are large-scale group activities repeated over generations that often form large mounds. However, the features documented during this project are substantially smaller, arguably family-size ovens (see McAuliffe et al. 2023; Thoms 2023). Thus, while we may not see the exact type of large communal organization that is present in other regions, the Hickory Creek sites have multiple but comparatively small features during every occupation, as well as several defined activity areas nearby. This suggests there were likely small groups occupying the sites at any given time, having some communal food production and activity areas (e.g., see discussion of 41DN624 Features 9-13). Although sometimes used to roast meats/proteins or occasionally ferment alcoholic beverages, cross-culturally earth ovens are most frequently used to process carbohydrate-rich plant foods (Thoms 2023). Although our evidence suggests many features at 41DN580 and 41DN624 were used for animals and riverine resources (mussels, beavers, turtles), in this region of Texas earth ovens are typically interpreted as facilities to roast onion or camas bulbs, arrowhead tubers, or spatterdock rhizomes, geophytes that would have benefitted from long earth oven cooking. The site furniture (i.e., hearths) typically provides the structure around which other camp activities and facilities are organized (Stevenson 1991:277). Where these earth ovens occur simultaneously with other smaller features and activity areas in the near vicinity, we suggest that these represent the remains of activities that would have taken place during the roasting process. In other words, while the earth oven was Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 372


---

## Page 397

baking whatever foodstuffs were available, the group in camp would engage in a suite of other activities including meals, resource procurement and processing, tool refurbishing, and other social activities. If we take 41DN624 Features 9-13 as an example, there are two ovens roughly 20 m apart with a smaller FCR feature and substantial activity area in the center. These are at elevations between 172.2 and 171.99 m amsl and could represent a single occupation. If true, this may indicate ovens were constructed on the edge of camps, or at least the edge of defined activity areas, where they could be easily accessed and maintained during their likely long burn times. Interestingly too, these features are of vastly different sizes and constructions, suggesting they were used to cook different types of foodstuffs and would possibly have facilitated different types of social interactions and associated activities. In sum, we believe the data collected from 41DN580 and 41DN624 show the increasing intensity of riparian-woodland resource use over time, and that these mosaic environments created persistent places on the landscape as populations increased and territories shrank. These mosaic environments likewise supported multiple hunter-forager strategies allowed Indigenous peoples to adapt to changing sociopolitical and environmental conditions through time. And while we cannot definitively determine site seasonality based on the current data, palaeobotanical and pollen/phytolith remains possibly suggest fall occupations, although there would certainly be a diversity of resources in these areas year-round. Research Issue 2: Group Size and Mobility Acacia’s second research issue concerned group size, and if sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 represent short-term seasonal camps or longer-duration basecamps. We asked if the data could indicate the size of the groups occupying these sites, and what their possible range of mobility was. This topic was touched on in the previous section as it relates to site reuse and foraging strategies. Overall, it is not clear if features from each major component at 41DN580 and 41DN624 are contemporaneous with each other (i.e., multiple features representing a single occupation), or whether they represent multiple occupation events that occurred over a span of several hundred years (see Tables 15.1-15.2). Even a few centimeters of vertical separation could indicate a temporal separation of a few hundred years based on modeled sedimentation rates by Lawrence and Eyeington (Chapter 7). On the other hand, small natural changes in the ancient topography would also account for some of these smaller differences in elevation between some features. For example, at 41DN580 Features 5 and 8, which are separated by more than 65 m in distance yet are mapped with a 2 cm difference in elevation and returned very similar radiocarbon dates - 4450 ± 30 and 4470 ± 30 BP, respectively. There is a chance that these features were utilized concurrently between 4440 and 4480 BP, or on the outside they could represent occupations separated by 80 years or more (at least two generations). These minute changes in possible timing of individual features could therefore have profound impacts on estimates of group size. There have been numerous studies that estimate group size based on the number of hearths, the calories produced by a particular type of resource cooked in a particular type of earth oven/FCR feature, ethnographic analogies of average hunter-forager group size, etc. However, none of these Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 373

## Page 398

models are quite comparable with the data collected for the two sites described in this study. Furthermore, the current lack of understanding about what foodstuffs were actually being processed in these features (beyond freshwater mussels) precludes use of many previously published models. What we can say is that even if all features from a given period were used contemporaneously, these were small social groups that likely fall at or below the average 20 to 25-person hunter-forager group size. Looking at group mobility, we can say with some certainty that none of the occupations documented at either site represent permanent or long-term settlements. The paucity of artifacts as well as the lack of middens and evidence indicating feature reuse (especially of the larger earth ovens) indicates these were temporary camps, likely occupied only for very short durations. While it is possible such evidence may exist outside the current project area at the site, currently, neither site provides enough evidence to show that they are gathering places for larger social groups or for long durations. Across 41DN580 and 41DN624, the relatively low quantities of cultural materials may be partially attributed to taphonomic processes. While the local scarcity of high-quality lithic raw materials and long-term reuse and curation of tools may largely explain their paucity in the assemblage (Ayala and Pontillo, Chapter 8), the substantial presence of thermal features but lack of organic remains (i.e., faunal bone, carbonized plant material, etc.) could be caused by the slower rates of sediment accumulation (Lawrence and Eyeington, Chapter 7; Colvin 2013; Ferring 1986). Lawrence and Eyeington report in Chapter 7 that, on average, sedimentation rates at both sites are markedly lower than at other documented sites across the region. Slow sedimentation rates would have left site areas exposed for longer periods of time, decreasing the amount of organic preservation. This corresponds well with the results of Ramsey, Jacobson, and Haliburton’s faunal analysis presented in Chapter 10, which showed extremely high rates of weathering and breakage/fragmentation of the vertebrate remains, as well as several instances of notable carnivore gnawing and modification. The activity patterns at both sites examined here support the work Ferring and Yates (1997, 1998) undertook at Lakes Lewisville and Ray Roberts, where they suggested that Archaic period sites comprising multiple small thermal features but limited lithic and faunal assemblages reflect highly mobile groups whose foraging strategies relied on the local diversity of riparian, patchy woodland, and prairie ecozones. Ferring and Yates (1998) also hypothesized that this characteristic site expression was concentrated along major drainages and may indicate short stop-over points on longer seasonal rounds. Data from 41DN580 and 41DN624 corroborate these interpretations and may suggest this area was occupied primarily in the fall months. Moreover, Ferring and Yates (1997, 1998) examined Late Prehistoric components at several sites to suggest that in the later periods of prehistory, the presence/absence of ceramic materials could indicate not only the duration of site occupation, but also gendered economic activities. They suggest it is possible that the presence of ceramics at the two sites could indicate not only larger group sizes, but also potentially suggests that the group was not a male-only hunting party (Ferring and Yates 1998). Non-local lithics provide evidence for the range of group mobility, or at the very least the extent of their trade networks. Edwards Plateau chert is sourced roughly 150 mi (~250 km) or more Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 374

south of the project area, and novaculite (Nova chert) is found in Arkansas and parts of Oklahoma, while quartzite is found locally in the Uvalde Gravels washed out in streams and riverbeds. By the Late Prehistoric, however, this ratio had shifted dramatically. The lithic evidence, combined with other data points (shell tool and ceramic use, for instance), signals a notable change in Indigenous behavior, the resource optimization of, and relationship to the Hickory Creek landscape in the Late Prehistoric period. Research Issue 3: Site Changes Through Time Based on the data and interpretations outlined above, Acacia was interested if and how these cultural patterns changed over time. There was no evidence of Early Archaic occupation at either site, yet throughout the Middle Archaic, a period lasting about 2,000 years, significant and repeated occupations spring up across the floodplains. These sites are occupied sporadically over several thousand years with relatively little cultural or environmental change evidenced in the recovered material record. However, there is a significant shift from the Archaic into the Late Prehistoric period that, aided by better preservation, shows changing technologies but continued use of the riparian- woodland environmental mosaic resources. Additionally, there are several datapoints that stand out and are explored below. First, at site 41DN580 all the roughly datable Category 1 feature scatters of FCR are from the earlier Middle Archaic I (5000-4800 cal BP) occupation. Later occupations at this site and 41DN624 have a more balanced distribution of feature types. If Acacia’s experimental data and interpretations hold, this could suggest more of a focus on stone-boiling in the Middle Archaic shifting to an increased use of earth ovens in later periods. In addition, out of all 29 features examined at both sites, Middle Archaic 41DN580 Feature 16 and 41DN624 Feature 6 (both Category 3) bear striking resemblance to each other and are dissimilar in construction to most later earth ovens. These are relatively shallow pits lined with very large, tabular pieces of sandstone, unlike the later features which are generally made with more densely stacked mounds of rock. These are the only two features excavated whose larger flat stones could be interpreted as griddles, in addition to the central depression that could of course be used to roast other foodstuffs. When combined with the lack of vertebrate faunal remains could also plausibly indicate a different resource-focus of the people occupying the sites in the earlier parts of the Middle Archaic. During the Middle Archaic II periods at either site, Acacia uncovered not just features but also notable activity areas. These are represented by Features 10, 11, and 13 at site 41DN624 and in Units 69-80 at 41DN580. Each of these activity areas comprises a notable number of lithics, scatters of mussel shell, and some faunal material, while thermal features are set away from these areas. Faunal materials recovered from these areas also show more evidence of carnivore modification on faunal bone than other parts of the sties, suggesting these areas were left open to scavengers for longer periods of time, (Ramsey, Jacobson, and Haliburton Chapter 10). Similar activity areas are not present in either earlier Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 375

## Page 400

or later components at either site. This could suggest several possible behavioral changes, including that the groups occupying the sites were at these locations for longer periods of time and so defined activity areas were more necessary, and/or that the types of activities taking place were more intensive and therefore left more of an archeological signature. It could also be that similar activity areas are present in other periods but are outside of our current right-of-way and so remain unidentified. The most dramatic change at either site is between the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. Not only does the material record become more abundant, but the types of technologies represented also change. The lithic materials indicate the greatest change. First, the lithic points recovered show the shift in technologies from the larger dart points of earlier period to the smaller arrow points. Moreover, the ratio of local to non-local lithic source material significantly shifted. Across the Archaic period assemblages, nearly 80% of the lithics recovered come from Edwards Plateau chert. This could simultaneously indicate that people during this period had wide ranging exchange networks and likely were highly mobile across the whole region. By the Late Prehistoric, that ratio had shifted to only 14% non-local material, which we interpret to represent a significant decrease in mobility and territory size, while maintaining at least some trade relationships. Additionally, these Late Prehistoric lithic tools exhibit a notable amount of refurbishing and retouching, some have use-wear that suggests their function changed during their use life (Ayala and Pontillo, Chapter 8). The types of faunal materials in the Archaic and Late Prehistoric components are broadly similar, although the preservation rates are drastically different. Beyond being able to better reconstruct the Late Prehistoric environment and identify likely food sources, faunal materials also show a variety of tools used by site occupants. These include a partial bone needle, mussel shells possibly used as hoes or other tools, and ceramics. While possibly a result of preservation bias, this change in the material record could also indicate an intensity of site occupation – in either longevity or group size – and an increase in the types of activities taking place not seen in earlier periods. Additionally, the geoarcheological data generally show consistent, slow rates of deposition at both sites during the periods of known occupation (Lawrence and Eyeington, Chapter 7). At site 41DN580, deposition rates for the oldest Zones VI and V (Bk1 and Bk2 horizons) encompassing Features 5, 8, and possibly Features 15–17 roughly ~5000–4800 BP is between 2.4 and 3.7 cm per 100 years. Zone IV (Bk1 horizon) encompassing Feature 3 and possibly Features 4–6 at roughly ~4000– 3800 BP has a higher deposition rate of 5.2 cm per 100 years. Finally, the most recent prehistoric occupation in the partially truncated Zone II (A horizon) encompassing Feature 14 at roughly ~750– 700 BP has an average sedimentation rate of 4.4 cm per 100 years. Moreover, stable carbon isotope (δ13C) analyses suggest that at the base of the excavations in the Bk2 and Bk3 horizons, the environment for the site was mixed grassland and arboreal. After that, the C4 biomass increased with more dominant grasslands until the upper A horizon. From the A horizon to the surface, the C4 biomass decreased and was returning to a mixed grassland and arboreal environment. Thus, most of the site’s occupation took place during a period of mixed grassland and arboreal environment with moderate deposition rates. Similarly at site 41DN624, occupation in the oldest in Zone IV (Bk2 horizon), encompassing Features 6–8 between ~5900–5600 BP, and Zone IV (Bk1 horizon) encompassed by Feature 12 and possibly Features 9 and 10 between ~3700–3500 BP, deposition rates averaged 1.7 cm per 100 years. In Zone III, Feature 3 and possibly Features 4–6 at roughly ~2900–2700 Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 376

BP, deposition rates averaged 7 cm per 100 years. This is a significant increase from previous periods of occupation. Environmentally, although fluctuating, stable carbon isotope (δ13C) data suggest that the environment for 41DN624 has been predominantly composed of C4 biomass with grasslands. Within the lower Btk horizon and overlying Bk2 horizon, the δ13C values show decreasing C4 biomass and the environment was approaching mixed grassland and arboreal for periods of time. Together, these data broadly suggest a relatively stable and predictable local environment over the long term, potentially leading to the area’s reoccupation over time (Lawrence and Eyeington, Chapter 7). Overall, our data suggest that the broad patterns of Archaic life along Hickory Creek were relatively stable. Despite discrepancies in preservation, the data show relatively small changes over time. While specific resource availability and use may have varied over time, the people occupying the sites through time focused on riparian-woodland mosaic resources, many of which benefit from long cooking in earth ovens, bringing with them heavily utilized tools from high-quality sources mostly from areas farther south. These lifeways persisted until the Late Prehistoric period, when widespread technological changes precipitated changes at the local level as well. Research Issue 4: Regional Interactions and the Henrietta focus This study posits that for much of the Archaic period, Indigenous peoples used the Hickory Creek waterway in their seasonal migration corridor, stopping along its banks for short periods of time to gather mussels, hunt deer and other animals, and possibly collect edible plants before moving on to camps elsewhere. The people who stopped at sites 41DN580, 41DN624, and other sites traveled in small groups, likely not more than 20 people. A preponderance of lithic artifacts on Edwards chert suggests that central Texas was regularly within their seasonal rounds, but it is not entirely clear how far north, west, and east they ranged. This mobile hunting and foraging strategy, based on optimizing the use of resources, was widespread across the Southern Plains and throughout Texas during the period from ca. 5900-3500 BP. What’s more, data from sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 suggest the pattern of land use along Hickory Creek changed very little between ca. 5900 BP and 2700 BP. The Late Prehistoric component at site 51DN580, however, offers a glimpse into a marked shift in behavior, social organization, and regional interactions. This time was one of tremendous social change in North America, reflected by highly visible technological changes, such as the introduction of the bow and arrow, pottery, and incipient horticulture. During the period overlapping the Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580, ca. 700-800 BP, peoples west, north, and east of what is today north-central Texas were already less mobile. Native groups were beginning to settle more permanently in hamlets or small villages and these often articulated with larger regional centers. Pottery was becoming more common, particularly among the Caddo to the east, coastal groups to the south, and the Puebloan/Mogollon peoples to the west. Many of these same peoples had begun to practice some form of farming, or at the very least, horticulture. Social organization was becoming more complex and territorial, evidenced by ceremonial centers and larger cemeteries. All this was happening even as the peoples across much of Texas, particularly north-central, central, and south Texas, still practiced a seasonally mobile hunting and gathering lifestyle and even as ranging Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 377

Social spheres surrounding site 41DN580 ca. AD 1200. As already discussed, the 41DN580 Late Prehistoric component assemblage compares favorably to the Henrietta focus component at the Harrell site, located approximately 90 miles west. However, there are important differences. First, it is clear the Harrell Site was much more intensively used, and by larger groups than the people who camped at 41DN580. Not only were features and debris of all types more abundant at the Harrell Site, but that site also has a cemetery, which is not present within the investigated portion of 41DN580. While there is evidence of horticulture and longer-term settlement at the Harrell site, there are none of those elements at 41DN580, again, at least in the portion of it that we investigated. Side notched arrow points, notably Harrell and Washita points, are also absent. What we do have at 41DN580 are abundant faunal remains, shell-tempered Nocona plain ceramics, stemmed arrow points such as Alba and others, a fragment of what appears to be a bone needle or awl, and modified mussel shell and shell tools that were probably used for digging, scraping, polishing, scooping, woodworking, and leatherworking. is very rarely documented in the archeological literature of north-central Texas. The best comparisons within Texas are found at coastal and mortuary sites, although outside of Texas there is comparative data from similar age Mississippian period sites along the Missouri, Mississippi, and Illinois River basins hundreds of miles north/northeast of site 41DN580 (Lamb 2011; McLeester 2019). With respect to mussel shell tools, the Harrell site offers the best regional comparison to 41DN580. Unfortunately, the Harrell Site is not well-dated, nor is Krieger’s (1948) Henrietta focus well- defined. There are scant other investigated sites attributed to the elusive Henrietta focus. Other sites believed to have Henrietta focus components include 41TR56 (Tarrant County), 41SE300 (Stephens County), 41TH26 (Throckmorton County), 41DY13 (Donley County), 41YN23 (Young County), and a handful of sites in Clay County, nearly all of them recorded in the 1950s and 60s and not revisited in recent years. Most of these sites have human burials and Harrell or Washita points associated with them along with a wide variety of other arrow point styles. Krieger estimated the Henrietta focus spanned from about AD 1200-1400 and believed it to be related to early Plains Villager cultures north of Red River. He based these interpretations on evidence for early horticulture and similarities in assemblages, notably side-notched arrow points and Nocona Plain ceramics, which are abundant on Paoli and Washita River Phase Plains Villager sites of Oklahoma (Drass 1998; Ellis et al. 2015). In terms of geographic extent, Krieger drew the Henrietta focus boundary to include Upper Trinity River Basin, which would include the Hickory Creek watershed. If the upper component at site 41DN580 can be considered within the Henrietta focus tradition, then it is not the type of permanent settlement Krieger and others used as their prototype. Rather, it is more of a short-term encampment at the eastern margin of what we understand to be Henrietta’s extent. Significantly, our dates for site 41DN580 are about 200 years earlier than Krieger estimated the Henrietta focus to be, with about AD 1200 being the upper end of 41DN580’s occupation. So where then does 41DN580 fit in? The site’s shell-tempered Nocona Plain ceramics place it squarely within a shared north Texas/Oklahoma Plains sphere of interaction not shared by the cultures elsewhere in Texas in that same time period. Although Caddo potters east of the Upper Trinity drainage basin already had an advanced ceramic tradition, shell tempering is not common in the Caddo region until after AD 1400 (Drass 1998; Ellis et al. 2015; Perttula, Chapter 9). Meanwhile modified shell tools and adornments can possibly be linked to sites like the Harrell site, sites of the upper Midwest, and possibly sites along the Gulf Coast. Lithic tools also suggest a changing sphere of interaction through time. While Edwards chert from south in central Texas dominates the Middle Archaic assemblages at sites 41DN580 and 41DN624, the Late Prehistoric component reflects a different procurement strategy of local and Red River drainage basin sources. Put simply, whether site 41DN580 can be included in the Henrietta phase paradigm or not, it is evident that the dominant sphere of interaction for its inhabitants derived from regions north, as opposed to regions south in central Texas. This is not too different from what Krieger theorized following excavations at the Harrell Site (Texas Beyond History), although his timing of Henrietta Phase culture expressions may require some rethinking. Data from Site 41DN590 suggest this shift in influence may have begun by AD 1200 and possibly earlier, if dates from 41DN580 are reliable. Ultimately, more data from other sites are needed to better understand shifting spheres of influence in the Texas Late Prehistoric period. However, the preliminary implications from the data Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 379

16. R R D EASSESSING THE ESEARCH ESIGN Summary of Interpretations Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 are considered eligible for listing as SAL and in the NRHP. Acacia implemented a data recovery plan at both sites. The THC concurred in December 2021 and February of 2022 that these field efforts mitigated the project’s effects within the Hickory Creek Interceptor ROW. Any future projects that could impact either site outside of the current project area warrant further consideration to assess the possibility of additional contributing components. With these considerations, no further fieldwork is recommended or warranted. The testing and data recovery investigations at 41DN580 and 41DN624 sought to address site chronologies and reuse over time, environmental conditions and adaptive strategies, group size, and mobility patterns. These efforts found that both are multicomponent sites. 41DN580 has intact stratified components that date to the Middle Archaic as well as the Late Prehistoric period, while stratified components at site 41DN624 represent occupations from the Middle and Late Archaic periods. One contribution of this work has been to present new archeological data from north-central Texas on the period ranging from 5900-3700 BP, what is generally considered to be the Middle Archaic period. Previously, only two sites with components from this period had been excavated or reported, and the data from those components were neither extensive, nor were they truly separatable from discussions of older and younger components. Until excavations at 41DN580 and 41DN624, the Middle Archaic period was essentially missing from the north-central Texas record. For this reason alone, the data presented here for sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 represent a comparative record not previously available to researchers. Further, the Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580 containing ceramics and shell tools offers new data of another kind. It was found only during data recovery excavations—as a complete surprise to investigators. Consideration of this component was not accounted for in the research design prepared for this project as it was not identified during previous efforts. Nonetheless, this component not only provides key comparative data presented in this report, but also offers a critical launchpad for new avenues of analysis and study. Most notably, the component describes an important and understudied data set – modified mussel shells – and offers new insights into regional spheres of interaction among Late Prehistoric periods in north-central Texas. The variety of features from sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 indicates multiple types of hot-rock cooking activities from stone boiling to long baking in earth ovens. People collected resources for these activities locally from the adjacent creek beds and surrounding mosaic environment. The lithic tool assemblage shows interregional mobility across the state was high during the Archaic period. Further, feature data indicates these groups were likely small and did not stay on these sites very long. During their stays they accessed both riverine and terrestrial resources, possibly during the late summer or fall season. In the aggregate, data from these sites further support existing hypotheses that suggest the Trinity River basin of north-central Texas was a thoroughfare for small bands of highly mobile people who returned seasonally and repeatedly to certain locales that offered a mixed woodland and Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 381


---

## Page 406

grassland mosaic for hunting and gathering of plant and faunal resources. Notably, data from 41DN580 and 41DN624 reflect that the general pattern of mobility, group size, and resource use likely remained consistent throughout the Archaic period. Although the sites do demonstrate a slightly increased number of features and size of the artifact assemblage through time during the Archaic period, given preservation issues and other site formation processes, it may not be possible to identify clear changes in land use, group mobility, and resource procurement during this period. On the other hand, organic preservation issues aside, there is some clear evidence that a significant change in land and resource use patterns occurred during the Late Prehistoric period, around 800 BP. More locally sourced lithic materials from the Late Prehistoric component at 41DN580 suggest decreasing mobility. This is reinforced by the presence of shell-tempered Nacona Plain and Nacona Brushed pottery, which is found throughout the Trinity, Brazos, and Red River basins. Although shell-tempered Nacona ceramics – when first identified at the Harrell site in Young County – were originally thought to be the product of Southern Plains trade form the north and west, there is recent evidence that strongly suggests these ceramics were manufactured locally (Crook and Houghston 2015). At site 41DN580, shell tools and a single polished bone tool, likely a needle or awl, also suggest the people who encamped here had a broad toolkit. In short, a wider range of activities took place at site 41DN580 in the Late Prehistoric period than during any of the Archaic period occupations. Congregations may have focused less on processing foods and resources in earth ovens and griddles during short-term encampments, and more on processing and/or storing resources in pots, cooking atop a fire, and possibly even ceramic manufacture. This assemblage suggests that people who stopped in the Late Prehistoric engaged in a more generalized provisioning and range of activities while there. Unfortunately, we simply do not currently have enough data from the Late Prehistoric component at site 41DN580 to assess duration of encampment or size of the groups. We hypothesize, however, they may have been operating in a smaller territory, one focused more heavily on the area around the Trinity River basin. Conclusions The research design for data recovery of sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 specified that Acacia would articulate research questions through an iterative process of analysis and reporting first on all of the testing data and then following submittal of a second interim report and research design, on the second phase data recovery materials. However, separating out the analyses into two phases once the material was collected was simply not practical, particularly for lithic, shell, and bone artifacts, if for no other reason than there we so few of them found during the testing phase. Thus, all of the artifacts from testing and data recovery efforts were analyzed together as a single collection. Moreover, we found that by the time we had assembled all the data together to develop new or alternative research questions, we had effectively completed most of the work and written the report documenting both testing and data recovery work. This report presents a complete discussion of all studies and data. All artifacts collected during these efforts will be curated along with project records at the Center for Archaeological Studies (CAS) in San Marcos. ## Page 527

Site 41DN580 Trench A (documented and sampled during Significance Test Excavations June 2021) Seventeen-meter-long trench was oriented north-south, a 4 m wide section of the west profile examined. No cultural materials observed within examined profile area. Zone Ia 0-9 cmbs (174.90-174.81 elev.): Dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) clay loam; friable consistency; subangular blocky structure, medium size, moderate grade; many rootlets, few worm burrows, many 1 mm burrows, Hydrochloric (HCl) reaction was slight visual and slight audible; lower boundary was abrupt and smooth. Horizon is disturbed fill material with few subrounded gravels and small cobbles. Ap1 horizon appears to be dredge material on recent Holocene alluvium. Zone I 9-20 cmbs (174.81-174.70 elev.): Dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) clay loam; friable consistency; subangular blocky structure, medium size, moderate grade; many rootlets, few worm burrows, many 1 mm burrows, HCl reaction was slight visual and slight audible; lower boundary was abrupt and smooth. Ap2 horizon is initial ground surface on recent Holocene alluvium. Zone II 20-52 cmbs (174.70-174.38 elev.): Very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) loam-clay loam; friable consistency; subangular blocky parting to angular blocky structure, medium size, strong grade; common worm burrows, few rootlets, few snail fragments, few silt coats, HCl reaction was slight visual and slight audible; lower boundary was clear and smooth. A horizon. Possible West Fork soil. Zone III 52-105 cmbs (174.38-173.85 elev.): Brown (10YR 4/3) to dark grayish brown (10YR 4/4) silt loam; friable consistency; prismatic structure, medium size, strong grade; few rootlets, few snail fragments, few Rabdotus snail, common 1 mm burrows, few 1 mm calcium carbonate (CaCO3) filaments with dendritic arrangement, HCl reaction was strong visual and strong audible; lower boundary was gradual and smooth. Bk1 horizon. Pilot Point alloformation. Zone IV 105-157 cmbs (173.85-173.33 elev.): Yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) silt clay loam; friable consistency; prismatic structure, medium size, strong grade; few rootlets, few snail fragments, few Rabdotus snail, few 1 mm burrows, many 1-2 mm CaCO3 filaments, few 10 mm subrounded pebbles and small gravels, few 1-2 mm crystals (possibly CaCO3 or gypsum), HCl reaction was strong visual and strong audible; lower boundary was gradual and smooth. Bk2 horizon. Sanger alloformation. Zone V 157-292+ cmbs (173.33-171.97 elev.): Yellowish brown-light yellowish brown (10YR 5/4–6/4) silt clay loam; friable consistency; prismatic structure, medium size, strong grade; few rootlets, few snail fragments, few Rabdotus snail, few 1 mm burrows, many 1-2 mm CaCO3 filaments, few 10 mm subrounded pebbles and small gravels, few 1-2 mm crystals (possibly gypsum), HCl reaction was strong visual and strong audible; lower boundary was unobserved. Bk3 horizon. Sanger alloformation. Testing and Data Recovery of Sites 41DN580 and 41DN624 503

## Page 528

Trench B (documented and sampled during Significance Test Excavations June 2021) Five-meter-long trench was oriented north-south, with the west and south walls examined. No cultural materials observed within examined profile area. Zone I 0-14 cmbs (174.21-174.073 elev.): Dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) clay loam; friable consistency; subangular blocky structure, medium size, moderate grade; many rootlets, few worm burrows, many 1 mm burrows, HCl reaction was slight visual and slight audible; lower boundary was abrupt and smooth. Ap horizon on recent Holocene alluvium. July 27, 2021 Mr. Ken Lawrence SWCA 4407 Monterey Oaks Blvd. Suite 110 Austin, TX 78749 United States RE: Radiocarbon Dating Results Dear Mr. Lawrence, Enclosed are the radiocarbon dating results for nine samples recently sent to us. As usual, the method of analysis is listed on the report with the results and calibration data is provided where applicable. The Conventional Radiocarbon Ages have all been corrected for total fractionation effects and where applicable, calibration was performed using 2020 calibration databases (cited on the graph pages). The web directory containing the table of results and PDF download also contains pictures, a cvs spreadsheet download option and a quality assurance report containing expected vs. measured values for 3-5 working standards analyzed simultaneously with your samples. Reported results are accredited to ISO/IEC 17025:2017 Testing Accreditation PJLA #59423 standards and all chemistry was performed here in our laboratory and counted in our own accelerators here. Since Beta is not a teaching laboratory, only graduates trained to strict protocols of the ISO/IEC 17025:2017 Testing Accreditation PJLA #59423 program participated in the analyses. As always Conventional Radiocarbon Ages and sigmas are rounded to the nearest 10 years per the conventions of the 1977 International Radiocarbon Conference. When counting statistics produce sigmas lower than +/- 30 years, a conservative +/- 30 BP is cited for the result unless otherwise requested. The reported d13C values were measured separately in an IRMS (isotope ratio mass spectrometer). They are NOT the AMS d13C which would include fractionation effects from natural, chemistry and AMS induced sources. When interpreting the results, please consider any communications you may have had with us regarding the samples. Thank you for prepaying the analyses. As always, if you have any questions or would like to discuss the results, don’t hesitate to contact us. Sincerely, Chris Patrick Vice President of Laboratory Operations Page 1 of 19

## Page 556

Quality Assurance Report This report provides the results of reference materials used to validate radiocarbon analyses prior to reporting. Known-value reference materials were analyzed quasi-simultaneously with the unknowns. Results are reported as expected values vs measured values. Reported values are calculated relative to NISTSRM-1990C and corrected for isotopic fractionation. Results are reported using the direct analytical measure percent modern carbon (pMC) with one relative standard deviation. Agreement between expected and measured values is taken as being within 2 sigma agreement (error x 2) to account for total laboratory error. Report Date: July 27, 2021 Submitter: Mr. Ken Lawrence QA MEASUREMENTS Reference 1 Expected Value: 96.69 +/- 0.50 pMC Measured Value: 96.52 +/- 0.28 pMC Agreement: Accepted Reference 2 Expected Value: 0.44 +/- 0.10 pMC Measured Value: 0.45 +/- 0.03 pMC Agreement: Accepted Reference 3 Expected Value: 129.41 +/- 0.06 pMC Measured Value: 129.48 +/- 0.35 pMC Agreement: Accepted COMMENT: All measurements passed acceptance tests. Validation: Date: July 27, 2021

## Page 568

Procedures for sample processing and single-grain OSL age analysis: All samples were opened and processed under dim amber safelight conditions within the lab. Sample processing for quartz optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) dating followed standard procedures involving sieving, HCl and bleach treatments, heavy mineral separation at 2.72 g/cm3, and acid treatments with HCl and HF to isolate the quartz component of a narrow grain-size range, 150-250 µm. The purity of the quartz samples was checked by measurement with infra-red stimulation to detect the presence of feldspar. The USU Luminescence Lab follows the latest single-aliquot regenerative-dose (SAR) procedures for single-grain (SG) OSL dating of quartz sand (Duller et al., 1999; Murray and Wintle, 2000, 2003; Wintle and Murray, 2006; Duller, 2008). The SAR protocol includes tests for sensitivity correction and brackets the equivalent dose (D ) the sample received during burial by irradiating the sample at five different E doses (below, at, and above the D , plus a zero dose and a repeated dose to check for recuperation of E the signal and sensitivity correction). The resultant data are fit with a saturating exponential curve or linear regression for young sediments. Cumulative D is calculated on the Central Age Model E (CAM) or the Minimum Age Model (MAM) of Galbraith and Roberts (2012), depending on the distribution of D results and evidence for partial bleaching*. In cases where the samples have E significant positive skew, ages are calculated based on a MAM. The SG-OSL age is reported at 1σ standard error and is calculated by dividing the D (in grays, Gy) by the environmental dose rate E (Gy/kyr) that the sample has been exposed to during burial. More details on OSL analyses and results are available upon request. Dose-rate calculations were determined by chemical analysis of the U, Th, K and Rb content using ICP- MS and ICP-AES techniques and conversion factors from Guérin et al. (2011). The contribution of cosmic radiation to the dose rate was calculated using sample depth, elevation, and latitude/longitude following Prescott and Hutton (1994). Dose rates are calculated based on water content, sediment chemistry, and cosmic contribution (Aitken and Xie, 1990; Aitken, 1998). Under the collaborative agreement to analyze samples at the USU Luminescence Lab, please consider including Dr. Rittenour as a co-author on resultant publications. Contact me for additional information and help with describing the OSL technique when you plan your publication.
